From: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Subject: hearing protection

Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I finally got more of those earplugs I like -- they are my absolute 
favorites so far.

They are made by Howard Leight company, Santa Monica 90404.
They are rated at 30dB. This is with an assumption of ambient volume of 92dB.
I have the chart showing attenuation at different frequencies, along with 
the standard deviation... if anyone wants it, ask and I'll post it.

We got these earplugs (model Max Lite R-LPF-5-RO) at a gun store in Sac.. 
they run about $2.50 for five pairs, unless you get them at Uncle Ralph's 
in Berkeley, where they are $3.00 for *one* pair.

Maui



From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct  1 04:15:11 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: Sunset Cancelled
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> 
> Hi y'all (sic)
> 
> I know it's a drag when somebody gets greedy or whatever and imbibes
> too much, causing problems for themselves and others, *but*, I'd be
> *surprised* to find that among those who do *anything* there are people
> who have *never* made the mistake of taking too much of something [the
> *what* doesn't really matter, too much of anything can be a drag].
> 
> While this may have shut down a party, I think it's good to remember
> that many of us have been there and some of us will likely be there
> again, at some point in our lives...let's not let society's attitude
> about intoxication make us forget that the person afflicted and their
> health/safety/comfort is *more* important than partying whether the
> cops got called or not.  I doubt that the person involved is not clear
> on the concept that they made a mistake, so let's not get down on 'em
> too hard whoever they might be.  Unless this person does this repeatedly
> [as in regularly, has been spoken to and still doesn't do anything],
> they deserve a little sympathy and support and could probably use it now
> more than ever.
>

It seems to me that the real reson that the permit was revoked was the
simple fact that there were about 700 people at sunset.

With this many people and absolutely _no_ security, they feel like it is
a tragedy waiting to happen.  I'm sure the fact that someone was spaced out
on drugs merely provided the excuse to close sunset.

I know Galen and others also had misgivings about  continuing the party
at Berkeley Marina also because they felt that the party was becoming too
"popular".  He we can clearly see the problems with regular free outdoor
"renegade" parties.  Once they become predictable then you get people who
want to come for other reasons then to party, be they "gangstas" or 
"undercovers".  I think Galen has done a good job and also has shown a
Large City Police Department some very positive sides of the scene.

My feeling is that even if there were undercovers there watching people,
they would have to be total indoctrinated zelots not to see the love and
caring and natural happiness of the crowd.  I'm sure some of them have compared
what they saw to what they would see in a bar or night club and I know
at least some of them should have been moved.  I think that Galen and the police
have an understanding and even though the parties may not continue there,
I hope that maybe Galen has built a bridge between our community and
"law enforcement".



> 
> *
> 
> > Galen seemed to understand why the cops revoked the permit
> > I think He is just dissappointed that it was one of the family who 
> > screwed up. We screwed it up for ourselves basically.
> > 
> > salutations, allen@ameba
> 

Yeah, as long as there aren't any incidents that make them look bad, they
were willing to tolerate it.  But when someone else call them to the scene
then they have to respond and file a report and the report becomes official
so they can be held accountable for what happens.

Here is the problems with these types of parties, you don't want to be
exclusive but when the party becomes easy and reliable to find, the you
get all kinds of "unwanted attention", this, among other things has
been one of the major problems with the FMR.  One way to eliviate
gangstas and police is to start your party on a _LATE_ weeknight.  The
police are usually not overly active and most gangstas will be passed
out once the liquor stores close at 2, they generaly aren't in the mood
by that time to do any long road trips just for amusement.  It also
keeps the numbers down.  The last couple of Full Moons have been pretty
good.  The Sacto full moon was without incident, it started around 3
am.  The delta full moon also started around 3 and was a success.  The
most recent Berkeley Full Moon started at 2:30.  In all of these cases
the police of the city were aware that a party was taking place and
allowed it to happen.  Once an incident occurs, they can no longer
"ignore" that it is happening.  Ok course the bad part of this is that it
weeds out a lot of cool people who just can't stay up that late (and go to
work the next day) this is unfortunate but necessary.

last

but really smokey.  At some point the cops showed up, but the guy at the 
door must have played it cool because the cop never actually made it 
inside the house.

and I was going to give him my email address, but no one had a pen.  Oh 
well, sometimes you just have to chalk it up to entropy and keep on 
truckin'.

> I went to this house party at 506 Haight last night.  It was pretty cool, 
> but really smokey.  At some point the cops showed up, but the guy at the 
> door must have played it cool because the cop never actually made it 
> inside the house.

For the police to enter a private residence, they need either a warrant 
or good probable cause to suspect that criminal activity is taking place. 
They are *not* entitled to enter without one of these. And having loud music 
is *not* probable cause.

I think it's best if we don't let them in to our parties, as then they 
will forget that they are doing so with *your permission* and will start 
to feel like they have a right to enter, which they don't.

I would like the opinions of others out there, though....


Maui

From: child@netcom.com (Spaced-out Funky Earthchild)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Sunset maybe not over
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


To whoever this may concern:

If you think that Sunset is over, then it's over.  Boy, what a pushover - that
was easy.  If I told you that because of a certain incident, partying was over
would you go along with that too?  
If someone destroyed their apartment in your building and the police said, "ok
that's it, everybody living in this apartment complex must move out because one
of you is rotten"  would you move out?

If Sunset is not at some other location, I might make it to the Marina with a
boom box.  I remember at the Sacto full moon, some cops showed up and everybody
started asking, "is it over?"  I said, "no way".  It continued without 
incident BUT if everybody had just thought it was over, it WOULD have been 
over.  You see, it takes two to tango (or not tango).

If you want Sunset to be over (read, if you believe Sunset is over), then it 
will be over.  Let's not be sheep, leave that to the sheep and the sheep 
herders, and in my opinion, there's far too many of this kind living among the
human population.  Doesn't America pride itself on independent thinking?  Well
join the ranks of independent thinkers, if you aren't already - there's no
signing of a contract (unspoken or otherwise) required.  If you still have to
live within the context of rule-based society and dire consequences will result
if you blatantly don't follow, then wear sheep's clothing but keep your mind
free, else change the rules!

In my guess, there is probably one person responsible for revoking or
extending a "permit".  Are 300 people gonna bend to the will of one 
person?  If you want to play the game the way the rules have been set up around
us (ie. necessity for permits, etc.) then maybe someone can talk with love and
understanding and empathy to that one person responsible for revoking the 
permit and get him/her to change his/her mind.  You never know......

This is of course, assuming that Galen wants to continue Sunset at the Marina.
If he doesn't someone else can easily do it instead.  The wheels are rolling...


If you haven't already, then free yourself! if you want....
Space

From: "'Dave Bayer'" <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Cops and society
To: SFRaves! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <199410011112.EAA04990@nexsys.nexsys.net>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9410011722.A28496-0100000@drought.berkeley.edu>

Precedence: bulk



On Sat, 1 Oct 1994, Geoff White wrote:

> My feeling is that even if there were undercovers there watching people,
> they would have to be total indoctrinated zelots not to see the love and
> caring and natural happiness of the crowd.  I'm sure some of them have compared
> what they saw to what they would see in a bar or night club and I know
> at least some of them should have been moved.  I think that Galen and the police
> have an understanding and even though the parties may not continue there,
> I hope that maybe Galen has built a bridge between our community and
> "law enforcement".

	I think you give a lot of cops too much credit here. From my 
experience, once crime (including the use of drugs, no, especially the 
use of drugs) enters the picture, cops tend to over look what else may be 
going on. All the 'love' associated with the rave is only a drug induced 
lose of control (or something to that effect), not real love, or even 
real caring... Just a bunch of societies useless getting "their fix" (a 
quote from some woman on the Berkeley police force after our stereo had 
been stolen, the implication was where there is crime, it must be caused 
by those evil drugs). While the Berkeley cops might be lax about a bowl 
or two, they do not seem to take the same view on e's and trips. While I 
do not mean to harsh directly upon the police force (maybe I do, I am not 
quite sure), I do not believe that they would necessarily be overcome by 
the 'pseduo-love' that these deviants of society believe they have 
found... While they might come to an 'understanding' with us or the people 
who bring the parties together, it does not have to be a result of 
understanding what goes on (except that it does not seem to be violent 
and mentally disturbing to others).

dave

	If a cop shows up you shouldn't even let them see inside the
door. Open the door, step outside, and close it *LOCKED* (make sure you
have your keys =) behind you.

> 
> 
> > I went to this house party at 506 Haight last night.  It was pretty cool, 
> > but really smokey.  At some point the cops showed up, but the guy at the 
> > door must have played it cool because the cop never actually made it 
> > inside the house.
> 
> For the police to enter a private residence, they need either a warrant 
> or good probable cause to suspect that criminal activity is taking place. 
> They are *not* entitled to enter without one of these. And having loud music 
> is *not* probable cause.
> 
> I think it's best if we don't let them in to our parties, as then they 
> will forget that they are doing so with *your permission* and will start 
> to feel like they have a right to enter, which they don't.
> 
> I would like the opinions of others out there, though....
> 
> 
> Maui
>

>It seems odd that it took them this long to react. I 
>barely noticed the  incident on Sun. and the party 
>certainly continued well after the ambulance  came and 
>went. All I know about the incident itself are 
>unconfirmed rumours  which would serve no purpose by 
>repeating. I wonder what the conditions of  the permit 
>were that they can revoke it so arbitrarily?
>
>Joe
>

the reason it took them so long to react is because its the 
berkeley police dept. galen was dealing with.  because of their 
history of dealing with large crowds (demonstrations, riots, 
frats, faires, etc.) they are "hip" shall we say to feeling the 
vibe of a large group and reacting only as necessary.  this is 
what makes the loss of the marina location hurt even more.  it 
happened in a place where the police were probably quite 
willing to let it go on indefinitely with little or no hassle 
as long as we were responsible for ourselves and each other.  
as a long time berkeley resident i know this to be true.  thnx 
galen for a beautiful summer vibe.  thnx everyone else for 
sharing in the healing that will have to take place in the face 
of this major f*ckup by the group (we owe it to each other to 
share responsibility. we are each others keepers).  let's start 
the healing now.

peace&positivity,
g-n-c
house archives

>  Who was that referee?  I really liked the set by the DJ spinning early

That dj was DRC.  I think she is a really hot dj.  She kept me dancing
through her entire set.  2 guys came all the way from LA just to hear her
spin.  Well worth it.  Then came Dutch.  Again he was very good at the
beginning of his set then he switched to some more house music
(unfortunately it kind of slowed me down).  He had a great mix of Sven
Vath's new release "Harlequin-beauty and the beast".

All and all I enjoyed myself *alot*.  Good variety of people.  I think
Kairo did an outstanding job with painted panels and all the decor.  I left
quite early (2:30)ish.  Did the music pick-up after the belly dancer
performed her candle dance?

I enjoyed seeing many sfravers.  Hope I would have met some new ones.  I
was the one wearing the crude "F*ck La Mode" black T shirt.  It means
"screw fashion" in french.  It did get too hot right away, took one layer
off which helped a little.  I was also surprised at the poor ventilation.

In two weeks Alex will be spinning there.  He also spins some wicked
techno/trance sets.

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

Subject: Megatripolis
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Sun, 2 Oct 1994 17:37:01 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 2418      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Megatripolis  -  nice!

 I didn't stay all the way through until 6AM , but I enjoyed it while
I was there. It was a night of firsts for me.

 First , I had never been to the Trocedero before. I was told that the
decor last night was special for Megatripolis - a facinating environment
of banners , hangings , a big gong , and a few little altars.

 Of course , it was the first Megatripolis in S.F. for everyone. From
a flyer picked up there , it seems that it will be held every week.

 I finally got to hear and see Frazier Clark. He had a short speech at
10:30 , where he explained the Megatripolis concept to us -  given the
concept of a future perfect human state called Megatripolis - how  
would the Megatripolitans behave , and treat each other ? Megatripolis
in San Francisco  would be a space for us in the present to emulate 
with our behaviour how these future beings of this perfect future
would treat each other. 

 I also got to hear John Perry Barlow for the first time - the guy who
discovered the term "pronoia". He gave a short speech about himself and
his philosophy - I didn't catch everything , but there was one idea
that I managed to write down ... if there is a lot of bad shit in
your life , it's the sucking backwash of an impending wave of positive
magiacal energy. With the recent death of his wife , he is personally
putting this to the test.

 After the speakers were a dance group , but I was upstairs listening 
to Susan , and missed them. The music upstairs and downstairs was good -
upstairs turned into a kind of ambient/house/trance space , while the
main floor was the harder stuff. ( I'll leave the DJ reviews to others ).

 I never got to the other warehouse site - how was it?

 I left at about 2:30AM , around when the vendors started packing their 
wares. Bought a book from AK Distribution , then left.

 Lots of positive , friendly energy in the crowd. I met a guy in the line
named Steve who was new to San Francisco , and this was his first rave
event. I couldn't think of a better club style event for loosing one's
rave virginity! 

	Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com 

PSes - Hi Fred! * To fellow sf fan Mike ( I hope I got your name
 right ) , I hope you get that multicolor LED wand idea working! 
 *  Who's flicking message LED toy was that? * Susie , thanks for 
 my first every blowpop ( courtesy of Fred )! * Maui - pay attention
 to those landmarks next time!

Ann Loraine emotes:
> I'm so sad there's no sunset party today, esp since i couldn't make it out
> to megitripolis!  i want to dance!  

och, me too.  I tried to go to megatripolis but got there too late, around
midnight and stood in the back of a long line waiting to get in.  When a
guy came out around 1 and announced that they were not going to let anyone
in after 2 am, I decided I wasn't going to make it and took off.
Megatripolis did give out 2 for 1 passes for the next week (I assume they
will have a door next week) for anyone left in line.

Sigh.  I was hoping to hang out there all night because, for the weekend,
I have no place to sleep.  Fortunately, as I walked out of the line, one
of the many friends I called that day paged me with a couch to crash in 
offer.

Stupid me, I don't have any techno to listen to 'cause I packed it all into
storage in a rush to evacuate.  The storage place is closed today too.  All
I have to listen to is Live 105 and a Metalica CD.  

I don't mind being homeless for 48 hours.  But no techno?  It makes my
purple fuzzy heart hurt.

Purple Tiger

ps Not having something makes you realize how important it is to you, so
I'm happy for the lesson.

far, so I figured I'd let people know what is going on.  As of 
right now,  I've gotten 12 replies, for a total of 14 shirts.

important that you contact me  if you want one and haven't 
emailed me already (mrmeyer@netcom.com).  As you can see, 
newsgroup response isn't as huge as you might think --
every vote counts.

"I turned in my parents
and all I got was this lousy T-shirt."

	Since coming back to SF in June, I had been depressed about the 
overwhelming number of dance-while-staring-at-molecule-five-feet-in-front-
of-face-and-two-feet-above-everyone's-head partyer goers (No cut to any 
of you who might dance this way, just I am one of those 'annoying' people 
who make eye contact with everyone that happens to be around, if I can). 
At the beginning of Megatripolis, I felt I was in for another one of 
these nights of being an individual dancing with a bunch of individuals. 
A pleasant surprise was instore for me as Goa brought out some nice 
hiEnergy stuff which seemed to bring everyone out of their shells, or at 
least a lot of people out of their shells.
	Was also quite happy to find another whistler out there 
(if you are on this list, hello once more brother of high pitched 
noises), although I had someone tell me that whistles were uncool and 
passe and to just never blow the damn thing (her experience had far 
out-wieghted mine, she made clear).
	Aye, so thanks to everyone who was there and made the evening 
what it was. No thanks to the group of Brits who hounded certain people 
and ended up basicly stealing a bit of cash from someone...

dave

my thoughts of Megatripolis..
i wish we'd been there earlier to see all of DRC's set, she rocked..
heard some nice east-coast favorites to keep me thinking of home..:)
all in all it was realy nice to hear something over 126 bpm...:)
*but*. and this is my jjbig cheese here since i moved, is that i still have 
yet to hear any music at parties with melody. Being the thing i like 
best, there seems to be a lack of real melody in the music i've heard 
here (except a bit tonight), at least some sort of rhythmic hook...i 
dunno, this is just me babbling..i guess that's why i should start 
spinning myself. :)
but..i'd list the people i met at this party if i could remember all your 
names, so i won't mention anyone as i can't remember everyone. :)

megatripolis..
mikebee

When I first go there, it seemed like a pretty mixed and mixed up crowd in
many ways.  I was thinking to myself that it would be an 'individualistic'
kinda chaotic night, but as I walked around I realized that the sfr quotient
was high(Hi!) and knew that this would take off eventually.  I tried dancing
to the fast stuff, but this cold I've been trying to kick kept me off the
dancefloor till later.  This was cool though because I spent more time
upstairs talking and grooving on the chiller stuff.  Overall, pretty good
first party.  The question is, how much will it be next week and will I
(you,we) go?

     Raverfolk,,,
     
     WOW! Megatripolis was just so awesome! The trance cauldron DEFINITELY 
     lived up to it's title. The energy was so great, and it was great to 
     meet a bunch of you that I havent seen for a while! Apart from the 
     visuals that didnt get setup on time ( lasers, I should say ), it was 
     just *perfect*.. 
     
     Was I dreamin', or was this the best rave I've ever been to?
     
     BTW, The dj'd played in the order DRC, Dutch, Goa Gil, and finally 
     Christophe.... I loooooveed all their sets..but IMHO DRC and Dutch 
     played some wicked stuff ( no pun intended :) ).. Also, the dj mixing 
     with what I thought was MiniDiscs was Goa Gil... They were MDs , and 
     not DATs right?
     
     Well, cant wait for the next one!
     
     Rave on,, and keep smilin' folks!
     
     Si++

You'll find that in France, Germany and Holland that a lot of people speak     
English -- especially people who work in hotels, restaurants and other service
industries.

You can probably get by with a French/English dictionary.  (I've found that
phrase books are useless cuz they are never complete enough.  With the
dictionary, at least you have all the words in the language at your disposal.
Vocabulary is much more important than grammar.)

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199410032052.NAA22417@netcom11.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Megatripolus report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Megatripolus report
-------------------

   This Saturday evening,  the opening of Megatripolus West.    This is the West
Coast edition of the Megatripolus club in London.

   It was held in two places,   one across the street from the Trocadero in a small
warehouse.    The warehouse opened about 7 pm,   where people spoke and talked about
the following.

  ** Freedom and the constitution
  ** Hemp clothing and fashion show
  ** Help food and other materials from hemp.
  ** I talked on Cypherspace and protecting your privacy.
  
   After that,   people were lounging around,  waiting for the club to open around
10 pm.    The lines formed early,   and due to the popularity of the event,   some
people couldn't get in.  ID's WERE required,   but I think you had to be 18 to get
in.    After 2 am,   anyone could get in.

   In the downstairs front section,  there were food vendors,  selling sushi,  cookies,
and hemp food.    Upstairs, they had the chill out sections,  with these small little
cubby holes around the wall,  for people to sit inside and on top.

   Them was the main dance area,   which initially started up with house music,  but
was interrupted by a speach my Frazer Clark and John Barlow.    After that,  the music
started and I wasted NO TIME in getting out there and dancing.

   About the only really bummer part of Megatripolus were these two English dudz who
kept bugging me and asking who was selling drugs.  They were especially pushey,  and
really loused up my head space.   I followed them around for a while and noticed
that they didn't dance,   they busted someone for pot,  and were constantly moving
around.   If they were narcs they were doing a piss poor job of it.   They eventually
left about 3 am.

   The sound system was totally insane,   except when the front speaker system would
cut in and out.    Eventually,  they fixed it.   When Goa went on,  the energy level
shot up about 3 notches,  and friends that told me they had to go home,  decided to
stay.    It was the most brilliant set that Goa played...   Later,  the music was
interrupted for some kind of ritual,  but eventually started up again.

   People were allowed in and out,   but once it got filled to capacity,  they
weren't letting anyone else in.    Security people were rude and pushey,  and
were even hostile to people working at Megatripolus and their promoters.  For
instance,  when I wanted to go to the warehouse to find someone with diskettes,
I had to wait about 35 minutes to get back in,  yet before I left,  I was assured
that there would be no delays.

   Ventilation was very poor,   and little or no relief from smoke and the heat,
dispite the fact that the Troc has fans (Which they didn't put out),  and a
very powerful air conditioning system which they didn't turn on.    Later I
was told that the bar wanted to sell more drinks.   After 2 am,  water was NOT
FREE,  and costs 50 cents (No refills).

   The vibe was awsome...   VERY GOOD VIBE... Highest SFRaver quotent I've seen
in a long time.   Lots of smiles, love and joy.

   Although this FIRST edition of Megatripolus was free,  the next one will cost
$10.    Will you still go?

Here's my score (on 1 - 10 scale)

Vibe:   9
Chill out opportunities:  3
Music:  9
Sound system:  8
Chill Zone: 6
Visuals:   None
Decore:  8
Security:  2

CC

I had a fine time at Megatripolis, and hope that they do many more parties here.
Getting to see & hear Goa Gil was a real treat.  The music was a lot faster than
what I usually get to dance to, and I like that!  Lotsa dancing smiling people!


> Upstairs, they had the chill out sections...

And a sushi bar!  (Sushi and fast techno under one roof! Yowza!)

>   About the only really bummer part of Megatripolus were these two English 
dudz who
>kept bugging me...

Each of them asked me if I had any E.  I asked each of them why everybody 
asks me that.

>I followed them around for a while and noticed that they didn't dance,

If a narc dances too much, he loses his capacity for being a narc, y'know.

>   People were allowed in and out,   but once it got filled to capacity,  they
>weren't letting anyone else in.

The guy at the exit did at least warn us that we'd have a l-o-n-g wait to 
get back in.
That convinced me that I didn't really want to leave after all.
They did have a visit from the Fire Department before the party started.
I suspect that they didn't have much choice about how many they could let in 
at a time.

>   Ventilation was very poor

That was my only complaint.  I did find a few spots that seemed to get 
cross-ventilation
when the exit doors opened from time to time.

> After 2 am,  water was NOT FREE,  and costs 50 cents (No refills).

Downstairs.  If you went upstairs, you could get all the water you wanted from
the drinking fountain.  The guy at the upstairs bar even gave me a cup to 
fill there.

That was my first time at the Troc, and I thought it was really nice for a club.
                         &andy
                         KC1IP/6
                         the tie-dyed side of the force

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9410040142.AA25464@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Megatripolus report
In-Reply-To: <199410032052.NAA22417@netcom11.netcom.com>
References: <199410032052.NAA22417@netcom11.netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

John Draper writes:

 > Ventilation was very poor, and little or no relief from smoke and
 > the heat, dispite the fact that the Troc has fans (Which they
 > didn't put out), and a very powerful air conditioning system which
 > they didn't turn on.  Later I was told that the bar wanted to sell
 > more drinks.  After 2 am, water was NOT FREE, and costs 50 cents
 > (No refills).

 > Although this FIRST edition of Megatripolus was free, the next one
 > will cost $10.  Will you still go?

Not a chance in hell. I cannot in good faith give my money or
otherwise attend spaces that treat their patrons with contempt.

While I can't blame a promoter that has the misfortune of selecting a
space and finding out the night of the party that the spaceowner is
going to screw things up, I *do* blame promoters that reuse such
spaces. These promoters are dogs; they don't give a shit about people,
they only care about green paper. "Blah blah blah...it's the only
space we could use blah blah blah." Good promoters would rather not
throw the party at all than throw it and screw people.

Good promoters try and provide ventilation. They give you free cups
(at a cost to them of maybe $.01-$.02 each) and free water. They allow
you to walk outside and cool off. They make you stand in line only
once. They're polite at the door and genuinely glad you came.  They
have a smoking area that is not the main dance floor.  They don't turn
the sound up to hearing damage levels, and when problems arise they
try their best to fix them.

Every party I have been associated with has had these things. All of
them have been hailed as having a great vibe, and none of them have
lost money.

That's why you don't see me often at big parties. They're usually a
collaboration between asshole promoters and asshole spaceowners that
don't care about their patron's health, just their money. To those
that are the exception, you not only have my gratitude and respect,
you have my attendance.

How you treat your people sets the tone for your whole party.
Promoters make the difference, and loving promoters have made some
wonderful things happen. The "rave scene" will die off eventually as
it recedes like every other fad dominated by money. But the small
parties and other parties thrown for the love of it -- they'll live on
and on, as long as people want to share the love and music.

Put your money where your heart is.

Sean

On Mon, 3 Oct 1994, people complained:
> 
> >   Ventilation was very poor
> 
> That was my only complaint.  I did find a few spots that seemed to get 
> cross-ventilation
> when the exit doors opened from time to time.

	The temp in the Troc was not too bad in my opinion, but then I 
quite like to get a good sweat worked up (except I need a second shirt 
when a I leave, and the car windows get all sweated up as I try to drive 
home). When its hot, those spray cn/pump/whatever they are feel quite 
good as well, and those who had them on Saturday night brought out many 
smiles. I do however, assume that I can get unlimited free water in such 
a case which was not really the case on Sat. (except I got a cup when 
they were still free and held on to it, filling it in the bogs...) I 
didn't reallyt see/feel much smoke in the air. Granted it was not 
outside, but I have yet to get to a party where people get like they did 
during Goa's set (dancing/jumping/yelling/looking at each other/.....) 
under a sky which wisks your mind aomng the stars....
dave

	id UAA10257; Mon, 3 Oct 1994 20:18:11 -0700
Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 20:18:11 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Reply-To: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: YSH
To: Barry Alexander <peyote@ekstatic.com>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199410040122.SAA27841@holonet.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9410031843.A28356-0100000@netcom5>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> > We took the opportunity to use the space we had our last party in :)
> > 
> > So YSH is confirmed for Cyclone on Oct. 8th  :) :) :) :) :)
> > 
> > Maui
> > 
> > 
> 	what can anyone tell me about this space who has been there.
> 	i've heard the ysh parties are great and will go next week,
> 	but haven't heard of Cyclone space.  thanks in advance...
> 
> 	barry

Cyclone is a largish warehouse space that has been a going concern for 
quite a long time now. That means it doesn't get hassled by cops! It 
reminds me of Komotion, except that it is definitely larger. But like 
Komotion, the inhabitants are your peaceful cool anarchist types who also 
do punk shows.
Inside is pretty trippy -- the residents have their own individual 
loft-cubicles, which are suspended from the ceiling and only accessible 
by various ladderlike structures and catwalks. They're pretty 
cool-looking; it's hard to keep people off 'em :) So far I haven't had a 
problem with that, since there's only one way up.

This space also has a skateboard ramp(!) which we've been using as sort 
of a chill space.

If anyone wants to help out, we could use more cloth hangings to isolate 
different areas -- doesn't have to be fancy or anything. Just let me know...

Happy to answer questions :) .....

Maui

On Mon, 3 Oct 1994, John Draper wrote:

> Tony V Garcia writes:
> 
> >The music was neat, though a bit fast for me at the time.  I really 
> >enjoyed the last set, was that Christophe???  He slowed it down so that 
> >was nice. 
> 
> Ahhh!   But that fast stuff opens up a lot more dance possibilities...
> Plus it has a LOT HIGHER energy level   :-)
> 
> CC

well, yes, that's what i've been told by people that love the fast 
stuff.  but I like stuff that's below maybe 140, because i can hear all 
of the instruments (well, electronically generated natural sounds)  more 
clearly.  I guess that's why I liked the last set more.  I also spoke to 
other people who felt the same as me and had retreated to the ambient 
room with shields at maximum.  I wouldn't be surprised if the rave scene 
started splitting into subscenes (hardcore, gabber, fast trance, 
tribal).  I've heard that is what it is like in Europe.

Goa Gil (from what I remember) came out to SF over 2 years ago (Summer of
92) for a party called Planet Groove.  I didn't go but I remembered his
name on the flier, because the place he came from India, and up til then I
hadn't heard of any djs from Asian countries.  Apparently he made his mark
by playing massive (3000+ people) full moon raves on Anjuna Beach in India.
The summer of 92 was sort of the dawn of techno in SF, and since then I've
heard Goa Gil's name out here only sporadically.

Goa apparently plays off of DATs, and I think there's some kind of digital
equipment that he uses to beatmatch/cue tracks to some degree.

Personally, anything over 125 bpm is way too fast for me.  Call me an old
fogey... :)

j



jack@internex.net

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  3 22:19:55 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id WAA07696; Mon, 3 Oct 1994 22:19:55 -0700

Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 22:19:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: Tony V Garcia <deepfog@cats.ucsc.edu>
Subject: Megatripolus critique
To: Conscious Ravers <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9410032204.A12932-0100000@si.UCSC.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Overall, it was a good party.  I like the Trocadero, because it seems to 
have a good sound system, and it has an upstairs chill space which is 
lacking at the King St. location.  However, there were 2 things which I 
thought needed pointing out (maybe someone could pass this on to the 
people that ran this show):

SOUND-  Way too loud.  Everywhere I went in there, I could hear the 
little hairs in my ears falling out.  I wanted to go in the main dance 
area, but couldn't because I was afraid of ear damage.  Now I know it can 
be improved, because I went to one of Martin's events (Vision) in May and 
the sound was EXCELLENT.  And he had more speakers in there.  I had no 
problems that night.  Take some lessons on how to use sound properly or 
pass out earplugs at the door.  

ENDING-  First of all, it ended VERY abruptly.  At 6:00, the "zippies?" 
spoke and I felt like the way they were talking, we were supposed to 
worship them and feel like they are taking over the sf bay area.  then 
they said "get out".  I really don't like it when clubs just kick you out 
on the street after the party is over, because it breaks the unity of the 
crowd.  if they had just given us an extra half hour to chill and say 
goodbye to all our friends (they could sell muffins and juice, make more 
money), it would be much more human.  the BEST party i went to brought 
blankets and let everyone chill with free fruit and muffins and coffee.  
I am not saying they have to do that to make it a good party, but just 
immediately kicking us out on the street with no transition left a bad 
taste in foggy's mouth (and other friends of mine so i know i speak for 
others).  Come on.  Let's try to be more personal.  

remember, this is just constructive criticism.  I basically had a great 
time otherwise.  Looking forward to making megatripolis part of the 
sfrave community.  

time for dinner...disco biscuits and fries--->deepfog

---------- Forwarded message ----------
From: Gianmaria Clerici <gclerici@us.oracle.com>
Subject: my Megatripolus
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRavers)
Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 20:10:53 -0700 (PDT)

Well I went to Megatripolus with lots of doubts but I have to admit that:

1) the music was great: we always complain about too much house or too much
techno (depending what you like) but Saturday there was a good variety and
I think that variety is the best.
2) the people were friendly and into it, I didn't see people with a club
attitude or weird just to be weird: everyone was doing his/her thing with
some respect for the others
3) security at the Troc is definitely very careful but they are nice people
4) visuals: well saying that I was pretty much sober, I really enjoyed trancing
out with the music and with the help of very trippy visuals
5) great vibes: I know it sounds like everybody always says that there were
great vibes but this time I got the impression that people were really enjoying
what was going 
6) ventilation: well if I compare last night to any Wicked lately I have to say
that it was great. This is another issue were people have different point of 
view, some people like very sweaty places some other don't. Last night was
barable.

So I guess I will go again

	Take care

					Giamma




From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct  3 23:08:21 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id XAA08566; Mon, 3 Oct 1994 23:08:21 -0700
Received: from quack.kfu.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id XAA08557; Mon, 3 Oct 1994 23:07:53 -0700
Received: by quack.kfu.com id AA20626
  (5.65c8/IDA-1.4.4 for sfraves@hyperreal.com); Mon, 3 Oct 1994 23:06:33 -0700
Date: Mon, 3 Oct 1994 23:06:32 -0700 (PDT)
From: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Reply-To: Willis Wong <walrus@quack.kfu.com>
Subject: Re: Megatripolis
To: Larry Ching <larryc@netcom.com>
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199410030037.RAA01946@netcom6.netcom.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9410021813.B18795-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I got there late also and heard the guy announce no more entry after 
waiting in line for a very long time.  He decided to let five more people 
in and I was number 4.  Whew.  Double whew when I found I didn't have 
to pay any sort of fee! (had no clue it was a free event) The frisker 
dude did a real thurough job on me :

<grope> <feel> "What's this?"
  "Keys"
<poke> <poke> "I don't think so"
  <yank> <show> "Earplugs"
"yeah, those are earplugs"
"thanks"
Boy if they went through this with everyone I can see how that line got 
so long.

Walking into the troc this time was definitely a visual onslaught.  Full 
on disco mania with mirror balls and several spotlights spraying dots 
everywhere made the room really trippy, and the banners on every inch of 
wall made it homey and man-made, while the flashing multicolored lights 
in yer face was slightly nauseating, it was definitely an energetic 
display.  

I've never seen the troc more cozy.  Even the upstairs was
interesting with the cubby hole vendor booths, good use of space.  Lot's
of soft toys hanging from the ceiling, including a really cool foam fish. 
To me it didn't seem all that hot or smokey.  Compared to just about 
every other club in that area it was not bad considering the amount of 
people there.  Can you imagine a Wicked there?  They'd for sure hang 
their nappy army nets halfway up the ceiling just to bring that hot humid 
air that much closer to us.  

Did anyone else get pushed alot from people cutting through the floor?  I 
dunno what it was, maybe someone slapped a sign on my back that said 
"shove me, please" . 

Goa Gil's high bpm set was envigorating.  It seemed to not have much melodic
theme though... I mean there wasn't anything fancy that I recall from any 
of the songs except that it was VERY BOUNCY.  (actually that's about all 
I could do was bounce!) Also, I didn't notice he was beat matching 
really.  It seemed like one machine would have a few songs already mixed 
together, and then when it came time to switch machines he just slip cued 
it in... seemed kinda abrupt at times but maybe with so many beats 
already nobody cared if a few extra slipped by.

While it was great to bounce and stomp, I felt very relieved on the final 
set.  Maybe SF house music has finally hooked me, but Christophe really 
delivered.  It seemed like the crowd got back in touch with the DJ, 
hanging on to the energy of mixing.  People cheered a bit and threw up 
their hands with glee and started really swinging about on each new tune, 
yet there were still plenty of windows to mellow out in anticipation for 
the next burst.  What a way to end it.

-Willis
  O,o  
  ( )  walrus@quack.kfu.com

to let him crash at their place so he's not totally restricted to Santa 
Cruz.  So I ask all of you SuperDuperRavers <sfraves@hyperreal.com> can

Well I had the greatest time at Megatripolis.
I was unfortunate to get there late enough that I was told that
no one would be getting in, but so many people started leaving after  the line
after that that I got pushed up to the fron and was soon in... around 1:30.
I guess I'm one of those who loves that faster groove... so the music was sooo
good... much fun, and the people around me were just so into it that
I don't think I've ever bonded so closely with so many people..
During Goa Gils sertt perhaps, we were just holding each other and dancing
so hard that it was all we could do to scream.... yeah.  invigorating,
intense, life so pure... perfect.  I really felt at one with everyone,
most everyone anyway, maybe not the red headed girl jumping around dumping water on people...
but... one of my top parties.
I'll be there next week.
Also, a very interesting mix of scenes...
beyond your normal ravers...
I then spent the day with two great people, who I finally talked to
there... hello Kathy and Andrew if you're reading.
Weekends like that make s life perfect and my housemates (nonravers)
understand me less and less.
*grin*
-john.

I too found the Troc quite stifling -- I just thought they didn't *have* 
air handlers. Finding out that they *do* have them and *didn't turn them 
on* was a big shock.
I also could have done without the SS-style security -- first of all, 
Susan had to stand there holding a very full crate of vinyl waiting *in 
line*. This also happened to the SPAZ posse, and Aaron in particular was 
pissed. They just simply didn't give *any* space for him & Jen to work with.

Next, after Larry Ching was sweet enough to help me find our car, we had 
to wait in line all over again, despite the fact that we had wristbands. 

Maybe it's just me -- I rarely go to clubs, but I've *worked* at them;
but the the nastiness of the security folk really took me aback.

*But*, from what I saw for the couple hours I was there, it was a pretty 
bangin' party. I only regret that Kairo had Susan and DRC spinning at the 
same time, so I had to keep running up and down stairs. All said, it 
*was* a fun party, and I will attend the next one, most likeley.

One fun part is that Mike Clay showed up with the same shirt I was 
wearing -- the "infinite detail" T's that Ethan gave us at F&F III :)

And I thought sushi was an interesting choice of edibles at a club/rave...

Maui

> While I can't blame a promoter that has the misfortune of selecting a
> space and finding out the night of the party that the spaceowner is
> going to screw things up, I *do* blame promoters that reuse such
> spaces. 

As far as I know, Kairo has never used that space before. And it's not 
likely that the first event at a new venue *isn't* going to have some 
problems that need ironing out.

>These promoters are dogs; they don't give a shit about people,

Sean, you don't even know them, and you weren't even *at the party*.

> they only care about green paper. "Blah blah blah...it's the only
> space we could use blah blah blah." Good promoters would rather not
> throw the party at all than throw it and screw people.
> 
> Good promoters try and provide ventilation. They give you free cups
> (at a cost to them of maybe $.01-$.02 each) and free water. They allow
> you to walk outside and cool off. They make you stand in line only
> once. They're polite at the door and genuinely glad you came.  They
> have a smoking area that is not the main dance floor.  They don't turn
> the sound up to hearing damage levels, and when problems arise they
> try their best to fix them.

To be honest, I don't the things that were bad about this party really 
had aything to do with the promoters. Of course,I was only there early 
(while DRC was spinning) but I do *not* remember the sound as being too 
loud. However, it certainly might have gotten that way after Susan & I left.

> Every party I have been associated with has had these things. All of
> them have been hailed as having a great vibe, and none of them have
> lost money.

None of them have lost money? I think Ethan has shelled out quite a bit 
to make things happen; without financial compensation... don't know about 
anyone else except YSH -- we've lost plenty on that party. We just don't 
care :)

> That's why you don't see me often at big 
> parties. They're usually a
> collaboration between asshole promoters and asshole spaceowners that
> don't care about their patron's health, just their money. To those
> that are the exception, you not only have my gratitude and respect,
> you have my attendance.

I agree with you completely here :)

> How you treat your people sets the tone for your whole party.
> Promoters make the difference, and loving promoters have made some
> wonderful things happen. The "rave scene" will die off eventually as
> it recedes like every other fad dominated by money. But the small
> parties and other parties thrown for the love of it -- they'll live on
> and on, as long as people want to share the love and music.
> 
> Put your money where your heart is.
> 
> Sean

Sean, you know I agree with you on these latter points, but I think it 
was unfair to Kairo and his associates to make critical judgements of them
without knowing the whole story,


Maui

here in SF-- you had bands like Flipper (that are WAY grungier than 
anything that Seattle produced) and bands that grew out of the thrash 
metal scene. The slow element went one way, the fast element another. 
They've always both been here, though...

	Kinda, each club has its own atmosphere (sorry, but I have to do 
this from habit....
SSSSSSSSAAAAAAAAATTTTTTTTTIIIIIVVVVVVVVVAAAAAAAAAAAA.... ah much better) 
and sound system and residence djs and....... When I was up in Scotland 
(and traveling down to London), a sound system provided a certain type of 
music and there was a greater range of offerings (esp. London) in 
contrast to how I kinda view things here (although this is starting to be 
broken up a bit :) ). BUT, festties, which are a mix of everything from 
punk to hardcore trbial (CJ Bolland spun at 45 instead of 33, will give 
you an idea.... well kinda) to housey sounds, were by far the most fun...

On Tue, 4 Oct 1994, Maui defended:

> > the sound up to hearing damage levels, and when problems arise they
> > try their best to fix them.
> 
> To be honest, I don't the things that were bad about this party really 
> had aything to do with the promoters. Of course,I was only there early 
> (while DRC was spinning) but I do *not* remember the sound as being too 
> loud. However, it certainly might have gotten that way after Susan & I left.

	This has been a trick (playing with the levels over the course of 
the evening so that the music builds in waves as well as increasing on 
the average to counteract the numbing effect, this last bit would be 
considered bad for your ears by most... including me) to make your 
experience more intense. Although it does not have to get up to levels 
that damage your hearing, I do enjoy djs that still pay attention to 
details this 'small'.

deepfog writes:

>SOUND-  Way too loud.  Everywhere I went in there, I could hear the
>little hairs in my ears falling out.  I wanted to go in the main dance
>area, but couldn't because I was afraid of ear damage.  Now I know it can
>be improved, because I went to one of Martin's events (Vision) in May and
>the sound was EXCELLENT.  And he had more speakers in there.  I had no
>problems that night.  Take some lessons on how to use sound properly or
>pass out earplugs at the door.

I agree somewhat that the sound was loud and unclear.  I found the sound
system inadequate in power.  I commented to someone in the middle of DRC's
set that there was way too much distorsion.  Usually an indication of lack
of power (clipping).  Then again it could have been a little of both, bad
speakers and lack of power.  (I'm not talking about volume here just
driving power for clean sound.)  The bass could have been just a tad
deeper.  Unless you were dancing near the stage, where bass bins were right
under the stage, it felt a bit anemic.

If I'm not mistaken I think Ethan mentioned something in a previous post
about the sound system being brought in from different productions group
each week.  That could be a blessing.  Could anyone confirm this? :)

Again, all in all I had a blast! :) :)

Denis,  ravnbird@crl.com

invest in a CD recorded and a Denon 2000 CD mixing system.  Then he could 
transfer his DAT material to CD and mix the CDs.

Goa Gil beatmatch?  Hah, and the sun will rise in the west.  No, he is
completely locked in to that style; he didn't beat match when he was
using vinyl either.  Non-matched mixing is still apparently fairly common
in Europe, from what I've been able to gather, and is actually making
something of a comeback on the east coast.  With Gil's style, it really
doesn't matter that much.  I've always liked him being around in the SF
scene because what he plays is so different than most everything else
being played, but really, I find it unemotional and static and hard to
dance to.  But that's fine, it gave me a chance to take a long break
on Saturday night.

As for sound levels, I didn't think they were all that bad, and I only
used my earplugs for short periods of time . . . and believe me, I remember
plenty of times when I went to the Troc and didn't take them out from the
moment I walked into the place.

not to rain on the parade or anything, but Goa Gil is, as far as I know,
a native of San Francisco.  He got the name because he has the means,
so I've heard, to do anything he likes, and one of the things he likes
is to spend half the year in Goa with the beach party scene there.
Chalk this up to unsupported rumor, but it fits his m.o.  

Having never been to Goa, again this is purely hearsay, but my understanding
is that it's primarily frequented by Europeans on holiday; it was actually
still a Portuguese colony until the early 1960s if memory serves.  Recently
there have been stories in the paper that the Indian government is building
a controversial railway extension into Goa, which will provide easy access
for the first time, and the locals are none too pleased about that.

I've seen Goa Gil spin maybe ten times.  It just hit me that the first one
was in June 1992 at a little underground party in what looked like a
little theater rehearsal space, maybe on Jessie St. or one of those mini-
streets south of Market.  Anyway, it was a pretty good party and the 
lineup -- you'll love this, this was back before the delineation of the
various musical styles was as strongly perceived -- was Carlos, Goa Gil
and an early version of Darwin Chambre (which is how they spelled it then).

phred
ATDT274-6400

i would like to strongly (let me repeat, STRONGLY) caution anyone from
using East Bay Regional Park District land.  In case anyone has forgotten,
21 people received citations that cost REAL MONEY in an EBRPD park on
August 5th. The authorities have NO sense of humor, the fine is expensive
(US$270), and is a misdemeanor (can you say, CRIMINAL RECORD?).  Please,
use extreme caution when using EBRP land.  Their parks are closed from
10PM until 5AM.  They mean it, and they enforce it.

There have been several attempts to get a regular trance party going but 
so far none have really taken off. All summer long I get bombarded by 
europeans who ask where the trance {goa style of course} parties are .
They do not like that funky -groovy. Personally I think the best DJs in 
sanfrancisco play house- However some of the best records being made now 
are Ambient-techno-trance . I think it is easier to mix house 
beats. Techno songs have odd fractalized rythyms which confuse me. People 
who like techno buy the music and listen to it UNMIXED! I cant imagine 
doing that with house. Laura and Shoban are the two who I first heard 
play not-house in SF scince Mr floppies (i know there are others but 
during the early part of the sf rave scene (toontown times) i was in jail.)
Floppy people are part of the contingent of people in sf who prefer 
cosmic-acid-artsy-freaky to the funky-groovy. I felt their presence at 
the jupiter bash. SPAZ is my favorite protaganist of the techno freakout .
ethan,bryce, WBL, and all of ya'll get on it . Zippy-hype master Frazer 
Clark seems like a supreme egoist But he has brought the possibility of 
aan above ground trance party into being-His hype and lots of help from 
everyone else. I say MAKE IT HAPPEN so I can have a place to send the goa 
crazed euro-heads on a weekend. 

Besides techno is really cool on a big sound system!
and maybe some AMBIENT JUNGLE!!!!!

salutations, allen@ameba

I thought this might be of interest to everyone in light of the recent
Sunset happenings.  Might try firing off some email, I know for a fact that
they do read and respond promptly to their email.

>>====================================================
>>The City of Berkeley is now fully equipped to send
>>and receive electronic mail from the Internet.
>>
>>* To use this service, all you need is access, either
>>directly or indirectly, to the Internet.
>>
>>* You can also access the Berkeley Public Library catalog by doing
>>
>>        telnet library.ci.berkeley.ca.us
>>
>>* At the end of this note are some  useful e-mail addresses, but first,
>>some notes on using e-mail:
>>
>>        --The Internet is not a secure medium, thus it is inappropriate to
>>          use it to send confidential or sensitive information.
>>
>>        --In case the message header is lost, the body of the text should
>>          contain the sender's name and full Internet address.
>>
>>        --Please use upper and lower case.  ALL CAPITALS READS LIKE
>SHOUTING!
>>
>>        --Finally, sending e-mail is very simple compared to the creation
>>          of a written letter, which is why the City of Berkeley is
>>          offering this service.  However, all users are respectfully
>>          requested to keep their correspondence brief and to the point,
>>          and to be patient awaiting a response.
>>
>>* The Future
>>
>>        The City, in partnership with Sun Microsystems, Inc. and UC
>>        Berkeley, is developing a World Wide Web server which will be
>>        available to Mosaic users.  Stay tuned for further bulletins!
>>
>>* Technical Issues
>>
>>        Technical questions should be addressed to the City of Berkeley
>>        Information Systems Division at:
>>

>>        Tel: (510) 644-6820

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct  4 14:45:58 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id OAA25426; Tue, 4 Oct 1994 14:45:58 -0700
Received: from netcomsv.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA25421; Tue, 4 Oct 1994 14:45:55 -0700
Received: from manual3.com by netcomsv.netcom.com with UUCP (8.6.4/SMI-4.1)
	id OAA07061; Tue, 4 Oct 1994 14:31:03 -0700
Message-Id: <199410042131.OAA07061@netcomsv.netcom.com>
Date: 4 Oct 1994 14:17:08 -0800
From: "Nathan Moser" <nathan_moser@manual3.com>
Subject: To Megatriopolis from Santa
To: "SFRAVES" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

        Reply to:   To Megatriopolis from Santa Fe, NM
My girlfriend Lisa and I moved here a couple of weeks ago from Santa Fe, NM, and
thought Megatripolis sounded like a great 1st SF rave. We weren't disappointed. 

We started the evening out catching the early show of Ollie Stone's "Natural
Born Killers" with some friends. Interesting movie, but I wouldn't recommend it
to anyone as a pre-rave picture. The on-location shots of New Mexico kinda hit
home with us. While traveling along route 666 (yeah, there is a route 666 in New
Mexico), the main characters snuff a Native American shaman. Lovely.

We got to the Megatripolis location around 10:00PM, like the vmail line
suggested. Talking to the people in line got us out of our Stone-induced funk,
and reassured us that the SF, CA rave community is every bit as friendly as the
New Mexico rave community. While in line, we all received complementary smiley
face erasers :-) in tiny zip-lock bags from people dressed in black hooded robes.
The topic of conversation immediately turned to whether there might be something
interesting on the erasers, but no one was willing to brave the taste to find
out, at least not out on the street.

Once inside, we were struck by the decor. Not overly high-tech, but quality and
creativity definitely triumphed over cost. 

The music was really diverse and most all of it was completely new to me, which
was exactly what I was looking for! From what I can gather, the lag time between
what you people hear out here and what arrives in NM is anywhere from 2 to 6
months, if it arrives at all. I hope your scene _doesn't_ fragment into sub-scenes
of house, gabber, techno, ambient, etc. The inevitable arguments over which
genre is better are far less interesting than just giving in to whatever moves
you. 

We were a little puzzled when the music suddenly stopped and some guy (who we
later learned was Frazier Clark) started making a speech. We couldn't understand
a word, and by the time we made it downstairs, he had finished. The next guy up
was evidently the originator of the "pronoia" concept, which from his
description seems pretty cagey. Anyone who has tripped hard at some point in
their lives can probably relate to the feeling of pronoia, that the universe was
set in motion for his/her personal enjoyment. It seems that it's where you take
this feeling that really matters. Certainly the main characters of "Natural Born
Killers" were in touch with the feeling (their drug, according to Stone, was
TV), it's just that they took it in a slightly less positive direction. In this
light, the PLUR concept discussed a few posts back seems more important then
pronoia. 

After the speeches were finished, a group of four made their way to the center
of the floor to spiritually initiate Megatriopolis. A shamanistic intro for a
techno-oriented club - we felt like we were back in Santa Fe!

The only let down of the evening was the sound system. I don't think it was the DJ's
fault or had anything to do with where the levels were set. The speakers sounded
like they were being underpowered, and like they were a decade to two too old to
handle what was being put through them. Couldn't tell if the bullet tweeters
hanging at the four corners of the floor were active, but their placement probably
wouldn't have helped things much anyway. Hopefully next week's $10 price tag
will allow for better systems in the future.

Once we've seen some different parties, we'll probably come back to
Megatriopolis. The vibe seemed to reflect a sincere generosity. Thanks so much
to all of you for pointing out a great first SF rave!

-nate






 I also got to hear John Perry Barlow for the first time - the guy who
discovered the term "pronoia". He gave a short speech about himself and
his philosophy - I didn't catch everything , but there was one idea
that I managed to write down ... if there is a lot of bad shit in
your life , it's the sucking backwash of an impending wave of positive
magiacal energy. With the recent death of his wife , he is personally
putting this to the test.

> > So YSH is confirmed for Cyclone on Oct. 8th  :) :) :) :) :)
> > 
> 	what can anyone tell me about this space who has been there.
> 	barry


I went to a big punk rock kegger party there this summer.

If I this is the same place, it is near the water with a large
junk yard / sculpture / firepits area that the big warehouse door 
opens out to.  Has a very dirty city feel to it.  All you ventilation
junkies should be high as a kite.

Went to Mushroom Jazz (sunset withdrawals) last night.  Very hiphop
now - lots of slinky bellbottoms (I am so Easy).  If house seems slow
to ya then you'll just melt all over the dance floor here.  Felt like a
"regular crowd" has settled in with a good emphasis on dancing.  A mix of 
solo and social dancers.  The people were more diverse than I remembered.
Excellent crab cakes and brazilian salsa.
Essential tip: cheap beer at back bar.

OB fabulous glamour pusses -
heard rumors about the basement of 1015 this friday
anyone confirm?

Dave

"Maui-Your Sister's House" writes:

[Talking about the Troc']

 > As far as I know, Kairo has never used that space before. And it's not 
 > likely that the first event at a new venue *isn't* going to have some 
 > problems that need ironing out.
 > 
 > >These promoters [who reuse hostile spaces] are dogs; they don't
 > >give a shit about people,
 > 
 > Sean, you don't even know them, and you weren't even *at the party*.

I'm afraid Maui has totally misread my post as an attack on Kairo. It
is not. And it does not matter whether I was at the party or not, if
eight people explain in excruciating detail what was wrong with it.

I don't have to witness the beating to be angry if a woman is
battered.

I don't have to be at the rave to be angry if the spaceowners abused
their patrons.

Read my posting again. I am angry at the spaceowners. Now if Kairo or
any other another promoter throws a party there--knowing how they treat
people--then it says that promoter is about money.

Finally, if one needs to use the word "you" a lot in a posting, TAKE
IT TO EMAIL!!!!!!

Sean

a fine security job- got him to the ground and handcuffed. Same thing
I did for years at shows.

or something, NOT beat-crashing!  Sometimes it's just too hard to 
get two 150 bpm tracks with panning hi-hats to seamlessly beat mix.

X-Mailer: Z-Mail (3.0.0 15dec93)
To: "Nathan Moser" <nathan_moser@manual3.com>,
        "SFRAVES" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: To Megatriopolis from Santa
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Mime-Version: 1.0
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Barlow invented the term 'pronoia'?  That's new to me.

Thanks for the report Nate and welcome to SF, I'm pleased to see we have
some new people checking in here.  

The four 'bullet tweeters' you mentioned are (I believe) JBL drivers hung
from the ceiling.  They are the last vestige of what I believe to be the
most awesome medium size sound system I've ever heard.  The old Troc
sound system circa late 1992 used those tweeters and massive banks of
folded-horn subwoofers in each of the four corners of the room.  It was
a body-resonating experience, and yet unless the DJs were driving the
system too hard you could be in the large sweet spot in the middle and
get away without earplugs at least for a while.  I miss that physical
resonance, most of the systems now (except maybe the big room at Townsend)
can't do it cleanly although many try and end up distorting the sound.
To be fair, Shredder is the other system that really gives that effect
but I haven't been to a party where they've been used since the NASA
at the Galleria last fall.

I've waxed rhapsodic about the old Troc system and what little I know of
its, er, uh, interesting history, because it represents to me so far the
state of the art for club sound.  It taught me a lot about new concepts
in sound reinforcement, as well as underlining some old ones such as the
absolute importance of minimizing distortion to gain comfortable, clean
and loud sound.

phred

Cynthia Lopez says...

>what about caldecott park?  last exit off 24 east before the 
>tunnel.  i remember back in the floppy daze when schwin used to 
>through 'em there.  it's worth looking at.

Well,  I used to live up there at Parkwoods Apartments right up at the
Caldecott tunnel,  and there is a baseball field nestled up against hills
on all 3 sides.  Then  just down from there,  is a small recreational
lake Timescal Lake..

I can remember many warm nights where I've taken a walk up there (usually
after 11 pm).     Often,  I would get hassled by cops who wouldn't allow me
to just walk out there and enjoy the warm evening.    I would say,   at least
several times,  they would ask for my ID,  and my friend Bill went out there
alone,   and got socked with a $300 fine.   It is very heavily Pig infested,
but with Parkwoods apartments now gone (A victum of the Oakland hills fire)
I suspect it isn't patrolled that much now.    PS:  I moved out of there
about 4 yours BEFORE the fire totally destroyed the complex.

CC

For what it's worth, the first ever SFRaves picnic was held in May 1992 up in
a park around there.  Sound permit was $80 or so, the area couldn't hold more
than maybe 100 people if they carpooled, but it was a very nice area.  
I am pretty sure there are larger spots with more parking, too, though 
nothing approaching the intensity of Berkeley Marina.

On Tue, 4 Oct 1994, allen jebian wrote:

> There have been several attempts to get a regular trance party going but 
> so far none have really taken off. All summer long I get bombarded by 
> europeans who ask where the trance {goa style of course} parties are .
> They do not like that funky -groovy. Personally I think the best DJs in 
> sanfrancisco play house- However some of the best records being made now 
> are Ambient-techno-trance . I think it is easier to mix house 
> beats. Techno songs have odd fractalized rythyms which confuse me. People 
> who like techno buy the music and listen to it UNMIXED! I cant imagine 
> doing that with house. Laura and Shoban are the two who I first heard 
> play not-house in SF scince Mr floppies (i know there are others but 
> during the early part of the sf rave scene (toontown times) i was in jail.)
> Floppy people are part of the contingent of people in sf who prefer 
> cosmic-acid-artsy-freaky to the funky-groovy. I felt their presence at 
> the jupiter bash. SPAZ is my favorite protaganist of the techno freakout .
> ethan,bryce, WBL, and all of ya'll get on it . Zippy-hype master Frazer 
> Clark seems like a supreme egoist But he has brought the possibility of 
> aan above ground trance party into being-His hype and lots of help from 
> everyone else. I say MAKE IT HAPPEN so I can have a place to send the goa 
> crazed euro-heads on a weekend.

> and maybe some AMBIENT JUNGLE!!!!!

"Fred Heutte" writes:
 > To be fair, Shredder is the other system that really gives that effect
 > but I haven't been to a party where they've been used since the NASA
 > at the Galleria last fall.

Unfortunately, the last six parties featuring "Shredder" that I
attended had the sound much too loud. This had the effect of muddying
the music terribly from the excessive reverberation and distorting the
sound from being driven at clipping levels.

I used to think that Shredder meant the system shreds your head, but I think
it really means that it shreds up all the work put into creating and
mastering a good piece of vinyl. The end result is that all the songs
sound the same... like a Westinghouse locomotive at 10 feet.

Sean

yeah, I enjoyed everything but the troc itself.  the people doing security
and some of the people who either worked either for the troc or the event
*were* rude and pushy.  i was drinking a beer at 2AM, had 2 gulps left when
this girl in ripped up jeans tried to rudely grab it out of my hand, with
a cursory comment about "the rules".  after I said, "waitaminit, I'll
fuinish it now" she tried to snatch it out my hand again.  i basically
put my hand on her forehead, cartoon style, and held her back while gulping
1 of the 2 last gulps, and then gave her the other, her babbling about
"i'm kicking you out" etc., which i completely ignored.  i also saw what
appeared to be narc activity and the gen. attitude of the club and workers
was pretty hostile to the crowd.  the vibe of the crowd was good, but I'd
say I'll not be very excited to attend another event with 'workers with
attitude', specially not if I'm paying...

If the megatripolis promoter(s) are out there, PLEASE FIND ANOTHER VENUE!!!!

BTW, what's the story on komotion these days?  I'd *much* rather patronize
them!!!!

-=j=-

Greetings, Ravers!

After much work, setup, and negotiation, we have finally worked out a viable
plan with Komotion to help bring you Friends and Family on Saturday, October
29th, as a celebration for ourselves, and the upcoming Halloween and Samhain
holidays.  We hope you'll join us in making this a wonderful SFR party for
all of our friends and family.  We are working with Komotion to make this
the coolest (literally) party we've had there.

We'd like to invite you to participate in making this event.  If you're an 
artist, musician, dancer, performer, poet, greeter, meeter, viber, wanderer,
body painter, altar maker, or have some skill you'd like to share with us,
we'd like to hear from you and work with you.  Please send some mail to
nrg@ultima.org, or to me, brycer@ultima.org.

Thanks!  see ya soon!
-- 
------- Bryce Ryan ------------ Site Admin ----------- brycer@ultima.org -----

Subject: Guide to SF Raves This Week!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com (SFRaves)

Precedence: bulk


Looks like a great weekend coming up - I'm afraid Wicked loses out to
the return of Your Sisters' House, and Thrive; for those of you new to 
the scene, Your Sisters' House is a collective of women who threw a 
great string of parties in lots of great locations last year - they
were lots of fun and lots of SFR people always showed up.  Thrive 
features many of the underground party promoters and could be great too.
Wicked is (almost) always great too, but I'll wait till the next one.
The bad news is that I'll be gone this weekend, so I'll actually miss all
of these. :(

-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
--------------------- UPCOMING RAVES IN THE SF/BAY AREA ---------------------
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Friday, October 7th - 
        Mother Earth sound system and the Chateaupia Housing Authority present:
                                HEAVEN
        the deepest house, 9pm til the break of dawn 
        DJs: Scottie, Stonie, Whitsitt, Brad + special guest Tony...
        $3 at the Chateau  2545 Hillegass @ Parker, Berkeley
        510 549 6260   

Saturday, October 8th - Your Sisters' House 
        "It's time to groove and giggle"
        DJ's Susan, Polliwog, Laura, other DJ's TBA
        10pm - ? (late)
        Call for info: 415.435.7575 

Saturday, October 8th - Thrive
        w/Mother Earth, Kokapelli, New Moon, THC, Divine & Vivid Sound Systems
        Free & Outdoors
        INFO LINES:  415.487.7681  510.549.6260

Saturday, October 8th - Wicked
        Jeno  Garth  Markie  Thomas
        415.512.5713

        call Bulletproof for info: 415.255.7168

        415.974.9464

        Josh  Charlotte  Corbin  Das
        a benefit to help battered women and children of the bay area

        Sat: Garth Spun Galen  Sun: Jeno Markie Tracy

        $10 before midnight, 21+
        415.266.8215

Here are some weeklies, in the house/techno/acid jazz/etc vein.  Some
of them may have ended - let me know when that happens...

---------------------------- T h u r s d a y --------------------------------

Universal Groove - $5. 415.281.5913  510.869.2727
Lift - Digit, David Harness & guests - $5, 21+, 55 Natoma, SF - 415.267.5984
Inspirations - San Jose Oasis, 200 N 1st St. 9pm-2am, 21+, $5.  
        journees@netcom.com  408.236.2102  415.267.6974
Pure Space - 10pm-4am, 21+, $5. DNA Lounge, 375 11th @ Harrison. 415.267.0640
Flour - Dani & Mark Farina - Deco, 510 Larkin @ Turk.  21+. 415.441.4007.
        (every other Thursday)
Kit Kat - 6th & Harrison (the End-Up) - 21+, $5 w/invite
Soul Purpose - live acid jazz and DJs - $5, 21+, Sound Factory, 525 Harrison. 
        415.905.8811    415.882.1178
Lube - rock hard acid techno - 7pm-2am - 415.905.8831
The Velvet Shop - DJs Carlos (San Jose), Harry Who?, Jeno!
        @ Club Selections in San Jose.  408-236-3732.  21+

------------------------------ F r i d a y ----------------------------------

Life/Twirl - Sound Factory - 525 Harrison @ 1st, SF    415.543.1300   21+
Dakota - 1015 Folsom, 21+, $10 - 415.431.1200
Kuba - acid jazz w/DJs Charlotte, Josh, Dos Rexx - 1190 Folsom, SF.
Soul'd Out - acid-jazz party @ F/X, San Jose.  DJs Julius Papp & guests
Spiral Jive - free outdoor gathering every other weekend - 415.281.8405
Pure Love & Sol - Dave Alga, Spinner, XL, Jazz-E, Ghost + guests (e.g. Carlos)
        $5  415.303.2906  510.765.3251  408.932.0224

---------------------------- S a t u r d a y --------------------------------

Dorothy's Tribe - Rick Preston, Nobel, James & guests
	6am-6pm at the EndUp, 401 6th @ Harrison.  415.543.7700

        9:30-7am, 21+, 415.985.5241

        10pm-2:30am. $3 before midnight, $5 after.  Cafe Bastille,

        Paddle Wheel Saloon on the Delta King, Old Sacramento  916.484.5692

------------------------------ Info Lines -----------------------------------

Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087.  Usually has 5-10 listings, updated daily.
Elmo - 415-884-ABCD
Freak Out - 415.485.6597
Clubline - 415.979.8686
Fatline - 415.207.3668

---------------------------- Radio/TV Shows ---------------------------------
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Sunday night 10pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive house, 
        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
Mondays midnight-2am - "The Mix Show" KWOD 106.5(Sac) - lineup 916.551.0494
Tuesdays noon-3pm - "London Jamaica" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Wednesdays 10pm-2am - Belladonna, KFJC 89.7 (Los Altos) - last two hours
        are usually techno-tribal-trance and ambient
Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

to get all the info every week.

I took all the responses relating to Megatripolus and made sure that Frank and
Frazer Clark got and read ALL of them.    They were appreciative of the efforts
I made in getting this information to them.    Frazer Clark,  one of the origional
Zippy folks,  has broken away from the Angus, Pinkus group,  and is the main
driving force behind Megatripolus.    Here is what he said,  and he wanted me
to relay this to all you SFRavers.

Ventilation - Frazer has arranged to have fans around the dance floor,  and
with the owners to have the air conditioning turned on.

Free water - Still NOT free after 2 am.   But they will try and have water jugs
downstairs.

Security - Frazer has talked with the security goons,  and has worked it out
with them to be more curtious to the patrons.   However,   nothing was mentioned
about their aggresive attitude,  looking for pot smokers.

ins-and-outs - will be permitted!!

Closing time still at 6 am.

Mijos, the New Moon set up in the Presidio, in a beautiful clearing, with
the sound loud enuf to please and quiet enough to keep the nearby residents
asleep. But perhaps a few lost drivers called the attention of bored cops,
and they found us.
But the site was beautiful, you could see the ocean on your way up and hear
the waves, and in the clearing, there was beautiful sound, surrounded by
proud trees and roofed by more stars than in a Montanna sky...

After telling us to "git off OUR federal property!" and narry a voiced
"pigs" from us, they were talked into letting us get a an extra 45 minutes.

No nudity, no bongs, no scary fashion, just a cool crowd. But then it
happened, they dragged someone out for a pipe and a dime bag, shone their
lights in our faces (so we ALL stumbled around in confusion) and sent us
away.

Tweaked driving and back seat hyper heart beats is all we got from "protect
and serve." all my dangerous episodes in North America, so far, have been
at the hands of the police. Shame on them......if we do no harm to any, why
can't THEY do the same? Wouldn't be in the police, then, would they?

Come/unity was thumpathumpathumpathumpathumpathumpathumpathumpathumpathumpthump!
And a hug to all who smiled that nite!
Lotsa love, 
 Milton and the E-Bee........

Just for your listening pleasure...

KZSU (90.1 FM, Stanford University) has had a house music program that has
been running for over two years.  DJ Unknown (Josh Bates) has been running
the program and has put on a number of amazing house marathons (the last
one being a 24-hour non-stop show in December)...The show ran weekly every
Tuesday from 12:00noon to 3:00PM, and was formerly called "London Jamaica".

I just wanted to inform you all that the date and time of the regular
weekly show has been CHANGED.  It will be on Sunday evening/Monday AM, from
12:00 midnight to 3:00AM.  The show will now be called "88 Acid", and the
focus for the next few months will be on acid house and deep house.  Guest
DJs, representing SF's finest, will be laying down the trax.

Remember, Sunday 12:00 Midnight to 3:00 am Monday.  Da fiercest.  So,
please give the show a listen & give Josh your support.  KZSU phone:
(415)723-9010.

jack
