From sfraves-owner  Sat Oct  8 13:29:04 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id NAA13110; Sat, 8 Oct 1994 13:29:04 -0700
Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id NAA13104; Sat, 8 Oct 1994 13:29:00 -0700
Received: by uclink.berkeley.edu (8.6.8/1.33(web)-OV1)
	id NAA23823; Sat, 8 Oct 1994 13:29:00 -0700
Date: Sat, 8 Oct 1994 13:29:00 -0700
From: anthrax@uclink.berkeley.edu (Ann Elizabeth Loraine)
Message-Id: <199410082029.NAA23823@uclink.berkeley.edu>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: new moon
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Hi all!  Thanks to Bryce, Maui, Gregg, Sean, Mark, Tracy, Dante, Philip (with
one L) and all else who came out to the New Moon party Thrusday am after 
ComeUnity.  It was a blast!  (both were, that is :)

Sound was provided by Liquid Air.  A quick stealth run into SF's newest park
was done by sneaky new mooners to set up.  Those who accomplished this feat
deserve congratulations for their talents, by the way.

By the time the music came on, there were already maybe 50 or so people there.
Most came from ComeUnity and were pleasantly surprized by the cool, green,
starlit, tree-lined space.  They also seemed to like the altar, which was
laid out on satin and tye-died cloths on one side of the clearing.  

Dante started us off about 4 or 4:30 on a very mellow groove, perfect for the
surroundings and the mood.  Unfortunately, the mood became a little tense due
to the arrival of some of the more official guardians of the park, who asked
us to leave but were talked into allowing us time for Tracy to do a short
set.  One confused soul apparently misunderstood the situation and was
ticketed when an "official guardian" noticed his little bag of...well, you
know.  

I was very impressed with how calm everyone was during the breakup of the party.
People were obviously outraged with the fact that this was public land and
we weren't hurting anyone by being there.  A few people even helped out by
standing with the organizers during the negotiations, showing their support
and adding their good sense to the proceedings.

Regarding the philosophy of a party breaking up this way:  Even though it
would have been better for it to have gone on all night, I think it was 
important to make the park part of San Francisco in this way.  It belongs
to all of us now!  Vive the Presidio!

all my love,

ann

ps the organizers took care to let everyone there know it was a "renegade"
i think this analagous to a promoter at a more "legit" site making sure
there is plenty of water, bathrooms, etc. if anyone has suggestions on sites,
etc, for future events, you can email me if you like and I will pass it
along

Well, my father and brother are both in the Navy, and the Navy
fed me, clothed me, and sheltered me for 21 years while I was
growing up, so I have s soft spot in my heart for those multi-ton
machines of death adored with blue metal flake paint and funded
by the administrations that give us the war on drugs.

I also like submarines, too, and have ridden in one while it was
cruising out in the Atlantic.  And yes it was fueled by nuclear fuel
that will some day be the death of us all.  It was fun, I heard
whales and got to look through the periscope.

I'm not about to bite the hand that fed me, I'm very proud of my
father and brother.

Happily Un-PC in the capital of PC-ness,

Laura

---------- Forwarded message ----------
To: analogue@magnus.acs.ohio-state.edu
Cc: idm@hyperreal.com, sfraves@hyperreal.com, SoCal-Raves@ucsd.edu
Subject: The story of the $100 TB-303 ...
Date: Sun, 09 Oct 1994 14:52:45 -0700
From: Greg Earle <earle@isolar.Tujunga.CA.US>

Yesterday (Saturday) we decided to buy a San Fernando Valley Recycler to look
for something else, and last night Jennifer sat down to scan the Musical
Accessories category.

All of a sudden she went "Wha ... what the Hell?!?!".  She'd seen this ad:

	ROLAND TB-303 bass synthesizer/controller,
	$100; Fender Strat neck, $150 or trade for Tele neck

(Yes, that really *does* say "$100")

I said "Dude, that thing's GONE, I bet it was gone first thing on Thursday
morning!".

She couldn't resist calling anyway, just to find out when it went.  She got off
the phone nearly peeing her pants with laughter.

Turned out that it was an older Jazzman who was really into guitars, and he had
this thing lying around.  "I just thought it was an ugly piece of junk", he
said.  "Made all these dumb little bass sounds!" :-) :-) :-)

The Recycler comes out at the crack of dawn on Thursday mornings.

The calls started coming in at 7:00 AM.  :-)

After a while, he left the answering machine to answer them.  And still they
came in.  Every 10 minutes, on average.

Some of them were classic:

(An English guy; insert appropriate accent) "I will top any bid.  Any."

Others were like: (Jazzman) "Hello?"  "Do you have it?"

Or: (Jazzman) "Hello?"  "Hey!  Who'd you sell it to?!?  Dennis?  Yo-yo?  Ike?"

And: "I've got the cash.  Right now." (Lots of these obvious "I'll buy it and
resell it for mega-profits" types, he said.  He filtered all of those out from
the answering machine messages.)

After the first hundred (yup) or so calls, he realized that selling it for a
mere $100 was not his smartest possible move, so he opened it up for bids.  He
eventually sold it for $350.  When asked how many total calls he'd gotten, he
said "Oh, man.  Hundreds.  Hundreds."

He finally chose some kid who sounded sincere and who begged him for it because
he "needed it for [his] show".  The kid showed up at his house - in full-on
Techno garb, natch - and when the guy brought it out and showed it to him, "the
kid started jumping up and down and making funny squealing noises" - "This is
it!!  It's it!  It *is* it!".

Anyway, this was too funny not to share it with y'all :-)

	- Greg

> Free water - Still NOT free after 2 am.   But they will try and have water
> jugs downstairs.

In the past, the Troc always supplied free water by having a water fountain
(which is probably nice for the bartenders cuz they don't have to serve water
all night).  The water fountain was (probably still is) right between the
men's and women's bathrooms.

Unfortunately, the Troc recently installed a photo booth machine right in front
of the water fountain.  A friend of mine hypothesized that the reason they
chose to put the photo macine in front of the water fountain was because
perhaps the machine needed a water supply in order to develop the film.
If that's the case, why don't they just put the machine near the bar and hook
it up to a water suppky there?

                      How was Sunset after sunset?
So how did the new location work out? We were there for about an hour, but had
to leave due to prior plans with some of our city-dwelling friends. We saw the
cops come and go, but just as we were leaving the parking lot, a park ranger
jeep went charging up the road. Any trouble? We really liked the location (we
didn't make it to any of the Marina Sunsets, so we couldn't really compare), and
the people and music were great! If it goes on this weekend, we'll come earilier
and stay later. 
-nate

I am fortunately enough to be able to see the action from my living room and I  
must say it was a wonderful experience. Before saturday I never paid much  
attention to the blue angels and as I watched the planes flew by shaking my  
windows with the incredible sonic boom, I sort of felt glad that my tax dollar  
went into it. I was fully aware that there were apparently better places to  
spend the tax dollar but still, as I was commenting with my neighbors, one does  
leave the experience with a sense of awe and a renewed belief in this nation.

                      Terence McKenna in SFExam/Chron
Any of you happen to catch the Terence McKenna cover-story interview in the SF
Examiner/Chronicle magazine this Sunday? First time I really read/heard his
ideas sans third-party interpretation. Seemed like the reporter was steering him
pretty hard through. Does he really feel that Psylocybin mushrooms are the
one-stop panacea for all of lifekind's ills, or is there more to his story? The
Apocalyptic warnings kinda turned me off, but it was definitely more thought
provoking than Hussien's latest adventures. He mentioned speaking/lecturing at raves.
Any events in this area?
-nate

  >I sort of felt glad that my tax dollar  went into it.

>      the war on drugs! What better reason to enjoy an airshow!

Well, I can't help but be impressed (and entertained) by such a powerful
example of high technology.  But the mentality that thinks that
our armed forces are cool and our country is cool because of such
displays of power is similar to the mentality that thinks a strong-arm 
police force is cool and our oppressive legal system is cool because
it can so easily prosecute people for doing drugs and attending  
non-permitted parties.

It's easy to admire power when it doesn't seem to be oppressing you
directly, but in my opinion, the power worship mentality is like
bowing to an authority figure just because it has authority over you.
Blind loyalty to strong things is one of the basic things about human
nature that make this world so fucked up.  

But yeah, I was entertained by the war planes.  Maybe next year the
navy will detonate a (small) atomic bomb on Angel Island to impress us.
That would *really* be cool.

Lee

I thought sunset was pretty amazing... It was located in the presidio, and
driving out to the spot, i was much amazed by the view...i liked the
location too... 

we got there around 4:00, an dmusic was just starting.  someone told me
that before that they had generator problems, but after 4, the music
didn't stop (except when the police came) until sunset.  the police came 3
times, first was the ranger police who said that they needed permits and
that no alcohol was allowed, but after the looked around a bit, they let
sunset keep going until sunset, when they had to shut it down, i thought
they were very nice about it.  then the military police came, but i don't
think they did anything except just look around.  finally at sunset, the
ranger police came back and shut it down, a little early due to noise
complaints...which i can understand because there were houses on the other
side of the hill... 

i thought the vibe was really incredible and i talked too and met many new
people... 

i had a very nice time... 

-john

the tb303 has two componenents:

a synthesizer
a sequencer

anyone who knows how to synthesize can either exactly emulate or make
a superior sound to the tb303

anyone who knows how to sequence can do the same.

anyone who doesn't believe me is welcome to come to the Blue Cube Studios
and watch me demonstrate the TRUTH of this.

people love the tb303 because they don't *have* to learn to sequence or
synthesize.

sorta like how people use violin samples instead of learning to play the
violin


From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 10 17:38:04 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id RAA02789; Mon, 10 Oct 1994 17:38:04 -0700

	id QAA21240; Mon, 10 Oct 1994 16:18:22 -0700
Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 16:18:22 -0700
From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)
Message-Id: <199410102318.QAA21240@netcom.netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Weekend report
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Weekend Rave report
-------------------

   This weekend had Wicked @ DV8,  Thrive (Which got busted twice - Shame on
you folks for even *considering* that Caldecott location),  and YSH which
was cancelled.   DARN!!   I was looking forward to that one.    Because I
volunteered to help set up an Internet Connection at Megatripolus,   I had
to at least be there between 8pm and Midnight.   Then was planning to head
over to YSH,  until I found it was cancelled.

   This 2nd installation of Megatripolus was far less crowded,  primary
reason being the $10 cover charge.    As they opened up,   things started 
very slow,   but started picking up later.    With the night being unusually
warm,   I had expected it to be hot and humid,  but the Troc must have
turned on the air conditioner.    Although the fans weren't present,  
I managed to stay cool.     

   Leaving and coming back now presented no problem,  and the security
"glitches" seemed to have been worked out.    The "Annex" across the
street offered free coffey with a box for donations.   Had plently of
cushions and pillows to flop down on,   and the ambience provided 
total and complete isolation from the dancing area.   It was a short
(And welcome) walk across the street,   at whats being called the
Annex..

   The music started out with deep funkey house,   and trance.   Then
started to gradually pick up,  until it was time for the speaker.

   If you go to Megatripolus with the expectation of non-stop dancing,
you might be dissapointed,    but these half hour breaks in the dancing
give time for interesting lecturers.    Not long,  the music started up
again.  None of these interruptions to the dancing lasted much more than
about a half hour,   and if one knows this in advance,  can at least 
plan their shill times to coencide with the breaks,  so it isn't all
that bad....

   About 2 am or so,  Jeremy got behind the turntables,  and put out the
most "Twisted" Jungle and hard core set I have heard since "Industrial
Strength" last year.   Yowsa!  didn't think my body could move that
fast....   1 1/2 hours of sustained hard-core can really get the blood
flowing....   Yummy!!.... Naturally,  a lot of California weenies were
wimping out,  and not dancing,  and complaining about the speed.   We
don't get much of this here in San Francisco!!!   Not all folks like
it here...

   Later on,  things slowed down again (rather abruptly),  clearly
indicating another DJ was spinning.   I took the opportunity to catch
the end of the lecture from the dude that founded "Burning man".
Unfortunately,   his lecture and presentation was at the same time
as the twisted hard-core set,   and I NEVER miss an opportunity 
to dance to it.

   This 2nd Magatripolus was different from the first,  as a whole
new set of DJ's presented their stuff.    Names I've never heard 
except was surprised that Jeremy was spinning.    I met him several
times at Sunset,   talked a lot while chilling.   I definitely will
recommend that Frazer put him on again.    I think that if they keep
having new DJ's each time,  and have the variaty of music they have had
in the last two editions,   I think that it has the potentuality to
draw a lot of people.   They have listened intentely to my sugesstions
and have read the SFRaves reports and critics,  and at least know what
the issues are.   Thats more than what I can say about a lot of 
promoters out there.

   The Internet computer was plagued by phone line problems.   Apparently,
the connection would get cut,   but later on,  it was worked out.    Thanx
go out to Ried for providing the Mac portable and figuring out the
modem problem.

   This next weekend,  the Russian River Amoeba party... Oh Yum!!
this is supposed to be good...  Gotta dust off the sleeping bag
from "Burning man!"  - Yukk!!

And now.... SUNSET IS BACK!!   Yay!!  And thanx go out to the authorities
(somewhat confused on what to do) to allow us to have it on the Presidio.

It was really incredable,  this site...  A huge grove of euculipsic trees,
with a spectacular view of the ocean abd the sunset.   We would get
visited often by many kinds of police.    Park rangers,   Military police,
etc.    All which caused the music to be turned down,  with the exception
of one time,  while the Sunset people were negotiating with the cops for
a chance to allow us to continue.   One time,  the Military police came
over and bitched because someone parked next to a fence,  alegedly to
keep people out of a munitions dump.   It was clearly indicated that NO
ALCOHOL and drugs were allowed,   and we would have to leave by exactly
sunset.   We had two hours (WOW!),  danced like there was no tommorrow,
and stopped only to chill out.    Weather was perfect in all respects.
No wind,   balmey....   Couldn't be better.

When the sun funally set,   sure enough,   up came the cops to make sure
we stopped on time.    The DJ was allowed to finish the song,   and held
up the next record in a jesture to indicate LAST SONG... I stepped up
my intensity...    until the fadeout....   Everyone cheered....   Very
good conclusion....

More next week...
CC

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 10 20:05:54 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id UAA05915; Mon, 10 Oct 1994 20:05:54 -0700
Received: from uclink.berkeley.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id UAA05907; Mon, 10 Oct 1994 20:05:07 -0700

Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 20:03:20 -0700 (PDT)
From: Sami Khoury <sk1@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Subject: Re: that pesky ol' TB303
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <199410110027.RAA13582@netcom9.netcom.com>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9410101924.B27768-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> anyone who knows how to synthesize can either exactly emulate or make
> a superior sound to the tb303

Exactly emulate?  Not really.  Different synths sound different 
because they are constructed of different components.  I'm sure *someone* 
at Nova knows how to "synthesize", but the BassStation still doesn't 
"exactly emulate" the 303.  Superior sound?  Sure, but it also depends on 
the setting and mood.  A sound is worthless if it doesn't fit anywhere.

> anyone who knows how to sequence can do the same.

Again, not really.  Part of the 303's sound is it's portamento (or slide) 
function.  This is not implemented in all sequencers (hardware or 
software), and not all synths which have portamento onboard transmit 
sysex for this function.

> anyone who doesn't believe me is welcome to come to the Blue Cube Studios
> and watch me demonstrate the TRUTH of this.

I think I'd rather go just to see it.  And to see WBL play, as well.

> people love the tb303 because they don't *have* to learn to sequence or
> synthesize.

I like the sound.  Is that so wrong?

> sorta like how people use violin samples instead of learning to play the
> violin

Sorta.

	Sami

Received: from Zool.AirTouch.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id VAA07033; Mon, 10 Oct 1994 21:37:38 -0700
Received: from nit.AirTouch.COM (pinbot.nit.airtouch.com) by Zool.AirTouch.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1/AirTouch-Zool:MLC:940403-02)
	id AA11625; Mon, 10 Oct 94 21:33:50 PDT
Received: from eon.nit.airtouch.com by nit.AirTouch.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1/AirTouch-nit:MLC-940403-02)
	id AA05229; Mon, 10 Oct 94 21:36:11 PDT
From: eric@nit.AirTouch.COM (Eric Pederson)
Message-Id: <9410110436.AA05229@nit.AirTouch.COM>
Subject: Re: that pesky ol' TB303
To: sk1@uclink.berkeley.edu (Sami Khoury)
Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 21:36:10 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9410101924.B27768-0100000@uclink.berkeley.edu> from "Sami Khoury" at Oct 10, 94 08:03:20 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL17]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3627      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> > anyone who knows how to synthesize can either exactly emulate or make
> > a superior sound to the tb303

not really, as discussed on the analog list, both the synthesis
and the sequencer on the 303 are unique to that instrument.  the filter
and the way it interacts with the accent and the sequencer are different,
jon d can expound at length on the sequencer, and the 303 filter
was described by mr 808:

> The following is excerpted from the TB-303 Service Notes (The Book of Roland,
> Book 1, Chapter 2, Verse 101).  No attempts have been made to translate from
> the Rolandese:
> 
> VCF ENVELOPE MODULATION
> In the conventional VCF configuration, envelope modulation voltages applied
> to modulation control voltage input of VCF rise from a fixed potential to
> their values regardless of shape and amount of envelope and fall back to the
> same potential. Fig. 1. In this setup, an attempt to deepen envelope
> modulation is increment of control voltage in one direction, only to open up
> filter.  Resultants are; higher the control voltage input, longer the period
> of time cutoff point travels through higher frequency range in which
> significant aural sound characteristic changes do not occur, whereas notes
> are brightened.
> To compensate for the limitation this impose, there is a GIMMICK in the
> TB-303 VCF circuit (emphasis mine).  The Q9 has a key role in this
> arrangement.  See Fig. 2.  It developes bias for Q10 and Q11 to set initial
> cutoff point at the center of frequency range. Within the range even a small
> amount of voltage can create a appreciable modulation.
>
  (ascii schematic deleted)
> 
> Rotating wiper of VR5 increases ENV MOD voltage being
> fed to base of Q10 while changing the bias which in turn
> lowers VCF cutoff frequency.  See Fig. 3.  This is equal
> to turning CUTOFF knob counterclockwise and, since Q10 and   
> Q11 in combination convert control voltage to the current
> in anti-log fashion, the cutoff point stays in an effective
> frequency range for the most portion of envelope sweeping duration.
> 
> The interpretation by Reverend 808 is as follows:
> 
> There are two unusual features in the 303 VCF circuit.  One, the holy GIMMICK
> as detailed above, is that the envelope modulation voltage is not added to
> the cutoff frequency as w/ other VCF designs.  Instead, the initial filter
> cutoff frequency is inversely modulated by the envelope so that the filter
> cutoff frequency can increase, then decrease to follow the filter.  Or, as
> Brother erik so keenly observed:
> 
> >1. If you turn the env-mod-poti clockwise not only the
> >   amount of modulation rises but also the cut-off-freq
> >   decreases. Because when the envelope reaches its end
> >   the cutoff is lower than it would be if the env-mod-
> >   poti is set to zero. 
> 
> The second feature, which was gained by scrutinizing the schematic diagram,
> is that ACCENT MODULATES THE RESONANCE AMOUNT.  As Resonance amount
> increases, so does the amount of Accent modulation.  As Brother erik also
> noted (note 5.), the Accent increases the level of Envelope modulation.  This
> affects both the VCA and the VCF.
> 
> I challenge the heretic DACC to name a non-modular monosynth that can
> duplicate the above, or alternately, supply instructions on how to simulate
> the above effects w/ same.

which basically means that you can't exactly duplicate a 303 with just
any analog synth, though you can come close in certain cases.
-- 
Eric Pederson                                        AirTouch Communications
eric@nit.airtouch.com                                           510-210-8890


From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 10 22:48:46 1994

	(1.38.193.5/16.2) id AA01916; Tue, 11 Oct 1994 01:36:12 -0400

Subject: Club Wicked
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Wicked@DV8 - looks like a club, certainly felt like a club, fortunately
didn't sound like a club.  I'm not complaining, it was what I expected and I
had fun.  Music was up to Wicked's always high quality and that new system
can be LOUD though fortunately it wasn't all night.  I thought Jeno spun a
particularuly killer set.  Not *that* different than his usual skillful self
and I knew a lot of the tracks but it was just SLAMMIN and so *ON*.  It
provided a nice contrast to Sunset which was great as always too.  I can't
help think that the powers that be would have been happier and perhaps kinder
in the future if we had all driven away a little bit more quickly and
coherently.  Of course the reason I know this is that I was guilty of
lingering for quite a while myself.  We really are lucky to have a wide
variety of consistently good parties to choose from.  From the Blue Angels
dive bombing the Golden Gate as I drove across it to relaxing on the beach
for awhile after Sunset(though the sun was still setting) I had one of those
"I'm *SO* glad I live in S.F. I can't begin to express it" feelings and it
wasn't even an out-of-the-ordinary weekend.

love y'all and this city,
phuture

Here's the directions to Kim's Restaurant , the site of this Wednesday's
South Bay Lunch at 11:30 AM:

 The restaurant is in the city of Mountain View , at 368 Castro Street ,
between California Ave. and Dana St. , near the intersection of Castro
and California. There is parking behind the restaurant.

 From the North , on HW 101: Drive past Palo Alto , past the HW 85 exit.
  Take the Moffett Blvd. exit , driving towards the west. After Middlefield
  Road , don't be in the right hand lane , as it turns off Castro after
  the train tracks. If you can't find parking on Castro , make a right turn
  at California , and park behind the restaurant.

 From the South , on HW 101: Drive past Sunnyvale , past the Ellis Street
  exit and the Moffett Field exits and take the Moffett Blvd. exit. 
  Drive west , and follow the same directions as above.

 From El Camino Real: Drive to Castro Street , turn onto Castro Street
  towards the bay. You could turn left at California and right onto
  Bryant to get to the parking lot , or you can try Castro Street 
  for parking. 

 See you there!
			Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
 PS - I have a sample menu form this restaurant - they seem to be proud
  of their vegitarian dishes. And they also have a wide selection of
  omnivore dishes as well.

>From anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl Mon Oct 10 12:11:21 1994
Return-Path: <anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl>
X400-Received: by mta sapling.surfnet.nl in /PRMD=surf/ADMD=400net/C=nl/;
               Relayed; Mon, 10 Oct 1994 19:37:59 +0100

               Mon, 10 Oct 1994 19:36:34 +0100

               Mon, 10 Oct 1994 19:35:24 +0100
Date: Mon, 10 Oct 1994 19:35:24 +0100
X400-Originator: WOODL@VAX.LSE.ac.uk
X400-Recipients: anarchy-list@cwi.nl
X400-Mts-Identifier: [/PRMD=uk.ac/ADMD= /C=gb/;sun2.mhs-r.109:10.09.94.18.36.34]
X400-Content-Type: P2-1984 (2)
Content-Identifier: Riot in London
From: WOODL@VAX.LSE.ac.uk
To: anarchy-list <anarchy-list@cwi.nl>
Subject: Riot in London
Mailer: Janet_Mailshr V3.3a (02-Feb-1989)
Sender: anarchy-list-request@cwi.nl
Content-Length: 3056
X-Lines: 48
Status: RO

FYI folks!
Yesterday afternoon there was a massive (40.000) protest march and rally
against the legislation of the Criminal Justice Bill which is scheduled to go 
through in the next few weeks. This Bill will make it illegal for gatherings 
of over 10 people on public land, and will allow squatters to be evicted within
24 hours, both serious threats to civil liberties in the UK. As well, the right
to silence will be removed -- obscene in a Bill created originally to reduce
wrongful convictions.
So the thousands of people marched through the streets of London, accompanied
by the sound systems which promote and support the rave culture in Britain. 
At around 5pm, when everyone was raving away in Hyde Park, the police started
rushing the park on horseback, trying to shut down the rave, whose permit was
to end at 4:30. My feeling is that if the police had laid low, the rave would
have continued til people got hungry and the pubs opened and folks owuld
have left. But rave music is political here, symbolic in the same way that 
punk once was. The police were determined to shut it down. 

But things did not go as planned. When the police charged, the crowds of 4-5000
moved towards them and after hailing bottles and sticks at them, the mounted
police moved outside the gates. Along the gates were hundreds of cops in riot
gear. Repeatedly they charged the fence, behind which massed hundreds of masked
protesters. While missiles were few, folks went on forays into the city and
returned bearing paving stones and sticks. When the police charged and tried
to batter across the fence, there was a strong hail of bags of sand, bottles and
sticks, so they quickly withdrew. 

Still, the mood was festive, a bicycle powered sound system repeatedly circled
and fire eaters and jugglers performed, poets ranted through megaphones
and the crowd danced to hardcore techno. When space was reclaimed, it just
became part of the dance floor, making the cops assaults increasingly ludicrious
At around 10 pm, Word circulated that all the gates had closed and we were all
hungry tired and it felt like a good time to leave. Yet, when we headed for the 
exits, all the streets were lined with cops in riot gear and the Underground/
Metro was closed. Quickly, people broke through the lines across Oxford St.
and suddenly store windows were shattering and everyone was running -- fast.
53 Shops had their windows smashed including the Boots and McDonalds, both
companies under boycott. When Tottenham Court Road Station was reached, many
broke through the lines and entered the transport to go home.

The BBC reported that police are looking for a group of anarchist organizers
for the riot. Personally I think that it was largely spontaneous, a situation
created by the cops, with a crowd sick and tired of being harassed; this week
the longstanding road protest in Leytonstone, London will probably end after
a slow destruction of homes and communities. 

The cracks in the system are increasingly evident, and the political is
becoming redefined.
lovlesley


----- End Included Message -----

             <9410102146.AA26294@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>

From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

<rambling commentary follows -- beware>

like many, I have mixed feelings about the blue angels and the military.

the thing i like about the military and the military industrial complex
is that it is a wonderful make-work program. socialism without any of
those democracy-good-communism-bad dumbfucks actually knowing/admitting
that it is socialism. (The fact that the irony of all this is lost on
these people is ironic, ain't it?)

the thing that I don't like about it is that all this high-tech work is
in the hands of private corporations, rather than the government
itself. most of what ills this country is privatization of this work.
costs would be significantly reduced if we got rid of the middle-man
(industrialists, multiple levels of subcontractors each skimming some
$$$ and passing the crumbs on to labor) and put the government in
charge of everything -- no more bidding games (the company w/ the
lowest bid and the biggest payoffs to congress wins, then they jack the
govt for big $$$ as they slowly unveil that their bidding and proposal
process was complete fiction.).

all this bullshit about "competition being healthy" is just that --
bullshit. Competition inspires cheating, fraud and brings out the worst
in mankind -- war instincts. Competition, privatization and all that
crap just breeds waste,  duplicated effort, a majority of losers, and a
minority of winners. In a system where competitiveness means 10% are
deemed winners and 90% are losers means that we create a lot of losers.
It is no wonder we keep on having recessions because ours is a system
that devours itself. Beyond that, we're wasting effort and most
importantly resources on a system where competition and its inherent
wastefulness is considered good. The earth is too small and limited for
us to be wasting resources -- the "product" of the other 90%, the
losers, is wasted energy, wasted time, wasted material. WIth the
earth's limited resources, this is clearly folly. (Is it any wonder
that things are completely fucked up when we're indoctrinated at such
an early age that competition is good?)

the other thing i like about space program, and military technology is
that they have really forced a strong boost in technology itself. I'm
all too familiar with private industry's ability to do research on it's
own -- it's completely pathetic, and no real innovation has  ever been
the result of industrial, product-oriented research (everything that we
consider innovation, from computer technology to medicine has come from
govt. funded research which private industry steals, repackages,
markets, and sells).

our system is such that corporate R&D is at best 1 or 2 years "out",
mostly because the stock market rewards companies that slash their
research work force, and also because most US corporate pinheads are
focused on quick returns on investments, rather than long-term risky
projects (long-term risky projects don't make for good resume foddder
when you're jostling for position to rise up a corporate ladder). Fact
is, the only innovation in the US happens in the university labs and
think-tanks funded by ARPA, NSF, NRL, etc. Because risk and long-term
rewards are expected there, but shunned in industry.

As an example, before the space and satellite program forced dense
electronic integration, the corporate response to various proposed
integrated circuit technologies was "how are we going to be able to
service and replace parts in integrated circuits when they're so tiny?"
They couldn't project out to a day when an integrated circuit
containing hundreds of thousands of components would be so cheap to
manufacture that you would just replace the whole thing, rather than
servicing it. Major advances in manufacturing technology, from the
microscopic to the macroscopic, have enabled us to create things that
the corporate pinheads would have vetoed as impossible to create,
impossible to market to everyman. And yet they exist, no thanks to
the corporate profit-oriented cover-yer-ass easier-to-say-no-than-yes folk.

If it weren't for nearly unlimited govt. $$$ to make technological
develkopment possible, we'd probably still be using discrete circuitry
and none of the things that we take for granted in our modern life --
ubiquitous computers, audio, internet, telephony etc -- would exist. Of
course, once something has been proved possible, industry will  be
happy to take a guaranteed thing and refine it to death.... BUt they
won't ever take the first step.
 
It's the old hippie in us that hates technology, but the raver in us
loves it.  a balanced view would indicate things like the space program
and high-budget military R&D have made what we're doing possible -- our
music, our beloved synths, amplifiers, digital recording studios; our
communications, bulletin boards and computers made possible by
far-sighted ARPA funding of universities and research labs.

you might view all this as an incredible waste of money, but you forget
that many of you are living off the profits of our huge investments in
military and space technology. I've heard the figures of this ROI
(return on investment) from our tax dollars being in the 1000% region,
though unfortunately, we've set up a system where the returns are
trickling up, rather than down.

if anything, the problem is that we didn't socialize  the system
enough, that we didn't spend enough tax dollars to make this
military-industrial-science-technology make-work program reach 100%
employment. In other words, it should  have also helped people in the
ghetto. If you think about it, it used to -- 20-50 years ago parts of
SF and Oakland that are now slums used to be blue collar working class
neighborhoods fueled by the moneys of naval shipyards. Now we've
got Hunters Point and West Oakland, to say nothing of the "california
recession".

I'd like to see national make-work programs continue, but perhaps on
some goal that we can all work for, and a goal that doesn't dominate
other peoples via  sabre rattling and war machines.  WHere? How? It's
up in the sky -- the space program, paid for by heavy heavy taxes on
the rich. Don't even make it worthwhile to get rich in private
industry, and give big breaks to those that are willing to work for
lower wages on this national goal, as well as support for this goal,
e.g. education, health-care, etc. In short, take the practices of the
reagan-bush era and invert them.

I for one would be happy to pay much more taxes (as long as everybody
else is also being taxed equally) in order to create a system of
universal employment, universal education, universal health care, with
a grand overall goal of colonizing space.

Too bad that this will never happen in the US -- we're too busy 
poisoning our dreams with "Lifestyles of the Rich and Famous" and all
those superficial fashion-wanks we see on TV.

-- Niels "honor labor" Mayer.

                      RE>that pesky ol' TB303                      10/10/94
Haven't looked inside a 303 specifically, but having looked inside other Roland
gear, my guess would be that it's made up almost entirely of proprietary chips
(stuff you can't get at Radio Shack, but only from Roland's Japanese OEM manufacturers).
Next best step many others have already taken is to borrow their friend's 303
and sample each sound, then sell the samples at those VERY cheap rates. You can
find a slew of small shops doing this in the Transoniq Hacker, for instance.
-nate

Do not fear - this stuff *does* relate to raving.
 
> I'd like to see national make-work programs continue, but perhaps on
> some goal that we can all work for, and a goal that doesn't dominate
> other peoples via  sabre rattling and war machines.  WHere? How? It's
> up in the sky -- the space program, paid for by heavy heavy taxes on
> the rich. Don't even make it worthwhile to get rich in private
> industry, and give big breaks to those that are willing to work for
> lower wages on this national goal, as well as support for this goal,
> e.g. education, health-care, etc. In short, take the practices of the
> reagan-bush era and invert them.

Niels, I couldn't agree with you more on the above paragraph.  In
addition to, or perhaps instead of working for lower wages, a shorter
work week would also help us reach full employment while leaving people
with more liesure time to explore cheaper forms of entertainment like
spending time with family/friends, and, uh, attending and putting on 
raves. d;-)
 
>[...] a grand overall goal of colonizing space.

One element of raving is that, for many of us, it is a transcendental
experience.  We transcend the need to sleep, the need to cling to our
egos and insecurities, the need to stay rooted a "normal" state of 
consciousness, while dancing to music and beats that cannot be physically 
played by humans.  To me, using technology to further dominate and 
control this planet is a rather shortsighted goal compared to attaining 
the freedom to get beyond it.

Not that I mean to trivialize the need for a stable foundation from which
to launch ourselves - but the amount of expense people and nations
put aside in order to nurture their distrust of each other is 
overwhelming when compared to what humans expend in order to explore new 
horizons.  I'm not sure whether it is an innate part of human nature to be 
so insecure and doubtful, or whether we all have been brainwhashed by 
the powermongers to be that way.  One thing I like about raving is that
not only does it defy the status quo authoritarian structure of things,
but it usually attempts to do so in a positive way.  I.e. raving is an
extension of our culture, not the destruction or suppression of it.

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (  ( ((Everything Is Possible)) )  )  lee@hyperreal.com

> 
> P.S.  I certainly would condemn anyone throwing things at the police,
>       but it is understandable how things have come to that point.
>       Go back and listen to 'Guns of Brixton', 'White Riot' and most
>       anything by Linton Kwesi Johnson to see how long this has been
>       going on . . .
>

Yeah, I'm totally down with LKJ. 
BTW do you have the LKJ dub 12" of sonny's letter?


Back in '84 I think it was, I was over in England when they were having
riots in Brixton and another part of London.  It was sparked off by 
three seperate incidents involving the police breaking into people's homes
brandishing and using firearms (they obviously had been watching too many
Dirty Harry movies).  In one instance, they came in, told eveyone to freeze.
They saw movement under the covers of a bed and shot and killed a 5 year old
boy.  The grandmother in the house had a heart attack and died right there.
They refused to call an ambulance for her until well over 20 minutes had
passed.  The person that they had come to arrests (supposedly for traffic 
violations, although it was believed he was a big time dealer of "drugs") 
was not on the premises, later when he was arrested, they had to 
release him because  they had nothing on him.  This set off several 
days of intense but relatively organized rioting centered around several 
housing complexes.  The interesting thing to me was that it WAS NOT 
just young black kids rioting and fighting the police but young whites as well.
Some of the insurgents were interviewed on television and they were
very clear why they were doing this.  They were tired of being
mistreated by the police and the recent shootings were the last straw.
Of course British Society be the condenscending racist society that it
is, (much like the good ol' US of A) could not see these young whites
as being in solidarity with their black counterparts but chalked their
participation up to "communist ringleaders" (obviously if a riot
exhibits some organized tendencies, it MUST be because white folks are
in charge ;)

Anyway, this latest incident just goes to show you what can happen if people
are pushed too much.  Fortuntely for the British, the police are not normally
equipped with guns.  If this had happened here, it would have been Kent State
all over again.

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: RE: THAT PESKY OL
content-length: 780
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> And furthermore, I don't know about
> the 303 really, but if it's an analog sound, you can never completely duplicate
> it with something digital.  There's *no way* you can with today's tech.

Well, there's no way to do it *affordably* wth today's tech, but it could be
done.  There are CPUs out there that can do a billion operations per second.
(I know DEC makes one.  Intel and Motorola probably do too.)  If I model each
analog component using one of these (i.e. one CPU would be a dedicated sine
wave generator, another CPU would be a dedicated filter), there is absolutely
no way you could distinguish the difference between an analog system and the
equivalent digital one.  You could *easily* model a 303 digitally.  But you
might have to take out a mortgage to do it.



From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 11 12:04:14 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9410111903.AA11018@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Presidio, Police, and Parties
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Things I have learned from the Park Patrol and other places:

Some of the Park Patrol are extreme hotheads. As in "Get out of the
car and stand against the fence."

Some are not, and while they see the parties as essentially harmless,
they want to set a precedent that they _will_ shut them down. They are
afraid of a free-for-all now that it is a public park.

There are a lot of patrols in the park. The park is utterly dead quiet
late at night. The only traffic will be your party and the park
patrol.

There are undercover police who work the park. They are there
specifically to find drugs.

The park patrol really really hates to see alcohol.

The Presidio is federal property, and crimes there can be prosecuted
under federal statutes. In particular, penalties for crimes related to
scheduled substances are substantially harsher than California
statutes.

The Presidio is a very large very beautiful and very tempting place to
throw a renegade. If you are thinking about it, take heed of the above
and plan accordingly. I personally would not do a party there, as
there are just too many patrols, and traffic to/from the site is very
conspicuous. A renegade might succeed if partygoers parked in a
residential neighborhood and walked to the site.

It should be possible to obtain permits for parties there. A daytime
event there would be wonderful. Let's barbeque :).

Sean

Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 13:17:54 -0700
From: mw@sybase.com (Michael Wertheim)
Message-Id: <9410112017.AA05248@martha.sybgate.sybase.com>
To: rpeck@nas.nasa.gov
Subject: Re: THAT PESKY OL
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
content-length: 2124
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> hardly.  Are you just making this stuff up as you go along?  The best way to 
> make an analog synth with today's technology would be to use analog today's
> _analog_ technology.
I never said this would be a smart way to do things.  The original poster
said that a digital system could not emulate an analog one.  I disagreed.

> If you wanted a system that uses digital signal processing and digitally
> controlled oscillators to reproduce a 303 sound, you're pretty much out of
> luck.  You can sample it and get something that sounds a lot like the orignal,
> but if you make it louder, you don't get the distortion that you would from
> a real 303.  That is, the errors created by an analog system sound different
> from the errors created by a digital system.  It's the error that gives the
> sound it's charm.
I'm not talking about sampling at all.  I'm talking about creating a digital
model of an analog system.  The model could emulate the noise as well.
And at 1 billion operations for second, which is an incredible amount of
overkill for this type of problem, there should be *no* noticeable digital 
errors.  (I'm not saying you would *have* to use such a powerful CPU.  I was
saying that the problem *could* be solved using one.)

> As far as cost goes, DSP is super cheap.  No super expensive general purpose
> CPU needed.   All this stuff is done at the hardware level by specialized 
> chips which were produced largely because the phone company and other 
> telecommunications firms need them to handle the daily telephone, television,
> and other traffic all over the world.
True, but DSP is the technology that digital synths use, and it's incredibly
lame at producing analog sounds.  I'm talking about modelling the actual 
analog circuitry, which is a completely different problem altogether.  There
are digital synths out now (the VL1) that use incredible amounts of processing
to emulate acoustic instruments through physical modelling.  I was posing a
similar solution of modelling a 303 in the same way.  Actually, I wonder if
the VL1's architecture could be used to emulate the 303.  Hmmm...




From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 11 13:22:25 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

 id <01HI5GP9SSRK00UDVR@EDEN1.HAC.COM>; Tue, 11 Oct 1994 13:20:43 PST
Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 13:20:42 -0800 (PST)
Subject: that pesky (revisited) TB303
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <01HI5GP9W0IA00UDVR@EDEN1.HAC.COM>
X-Vms-To: EDEN1::IN%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

ummm.....

   it's not possible for a given synth to EXACTLY duplicate another;
     each synth (especially analog ones) has it's own special tone
       color, which is determined by each and every component inside
         the box.  
   i've got an oberheim OB1, and a Juno 106.  there's NO WAY i can
     get the juno to sound exactly like the OB1, because they are from
       different eras, and have radically different circuits.

   this difference is even more exaggerated when one considers the
     newer synths, with all the various sort of linear, subtractive,
       additive, morphing, and what-have-you types of synthesis...

   so you mite be able to get a sound SIMILAR to yer TB303, but you'll
     never duplicate it, unless you chop the original apart and rebuild
      a clone piece-by-piece.

   don't forget there's a big difference between an analog sequencer
     and a digital one, too....


seeya!

Dave Scruton


From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 11 13:56:12 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id NAA24772; Tue, 11 Oct 1994 13:56:12 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id NAA24762; Tue, 11 Oct 1994 13:56:05 -0700
Message-Id: <199410112056.NAA24762@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Not Getting Stuck
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 11 Oct 1994 13:49:44 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 4986
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

The following letter appeared in _Processed_World_ Number 31.  I quote
without permission, but the magazine appears to be un-copyrighted. Any
misquotations or mis-spellings are entirely my own fault. I reproduce this
in this forum, because this appears to be the beginnings of a methodology
of transformation that may be applicable in our scene and in our lives. The
letter is quoted verbatim.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------
"We all know that the existing institutions are rotten.  Capitalism,
white supremacy, patriarchy, the state--you name it.  But what alternatives
have we proposed? Not many.

"I think this is a big problem.  It means that activists are struggling day
to day with only vague ideas about the kind of society we're fighting for,
or how to bring it about.  It means it's easy for us to re-create, in our own 
organizations, the very evils we're fighting against.  It also means we have
a hard time convincing other folks to join us.  If major social change is
going to happen, we'll need some fairly specific ideas about what to change
to, expressed in a way that lots of non-activists can relate to.  But proposing
alternative institutions is hard to do-- much harder than criticizing what
exists now.  How do we do it?

"There are people who suspect the very idea of envisioning something better.
I mean proposals about the kind of society we want to live in, the kind of
society that's worth struggling for. (Actually, 'vision' may not be the right
word, because it has connotations of something mystical and impractical.)

"It's about ~proposing~ ideas, not ~imposing~ them.  It's about ideas emerging
from a process of democratic dialogue.  And that is exactly the spirit in
which I am proposing these ideas on how to think about vision.  In no way do
I think I've got it all figured out.  THIS IS NOT A SET OF INSTRUCTIONS THAT
I WANT YOU TO FOLLOW.  Let's start a dialogue on how we can all get better
at thinking about vision.  Examine and criticize these ideas and then propose
your own.  Nor is it about predicting the future.  It's about naming and
communicating your desires, changing that part of the future that's within your
control and preparing to cope with that part that's out of your control.  It's
not about producing a fixed blueprint, or a plan. It's about an ongoing
planning ~process~.  The plans that come out are only for the purposes of
documenting where the process stands at a particular moment.  The process is
about changing the actions you take now, and about the human development of
everybody involved.

"Finally, it's not about pointless fantasizing, disconnected from action.  It's
about expressing the ideals that guide action.  I would argue that ~any~ action
towards social change is guided by some ideals of a better society.  Most of 
the time, these ideals are not stated, so they can't be examined and debated.
I think it's very useful to make these ideals explicit.  We should specify
present desires, not predict future outcomes.

"You don't have to say how this desired future would come about, or even argue
that it is possible to bring it about.  There is no requirement that it be
implementable.  Assume magic.  This will help you get clear about what you
really want.  One of the biggest obstacles to creativity is letting implemen-
tation issues constrain your desires and you imagination.

"You ~do~ have to explain how it would work, and how it would maintain itself
if it did exist.  No magic here.  It has to be technologically, ecologically,
and humanly ~feasible~ (for example, it can't require saints, but you can allow
for people's potential to be better than they are today). It has to be capable
of sustaining itself over time.  It has to be specific enough to be reasonably
argued with.  It must be quickly and easily ~adaptable~ (this helps avoid the
fixed blueprint problem).  Finally, it should be ~inspiring~ because if you're
not excited about it, then something went wrong.

"Here is a set of steps for getting started:
* Define the issue you're working on
* Define your criteria
* Define the components of what you're designing
* Identify the existing alternatives
* Evaluate the existing alternatives against the criteria
* Design new alternatives which would meet the criteria better
* Think about how your design relates to other areas
* Get comments from people, incorporate new ideas

"The opposition in this county is suffering from a vast failure of the imagi-
nation.  We know what we're against, but we're not nearly so clear about what
we're for.  It's time for us to figure it out -- all of us, not just a few
brilliant individuals.  Of course, developing a new vision of a better society
will not guarantee the changes we want.  But I am convinced these changes 
cannot and will not happen without such a vision."

The letter is signed "D.S., San Francisco"
-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

ummm.....

   it's not possible for a given synth to EXACTLY duplicate another;
     each synth (especially analog ones) has it's own special tone
       color, which is determined by each and every component inside
         the box....
-------------------------
I knew it was just a matter of time before the acoustic puritans spoke up on
this! :) Sound design is one of the few places I believe the Maciavellian "the
end justifies the means" really applies. I really don't care if you use 100 oscillators
or 100 kHz sample rate, or if you bang on a trashcan lid (or even if you use a
TB303!), as long as it sounds interesting. The "I created this with a circa 1965
Soviet-built synth using a 25-pitch microtonal scale" thing is fun for a novelty
listen, but if it doesn't _sound_ cool to you or someone else, who cares? The
sound designer's goal as I see it is a greater multiplicity of means (synth,
sample/computational, and "acoustic" instruments included), so that you might
stumble upon some interesting ends.

And let's not forget that it's what you do with that cool sound once you'
ve found it, music-wise, that ultimately matters.  :)

-nate

On Tue, 11 Oct 1994, resonate wrote:

> 
> people- if that TB303 sounds just as fat on CD as it does anywhere
> else (and it *does*) then a computer can generate 303 sounds because:
> 
> data on a CD is binary.

	Generating original sound and recording/playback are different realms. 
In recording and playback, the digital machine need only do a quick 
sample and write that or reproduce it. The problem with generating the 
sound is you need algorithum to sound it. Unless you have an analog 
machine, you are in effect screwing with (damn I for get the two series, 
one makes good drum noises, well it supposed to, and is used in FM chips 
that you might find on your sound card if you have one). The analog 
machine actually directly manipulates the current and voltage to produce 
noise through speakers. And it is quite difficulkt to approxiamte a twist 
of a pot with a math equation....

dave

 > 
 > people- if that TB303 sounds just as fat on CD as it does anywhere
 > else (and it *does*) then a computer can generate 303 sounds 
 > because:
 > 
 > data on a CD is binary.

True... but you don't get the same control over the sound that any analog synth
gives you.  With analog, you never get the same sound twice, and in order to
get that kind of control, as someone mentioned, you'd need monster computers. 
Stick to analog, if you want an analog sound.  Easy enough!  The comparison
between analog and digital is the same as the comparison to CD's and records. 
Records offer a wider variety of frequency, and a more natural sound, although
for clarity, a cd works better.  But everybody I'm sure has had this debate
many times...
                        JesusChrysler

From: "David M. Ilstrup" <dmi@holonet.net>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

This talk about the 303 and analog vs. digital has got me interested.

One of my hobbies is math nerding on digital signal processing.

The way I see it is this. Analog synths have one major advantage over
sampling technology right now, and that is simply that analog synths
give much more *parametric* control. What I mean is that there is
simply no counterpart in the digital domain to those nifty little knobs
that you have on analog synths. Sure you could sample a 303, but you only
get the sound that you've set. The range of timbres on the original
instrument is lost. Of course if DSP algorithms for modifying a starting
set of samples become available that have a similar utility to those
knobs, then it will be a whole different story...

-dmi

resonate expounds:
> Sound is the sum of all ingredients that go into its creation.
> 
> Would you eat a meal knowing it had the flesh of tortured animals in it?
> 
> I don't synthesize with anything except analog synthesizers. Argue all you
> want but purity is purity.

Analogue lets you hear the electrons in all their chaotic glory, digital is a
programmers version of it.  When asked if people would find virtual reality
more appealing than reality, Jaron Lanier responded, "No, virtual reality is
too predictable and people will get board no matter how good the simulation."
My take is that our minds are optimized for the analogue and are extremely
senstive to subtle variations in the environment.  These subtle changes are
neccesary to keep us awake and focused on living.  Lacking these subtle
quantum varitions, digital puts us to sleep and makes us lose interest.
It is said that frogs cannot see their prey unless it is moving, humans
can't see the world with their minds unless they are analogue.

I suspect that in our life times, digital will be sufficiently complex to
keep our attention.  That day will come when clock speeds are theoretical
limits, memory storage cannot be measured except by complex physical models,
and processing power is doled out in grams.  And then, once humans have
mucked around so much in virtual reality that no one can remember what they
did and the permutations of effects cannot be predicted, essentially casting
the human spirit into a digital mold, will VR will become livable.


Purple Tiger

ps I only tolerate digital because I've beaten my deep structures into
submission through repeate abuse.

pps Have you ever met people that cannot tolerate CD's and love to listen to
    FM stations on junky clock radios?  I have and i think its because the
    pops, hisses and static let them hear better.

ppps Read Rudy Rucker's "Hacker And The Ants"

>   Take the Moffett Blvd. exit , driving towards the west. After Middlefield
>   Road , don't be in the right hand lane , as it turns off Castro after
>   the train tracks. If you can't find parking on Castro , make a right turn
>   at California , and park behind the restaurant.
> 
>  From the South , on HW 101: Drive past Sunnyvale , past the Ellis Street
>   exit and the Moffett Field exits and take the Moffett Blvd. exit. 
>   Drive west , and follow the same directions as above.
> 
>  From El Camino Real: Drive to Castro Street , turn onto Castro Street
>   towards the bay. You could turn left at California and right onto
>   Bryant to get to the parking lot , or you can try Castro Street 
>   for parking. 
> 
>  See you there!
> 			Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
>  PS - I have a sample menu form this restaurant - they seem to be proud
>   of their vegitarian dishes. And they also have a wide selection of
>   omnivore dishes as well.
> 
> 



From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 12 07:43:07 1994

	id AA04998; Wed, 12 Oct 94 07:42:49 PDT
Date: Wed, 12 Oct 94 07:42:49 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9410121442.AA04998@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com, ptiger@crl.com
Subject: Re: sonic purists! Yow!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Resonate spews:
> > I don't synthesize with anything except analog synthesizers. Argue all you
> > want but purity is purity.

Pure what?  I can assure you that there are sound chunks that I can 
sample digitally that you will have an *extremely* hard time synthesizing.
A spoken phrase of human speech, for example.  

Purple Tiger adds: 
> My take is that our minds are optimized for the analogue and are extremely
> senstive to subtle variations in the environment.  These subtle changes are
> neccesary to keep us awake and focused on living.  Lacking these subtle
> quantum varitions, digital puts us to sleep and makes us lose interest.

Gee, you seemed wide awake that last time I saw you dancing to the
digital beat of a drum machine.  The (near) perfect control offered in
the digital realm allows us to transcend many of limitations imposed on 
us by nature's chaos.  That doesn't make it better, just different and 
therefore one more tool for our use. 

> It is said that frogs cannot see their prey unless it is moving, humans
> can't see the world with their minds unless they are analogue.

The one thing that is cool about being human, is that we can *conceive*
of things that we cannot expereince.  We understand what a perfect
triangle is, yet none exist in nature.  When we trance out to a perfect
beat, we transcend the reality from which we evolved.  I find it sad,
but respect, the choice of most humans to experience existence like a frog.

> I suspect that in our life times, digital will be sufficiently complex to
> keep our attention. 

Complexity for the sake of complexity can be quite boring.  Sometimes
we *want* the simplicity and purity of control that digital offers. 
A musician who says "I only use analogue" is like a painter who says
"I only use pastels".  That is fine for people who only like pastels.

> And then, once humans have
> mucked around so much in virtual reality that no one can remember what they
> did and the permutations of effects cannot be predicted, essentially casting
> the human spirit into a digital mold, will VR will become livable.

Some of the software I write already behaves rather unpredictably, so
I guess we are almost there. :)

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com  (  ( ((Everything Is Possible)) )  )  lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

at them, sort of like how light can act like a particle or a wave depending
on how you look at them.  In fact, not just sort of like.... *exactly like*

Hi All,

Sorry, but I'm not going to get all dreamy in my shorts about the Blue
Angels. After hearing that the Navy spends half a billion dollars a year to
keep these fancy stunt pilots doing aerial nintendo in the sky--pardon me if
I don't ooze patriotic red, white and blue.--I remind you, the Blues Angles
are a Half Billion dollar flying commercial for an all-volunteer army.

Those planes are also flying a 400 to 500 miles per hours over densely
populated areas, as Laura attested to.  And, I don't see those death defying
manuevers as inspiring-It really is a kinda of Russian Roulette in the
sky--which endangers people on the ground, and forces pilots to flirt with
death if they expect to keep their job. 

 I heard there was a smog alert over the weekend, and yet these planes were
allowed to fly..How much fuel do those things burn anyway? Even as a social
make-work program, there are to costly and ineffective.

I guess I'm just disgusted today after I read about the Shell Game the
military is playing with base closings. The article says that 26 bases which
were supposed TO CLOSE, remain open, and anyone who seriously believes that
the government is taking money away from the drug war, to spend on the Blue
Angels, is probably sucking nitrous at the speed of sound.

And.........What all this has to do with Raving, I don't know..
except that the PENTAGON  warlords are STARK RAVIN MAD!!!!
We arm the world, so we can protect ourselves from it. 

Never in the history of mankind, have so few, spent so much, to kill so many.
And never, have we been so unsafe. (see the book, Voltaire's Bastards)

I guess I'm just pissed that people seem to have this Disneyland in the sky
attitude about this. Isn't it nice that the Navy provides these high-tech
fireworks for us, little sonic farts,  while the San Jose library doesn't
have a decent set of encyclopedias, etc.  Hooray for your tax dollars at
work!!!!

(In there here we go again file),  we're set to see Saddam Hussein II on  TV.
WE can go marching on to the next pablum for the people.  Didn't we win that
war anyway? The media told us so.  It wasn't until afterward, that we found
out the truth about "smart bombs," "friendly fire.," and the"scuds." 

Let met apologize before hand for this post-flame explosion. I realize that I
am still furious about the Vietnam war. I didn't like being a political
pariah then, and I don't like being conned today.  Nothing personal.

                                                   Peace & Respect

                                                   robertj..monterey
                                                   Ex-Home of Ft. Ord-
                                                   New Home to Military
Accounting Offices

Greetings from Sunset!

I want to thank everyone who came out to the Presidio on Sunday, you all 
made the experience sweet even though it was short.  Thanks to you, the 
family vibe was with us again despite our difficulties with the generator 
and the park authorities (rangers, park police, and military police).  
Also, everyone was very cooperative in making the alcohol scarce and in 
cleaning up the trash.  Thank you all!

I would like to take a minute to thank the authorities for being so 
cooperative with us, both in the Presidio and in the Marina.  In both 
locations we were allowed to continue our party without permits, and were 
given information on obtaining permits.  These people have shown us their 
enlightened judgement and have bent the rules to accomodate us.  They 
deserve our respect, cooperation, and praise.  On the behalf of all of 
us, I thank them.  Our experiences with them have inspired me with hope 
and optimism for our society and I urge everybody not to stereotype them 
into the "pig" category.  Also, I think it's important to remember that 
they have to do their job as it is mandated to them whether they like it 
or not.  We have to make sure not to push their flexibility by being too 
obvious about other activities.  As to undercover police, which are 
around from time to time, I hope that they enjoy their assignment at our 
parties and report back favorably (and dance lots too!).  Our party is 
for everybody to enjoy!

This weekend, the Sunset crew is going camping at the Russian River for 
the Tribal Future party.  We are bringing our sound system and DJs out to 
have an new-fashioned ho-down and nature lurk.  Come ready to dance and 
swim and bring camping stuff.  For more info call (415)750-9452.  Hope to 
see you all there, we'll have a blast!

Thanks and lots of love, Lorien (helagon@well.com)

From sfraves-owner  Wed Oct 12 16:56:09 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA00365; Wed, 12 Oct 1994 16:56:09 -0700

From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9410122354.AA07530@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: sonic pursuits! Yow!
In-Reply-To: <199410120754.AAA27111@holonet.net>
References: <199410120754.AAA27111@holonet.net>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Those that think analog can do anything that digital can't need to
chug on down to their local university and read up on audio theory.

Digital can perfectly emulate anything our ears can hear. Whether or
not it is _done_ depends on the quality of equipment involved, and on
the skill of the human doing the programming.

As marginal sampling rates, poor DAC, bad mastering, and a plethora of
other sloppiness have shown us, it usually isn't done. But it can be.
It's much like the situation with digital movie effects. Yeah, you can
tell the difference between the real thing and the special effects,
but every year it gets closer and closer. And once in a while, they
make you believe. I consider it a good thing. The more it makes
possible, the more there is to enjoy.

Bashing "digital" is as silly as bashing "analog". Personally, I think
most of both sucks. One needs to take it case by case.

Sean

To: Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>
cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <9410122354.AA07530@pilot.njin.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9410121720.O20034-0100000@taz.hyperreal.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

On Wed, 12 Oct 1994, Sean Casey wrote:
> Those that think analog can do anything that digital can't need to
> chug on down to their local university and read up on audio theory.

I don't think that was the argument at all, if I've been following 
anything.  You are correct in saying that CD-quality digital music can 
*recreate* any sound humans can hear, but the debate it seems has been 
over the *synthesis* of sound.  Think of speech - it's totally possible 
to record a human voice on CD and play it back later without any 
difference, but I haven't yet seen or heard of a speech machine that 
could convert text to human speech so perfectly it was impossible to tell 
the difference between that and a real person.  Not yet, at any rate :)

Can we end this conversation now?  Thanks.

	Brian

This is the rave being put on by Father Matthew Fox, an excommunicated Dominican (?) priest, who I was asking about a couple of weeks ago. There was an article about the guy and his perspective in SF Focus, August (?) issue. Seems like an interesting bloke, working with some dudes from England to establish what they call rave mass, using the community vibe of raves to create a new sort of 'church'. There's a heavy technology bent, and they'll have lots of monitors set up w/ talking heads spouting the Word. It doesn't sound especially reverent or somber, sort of taking more of a Creation Spirituality angle.

DEFINITELY go dressed as a nun, my friend! You will be the life o' the partee...

If I were going, I think I'd dress as a pagan.

jaXun

No, this is not another analog/digital synthesizer post.

This is a gentle reminder to everyone that this is a virtual 
community, and many times the quality of life in this community
is defined by a high SIGNAL to NOISE ratio.

I know that rave is connected to a lot of things that are happening
in the world right now, and it is interesting to talk about.  But, 
with 900 people subscribed, I think we need a little more focus.
I try and move my discussions that are not directly rave-house 
related to e-mail.  It's faster and more like a person-to-person
conversation.  

[Add Flame Deterrent Here:]

It's just my $.02

-troy

Brian Behlendorf writes:
>On Wed, 12 Oct 1994, Sean Casey wrote:
>over the *synthesis* of sound.  Think of speech - it's totally possible 
>to record a human voice on CD and play it back later without any 
>difference, but I haven't yet seen or heard of a speech machine that 
>could convert text to human speech so perfectly it was impossible to tell 
>the difference between that and a real person.  Not yet, at any rate :)

I can't resist pointing out that (non-sampling) speech synthesizers
use the same technology as analog synths (oscillators, filters, etc). I
agree that they don't sound like real voices anymore than analog
synths sound like "real" instruments.

>Can we end this conversation now?  Thanks.

I agree. It's degenerating into a religious war.

Well folks, I have been on the sfraves list for about a month and I am just
about convinced that there is no better vibe in the country than what you
guys have got.  I am stuck here in TX, freshly graduated from college in May.
Needless to say, the rave scene here is...well, not what your's is.  And the
social vibe is all but snuffed by arrogant Texans.  How 'bout them Cowboys?
Anyway, I must leave this God-forsaken place soon and am weighing my options.
By trade I am a radio producer and DJ.  Finding work in this field is tough,
even if you're really talented.  (I've won several broadcasting awards.) I
am also a techno artist, and I feel my stuff is pretty slammin.  I want to 
find an environment where I can work professionally and still have an outlet
for my music.  SF is a big market and probably *really* hard to find a job in
radio, so I'm willing to look for other work if need be.  I don't know a soul
in SF, and I don't have the guts to come out with no job lined up and no 
place to stay and hope to survive.  I graduated cum laude (3.6 gpa) and I
am technically minded and brighter than most Texans.  I also have digital
multitrack recording experience in both radio and the music industry. (Music
was my major in college.)  I know this a long shot, but you all seem so
genuinely nice I figured it was worth a try:
Is anyone in a position to help me find a job out there?  It doesn't matter
what area it's in, as long as I can make enough to get by.  I was hoping
that maybe someone on this list owns their own company and needs help.  Say
for example you own a small software company, I can compose music and design
sound effects for your software.  OR WHATEVER!!!  I'm in a very unhealthy
environment here and I need to leave within a couple weeks.  (Well, I'd like
to anyway, for reasons to complicated to list here.)  I hope that there's 
someone there who can help.  I can send resumes and references if you want em.
Thanks in advance.  I'm crossing my fingers that the right person reads this.

-Jonathan

Michael Wertheim said:

> to emulate acoustic instruments through physical modelling.  I was posing a
> similar solution of modelling a 303 in the same way.  Actually, I wonder if
> the VL1's architecture could be used to emulate the 303.  Hmmm...

Well, since i know absolutely nothing aobut synthesizers...

The dude who was showing off the VL1 as this thing i went said that
it's basic concept was that you programmed in things like
length, diameter and stuff like that of wind instruments
and it would emulate them

You can do tons of impossible things like a 1 km long, 1 cm diameter
flute, or, of course, a 1 cm long, 1 km in diameter one too..
(well i dont know aobut that.. but you get the point)
although there are quite a few other options to play with,

i wonder what type of physical dimensions would be in a instrument
that would make it play like a 303?
(not like i can remember what a 303 sounds like with the pitch at 0 :)



 ,
dana

"Do you remember that part of the song, the one with that crackling sound?
 It's just Not Right that someone can do that to me."

don't ferget that EVERY purchase you make, for blo-pops or sugar pops,
  goes into a VERY large chain of suppliers, vendors, etc., and that
    implicitly you are keeping their beliefs/politics/etc going;

a classic example is Mitsubishi, who clearcuts forests like there's
  no tomorrow;  buying one of their shiny cars is indirectly supporting
    those activities....

if you're really serious about not imbibing anything whose source is bad,
  yer not gonna buy ANYTHING; that's the truth, cause (nearly) everything
   you see on a store shelf has SOMEONE's doodoo innit.

back to da raves...

Precedence: bulk


Matthew Fox is now in the Episcopal Church. Though I'm  not exactly 
sure of the details of his departure from the Catholic Church it was not 
a friendly parting of ways.

The rave mass is being produced by an alternative community from 
Sheffield, Enlgand who have  been prodcuing "sacred rituals" for  17 yrs 
which incorporate new media, ecological awareness and personal & 
communalexperience of mystical spirituality. The group is seeking to 
forge alliances with kindredd d spirits and open a dialogue for exploring 
grass roots solutions to some of our most pressing social & ecological 
problems.

I will be giving a talk with Matt next week on raves at his Institute In 
Culture & Creation Spirituality in Oakland. I will report back with 
relevant info.

If you are interested in knowing more about Matt Fox's ideas I recommend 
his new book _The Reinvetion of Work_ (Harper SF, 1994)) Should  be in 
some public libraries and local bookstores. Though I am aware that it is 
somewhat difficult to overcome the aversion to certain connections to 
mainstream religion Matt is very revolutionary and has worked for over 
20yrs for social justice and ecolocial spiritual  transformation.

Ronan

Hey gang!

Been surfing the list now for a few months, getting a good idea about 
what the vibe's like, and waitin' for the perfect opportunity/event to 
take the ravin' plunge. Well, its HERE!

Tribal Reunion sounded like such an excellent event all the way around, I 
decided I'd drop all plans to attend. Fortunately, nothing came up to 
foil my plans, and now I have a chance to meet all you bee-yooteeful 
people up in Healdsburg this weekend. It's gonna be SUCH a trip! Camping, 
drumming, honoring our Mother, connecting in the fine outdoors in what 
looks to be PERFECT weather...makes me wanna drive up there right NOW!

Pant, pant. Anyway, I hope to meet LOTS of you fine SFRavers this 
weekend. I'll be the big boy in the sky-blue bandana with the dreamy look 
in his eyes. Freek me out! Walk up and say HI JAxUN!!!
