This was sent to me as a forward from someone -- I have not seen it on 
the list, so I'm just hoping that it wasn't posted all over and I just 
missed it.

PLEASE read this -- anyone concerned with helping the parties go more 
smoothly (with less harassment from Mr. Ossifer) should know the basic 
rules about what cops can and cannot legally do. Who knows? Maybe the 
next time the cops come to your favorite party, *you* might have to answer 
the door!
   
Maui


Grady Ward (grady@netcom.com) wrote:
: Rule #1: When the FBI comes for a visit:
:  a) Do not let them into your house or apartment;
:  b) Do not talk to them without your attorney present.

: Like most police, their job is to put you into a Federal
: Pen, not to exculpate you. They will lie to get you to 
: start talking.

: If they have a subpoena, fine, they can serve it to you.
: BUT DO NOT TALK TO THEM WITHOUT AN ATTORNEY.

From: ROBERT ALPERT
Subj: DON'T TALK TO COPS       
Read: (N/A)                         Status: PUBLIC MESSAGE (Echo)
Conf: Legal (213)                Read Type: GENERAL

The following article is from a leaflet that has been distributed by the
Libertarian Party in New Jersey.  Written by an attorney, it deals with
the subject of talking to police or other government agents.

    *************************************************************
                     **** DON'T TALK TO COPS ****
    *************************************************************

    By ROBERT W. ZEUNER, Member of the New York State Bar

    "GOOD MORNING! My name is investigator Holmes. Do you mind
answering a few simple questions?" If you open your door one day and
are greeted with those words, stop and think! Whether it is the local
police or the FBI at your door, you have certain legal rights of which
you ought to be aware before you proceed any further.

    In the first place, when the law enforcement authorities come to see
you, there are no "simple questions." Unless they are investigating a
traffic accident, you can be sure that they want information about
somebody. And that somebody may be you!

    Rule Number one to remember when confronted by the authorities is
that there is no law require you to talk with the police, the FBI,
or the representative of any other investigative agency. Even the
simplest questions may be loaded and the seemingly harmless bits of
information which you volunteer may later become vital links in a chain
of circumstantial evidence against you or a friend.

    Do not invite the investigator into your home! Such an invitation not
only gives him the opportunity to look around for clues to your
lifestyle, friends, reading material, etc., but also tends to prolong
the conversation. And the longer the conversation, the more chance
there is for a skilled investigator to find out what he wants to know.

    Many times a police officer will ask you to accompany him to the
police station to answer a few questions. In that case, simply thank
him for the invitation and indicate that you are not disposed to accept
it at that time. Often the authorities simply want to photograph a
person for identification purposes, a procedure which is easily
accomplished by placing him in a private room with a two-way
mirror at the station, asking him a few innocent questions, and
then releasing him.

    If the investigator becomes angry at your failure to cooperate
and threatens you with arrest, stand firm. He cannot legally place
you under arrest or enter your home without a warrant signed by a
judge. If he indicates that he has such a warrant, ask to see it.
A person under arrest or located on premises to be searched, generally
must be shown a warrant if he requests it and must be given a chance
to read it.

    Without a warrant, an officer depends solely upon your helpfulness
to obtain the information he wants. So, unless you are quite sure of
yourself, don't be helpful.

    Probably the wisest approach to take to a persistent investigator is
simply to say: "I'm quite busy now. If you have any questions that you
feel I can answer, I'd be happy to listen to them in my lawyer's
office. Goodbye!" Talk is cheap. But when that talk involves the
law enforcement authorities, it may cost you, or someone close to you,
dearly.

P.S.    "This leaflet has been printed as a public service
         by individuals concerned with the growing role
         of authoritarianism and police power in our society.
         Please feel free to copy or republish."

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Sat, 23 Jul 1994 01:11:12 -0700 (PDT)
From: Maui-Your Sister's House <ysh@netcom.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Rave Mass

I am going to re-post a short excerpt from an interview with a defrocked 
priest who is taking a different, more constructive approach to religion 
& spirituality than the Catholic church.

(the following has been excerpted, without permission, from San Francisco 
Focus magazine's interview with Fr. Matthew Fox)

SFFocus: Is there room in the Episcopal Church for your kind of spirituality?

Fox: I think so. I'll give you an example-- it's the main thing that's 
drawing me there. Last August, I had just finished writing "The 
Reinvention of Work'. The last chapter was on ritual, how we need rituals 
to create community support. We were doing a summer program in Seattle, 
and four people flew in from Sheffield, England. The oldest was a 33 year 
old Anglican priest, and their story was they have a community there of 
200 people, in their 20's reinventing the form of the Mass. The result is 
they have some 500 or so people coming to this Mass; average age 27. This 
is mind-blowing-- it's a miracle. There probably aren't 7 people in their 
20's going to church anywhere else in England on Sunday. These are 
blue-collar people. Sheffield is the Youngstown, Ohio of England, the 
birthplace of the Industrial Revolution, and it's in a total depression 
now. These young people come out of abusive situations-- economic, 
political, drugs, alcohol, all of it. They're plugged into the Rave 
culture there, and in the Mass they use Rave music and dancing and media.

SFFocus: Did you get an opportunity to see it firsthand?

Fox: I went over in November to experience it. It's held in the basement 
of a sports complex, a round room, and they have 42 television sets, 12 
videos, and projections all over the walls: galaxies dancing, to atoms, 
DNA, and so forth. The altar is a big, round white table with projections 
on it from above, colors and forms that change throughout the service, 
and they create the videos every other week for the Mass. There's also 
live television happening during the Mass, but the reading of the 
Scripture is on all the television sets and video screens simultaneously. 
   
The first response I had was that this is a very friendly experience for 
a generation raised on television. The second response I had was that 
these people are taking television away from the broadcasters. They're 
doing it live. Where? At the heart of a community. That's why it was so 
interesting and powerful. And yet it is the Mass-- you can recognize the 
form of the Mass within it.

I came back and talked with Bishop Swing in San Francisco, and we're 
planning such a Rave Mass in the basement of Grace Cathedral in October. The 
Sheffield Community is going to send ten people over, their best artists 
and techno artists, for a 2 year commitment to get the community going 
here in America, here in the Bay Area.

SFFocus: So this will be ongoing?

Fox: Yes. Eventually, we hope to coordinate the Mass with a conference 
for Silicon Valley on spirituality and TechnoArt. Technology is promising 
us 500 video channels and an information superhighway. But is that 
highway going to take us faster and deeper into the hell of consumerism, 
or can the new technology being born right here lead us to the next level 
of human evolution, which has to have something to do with spirituality? 
That's the challenge we want to give to Silicon Valley.

We don't care what people think raves are generally, but when you're 
trying to put on a good party *and* having to deal with drunk kids that 
have no sense (and are _very obviously_ looking for drugs) it tends to 
sour the mood a bit. Indiscretion on the part of minors at your party can 
get you *busted*.

And where do they get the idea that _that_ behavior is what a rave is 
about? Mass media -- CNN. Newspapers. Time Magazine. Etc. etc. etc.

> last week or so :)

loud. All this after I got all GIDDY about how COOL everything was gonna 
be (including the weather). 

Dang.

jaXun

To: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Cc: resonate <resonate@netcom.com>, Brian Behlendorf <brian@hyperreal.com>,
        Sean Casey <csc@pilot.njin.net>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: sonic pursuits! Yow! 
In-reply-to: Your message of "Fri, 14 Oct 94 05:13:43 PDT."
             <Pine.3.89.9410140515.A9415-0100000@netcom11> 
Date: Fri, 14 Oct 94 10:36:34 -0700
From: "Niels P. Mayer" <mayer@netcom.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

> There are a few companies out there producing guitar amps that purport to 
> digitally reproduce the warmer sounds a tube amp produces. Any data on these?

It really shouldn't be that hard to provide a digital approximation to
the "idealized" transfer function provided by a vacuum tube or FET
transistor. The basics of it is that these devices, when overdriven,
produce even harmonic distortion (there's a power of 2 in the txfer
function) whereas a transistor, when driven to distortion, has both
even and odd frequency components (there's a power of 3/2 in the txfer
function). Granted real vacuum tubes and real FET's don't have an
idealized txfer function, but the "warmth" characteristics people
perceive are simply caused by the even versus odd fourier components.
Nothing magical here -- every scientist enjoys reducing joy and
pleasure to formulas and computation!

It's been a long time since I did the fourier analysis of the
distortion characteristics of a tube, transistor, and FET so I may be a
bit confused on the txfer function characteristics mentioned above). It
was pretty fun intellectual masturbation in an otherwise heinously
boring electrical engineering upper level class. Geez -- all those
all-nighters of nasty electrical engineering problem sets in school
(while all my friends were out partying and getting laid! :-)) just so
I could quack about this BS on sfraves! (I probably can't even remember
how to do a double integral anymore -- 8 years of software engineering
tends to rot the mind, ya know!)

Yours in geekdom,
	Niels.

PS: w/r/t the "everything can be emulated by digital" -- this may be
true for already synthetic instruments recording straight into a mixing
board, but for capturing the  spatial information in a live recording,
44.1Khz 16 bit stereo absolutely butchers any high-frequencey
phase/timing information that helps us spatially locate different
instruments. Perhaps sampling at 100Khz might preserve some of this
information. Note that in high-end studios, you can occasionally find
systems that digitize at much higher sampling rates than 44.1K (CD) or
48K (DAT). Yes, I know all about Nyquist's Theorem -- but that just
has to do with frequency domain, and doesn't model human perceptual
understanding of sound and spatial location, which has components
of timing (time differences between sounds hitting your L/R ears,
phase, and amplitude between L/R ears).

>shit, so perhaps it will be ok.

The situation is this:  Yes, there will be a party at Stanford.  With a
couple of excellent DJs as well.  (One of the Wicked DJs will headline).
The problem is that this party is a private Stanford party, and only people
who have Stanford ID's, or friends of the Chi Theta Chi house will be
allowed to enter.  The reason why this is so exclusive is because of
various liability reasons; it is a University residence and therefore they
are legally bound to restrict entry to non-campus partygoers.

(type 'u' in place of the 'v' - i've taken out the 'u' so this message
 passes thru majordomo's filter)

this weekend, and I'm really excited.  I haven't left Berkeley in far too

hugs.  I'll be wearing my fishing hat with a smiley face patch on it, if 
I'm not running around naked or something, and playing some extremely deep 
house at some point.

according to some contest somewhere.  Hope I make it to this.  House DJs 
do some amazing shit, but no one mixes like hip hop.  Ultimate cut and 
paste... oh boy... (21+, $16 at the door, $14 pre-sale at BPO and Zebra

From: "'Dave Bayer'" <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Re: (Fwd) What is a rave ? 
To: SFRaves! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9410140541.A9415-0100000@netcom11>

Precedence: bulk



On Fri, 14 Oct 1994, Maui expounded:

> We don't care what people think raves are generally, but when you're 
> trying to put on a good party *and* having to deal with drunk kids that 
> have no sense (and are _very obviously_ looking for drugs) it tends to 
> sour the mood a bit. Indiscretion on the part of minors at your party can 
> get you *busted*.

	Furthermore, if raves have an evil image, god-damn youngsters 
going around and taking god knows what drugs, and having sex with god 
knows how many people, to that awful noise that just does the same thing 
over and over and over..., they are more likely to broken up on 
compliants. The general public has this thing of not wanting 'evil' 
things in their neighborhood. So the worse th image that the masses 
associate with loud techno coming over the hills, the more likely the 
cops will be called, and thus, the more likely the party will end. 
Granted the attitudes and atmosphere at parties may be counter to many of 
those accepted attitudes that dominate the minds of our neighbors in 
grand old country, and maybe they have reason to want to put an end to 
parties before their attitudes are called into question and -oh no- those 
attitudes might change a bit.... But why should we help them shut our 
gatherings down. Yet, I guess following my train of argument, one might 
think I was for putting up a false image of what a 'rave' might be, which 
I am not in favour of.... (hmmm, what is an image of a 'real' rave I 
wonder?) 

dave

Here it is again:)



Fingers, Inc "Can You Feel It"  accapella on Trax records 12"

                *** Jack's House ***

In the beginning, there was Jack, and Jack had a groove.
  And from this groove came the grooves of all grooves.
   And while one day viciously throwing down on his box,
Jack boldy declared, "Let there be HOUSE!" and house music was born.
"I am, you see, I AM THE CREATOR!, and this is my house."
 "And, in my house there is ONLY house music."
"But, I am not so selfish because once you enter my house it then
   becomes OUR house, and OUR house music."
And, you see, no one man owns house, because house music
        is a universal language, spoken and understood by all.
You see, house is a feeling that no one can understand really
  unless you're deep into the vibe of house.
House is an uncontrolable desire to jack your body.
        And, as I told you before, this is our house and our house music.
And in every house, you understand, there is a keeper.
                        And in this house, the keeper is Jack.
Now some of you who might wonder, who is Jack and what is it that Jack does?
Jack is the one who gives you the power to jack your body.
Jack is the one who gives you the power to do the snake.
Jack is the one who gives you the key to the wiggly worm.
Jack is the one who learns you how to walk your body.
Jack is the one that can bring nations and nations of all
        Jackers together under one house.
You may be black, you may be white, you may be Jew or Gentile.
It don't make a difference in OUR House.
                                          And this is fresh.




--mike

To: SFRaves! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: (Fwd) What is a rave ? 
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>	Furthermore, if raves have an evil image, god-damn youngsters 

>going around and taking god knows what drugs, and having sex with 

>god knows how many people, to that awful noise that just does the 

>same thing over and over and over..., they are more likely to broken 

>up on compliants. The general public has this thing of not wanting 

>'evil' things in their neighborhood.

Ya know, this reminds me of something.  Only a couple of hundred  
years ago, witches were burned at the stake for ritualistically  
dancing around a fire in the nude, among other "evil" and "wicked"  
things.  This seems to be true of every movement which displays  
greater freedom of consciousness and expression.

I have this feeling that this will *always* be the case, for as long  
as there are people in the world who are so afraid of expressing  
themselves that they cannot allow others that freedom.  I'm afraid  
that as long as the rave movement continues, we should expect  
witchhunts.

ALPHONSE KARR 1808P1890
Plus cKa change, plus c'est la meCme chose.
The more things change, the more they are the same.
Les GueCpes, Jan. 1849. vi

		Wonko the Sane

> On Fri, 14 Oct 1994, Maui expounded:
> 
> > We don't care what people think raves are generally, but when you're 
> > trying to put on a good party *and* having to deal with drunk kids that 
> > have no sense (and are _very obviously_ looking for drugs) it tends to 
> > sour the mood a bit. Indiscretion on the part of minors at your party can 
> > get you *busted*.
> 
> 	Furthermore, if raves have an evil image, god-damn youngsters 
> going around and taking god knows what drugs, and having sex with god 
> knows how many people, to that awful noise that just does the same thing 
> over and over and over..., they are more likely to broken up on 
> compliants. The general public has this thing of not wanting 'evil' 
> things in their neighborhood. So the worse th image that the masses 
> associate with loud techno coming over the hills, the more likely the 
> cops will be called, and thus, the more likely the party will end. 
> Granted the attitudes and atmosphere at parties may be counter to many of 
> those accepted attitudes that dominate the minds of our neighbors in 
> grand old country, and maybe they have reason to want to put an end to 
> parties before their attitudes are called into question and -oh no- those 
> attitudes might change a bit.... But why should we help them shut our 
> gatherings down. Yet, I guess following my train of argument, one might 
> think I was for putting up a false image of what a 'rave' might be, which 
> I am not in favour of.... (hmmm, what is an image of a 'real' rave I 
> wonder?) 
> 
> dave

Well to me, raves are natural anti-depressants.  Yes I go to raves
because:

	the music is happy
	the music gives me a natural high	
	I want a reason to eat lots of pixie stix, eat charms blue
		razzberry blowpops and dance all night
	I like the people
	The people are friendly and loving and caring and happy

jsrffd2@ubd1.vdospk.com





From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 16 18:41:13 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id SAA19853; Sun, 16 Oct 1994 18:41:13 -0700
Received: from bethe.ucdavis.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id SAA19844; Sun, 16 Oct 1994 18:41:08 -0700
Received: by bethe.ucdavis.edu (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA26841; Sun, 16 Oct 94 18:41:06 PDT
Date: Sun, 16 Oct 94 18:41:06 PDT
From: alves@bethe.ucdavis.edu (David Alves)

acid house break-in 
get on
ride

truck go horse lift move launch
(mo' land fisher shake)

I went by Go Figure around 1:00.  It was in a large
apartment in the Mission.  Ambient patio and two other 
rooms.  40 or so people.  The music was shut down about
15 minutes after I got there ;(

Committed at this point I found a phone.
Parking was very easy and in a nice area.
I was a little early - the lights were on and final
preparations were being made.  I inquired about a bathroom and
one fellow told me to 'piss anywhere' in contradiction to a
sign put out later asking us to 'respect the property'.  My 
impression was that this guy was somehow affiliated with the
warehouse and not directly one of the party hosts.  I could
be mistaken ...

An Intimate Lounge connecting small offices to two large 
loading bays was absolutely Filled Solid by these stacks of
community speakers.  I was impressed with the sound.
It was flawless.  

During the setup period the music was Sick.
Soon they killed the overhead lights - kicked on a few 
flashy spinning colored lights - and started up the music 
again with some lighter funky house.  People started to arrive 
around 3:00.  The music built up a head of Steam quickly. 
Furious dirty acid has this sometimes not so subtle but very
emotional hook - imagine some Cosmic Bad Ass screaming -
"All aboard you Twisted Motherfuckers!!!!! "
You know enough midnight space language to Obey.   
You can't actually see the train but you have a sense 
of its total mass and cruising speed.
Without a doubt, you are On it.
Bust out the leathers, Coal furnace, Shovel the blackened
obscene God Damn shit onto my Head in this piss anywhere warehouse.
Let me tell ya girl, 
I like it.

I don't know who threw the party or who spun.
I only heard the first dj.  He was good.
I danced enthusiastically until I left.  
Groups of people were still arriving.

A million thanks to Mr White for his post!
Dave

hey, regarding the digital/analog discussion; KEEP IT UP!

 i'm a synth freak meself, and this is a great education just sitting
   here lurking...

 btw, even tho i'm a digital'ist thru-and-thru (i program lotsa platforms)
   i still gotta speak up for analog on one VERY important count:

   and that is CHAOS.

  yup, the forces of chaos are what keep the world going round; order
   just sorta emerges from the random alignment and synchronicity of
    erstwhile chaotic events... 

  what's that gotta do w/ synths? simple. if you want the truly chaotic
    sound, one which is utterly unpredictable, you've gotta go with analog
      components in at least part of yer waveform generation, because in
       most cases, digital can get repetitive at the micro-level...
  meanwhile, a humble transistor with it's middle pin cut can make a whole
    hellbroth of chaotic noise which even the best gaussian noise algorithms
      nary can touch...

(even less that .02 bux worth of opining...)

seeya!

Dave Scruton

I had some thoughts that didn't fit in with my
choo choo train review.  I decided to put them here.

What I wonder is how much repect does anyone show a
bit of property when throwing a renegade party?

At the very least, the party on friday happened
without some of the proper permits.  In the worst
scenario everyone there totally violated someone else's
property and space.  

For what reason?  
Because we really need to dance in different places?
Because the party was free?

I enjoyed dancing there.  It was fun.
But I have mixed feelings about how I treated
other people.  People I don't know.  Just to
go to a fun party.  

I think that I like a party where all the shit
is together.  Including a place in society and
respecting it.  It does not add any thrill for me
to be at a renegade as opposed to a club (or a park).  
Permits are not inherently bad.

Seeya
Dave

> 	the music gives me a natural high	
> 	I want a reason to eat lots of pixie stix, eat charms blue

This sort of capsulizes the Tribal Phuture party at the Russian River
this weekend.  Good Music, Good friendly people, no somkey clubs,
no ass-hole security, no bar, no cops, just the river, music,canoes, the Moon.
stars, music, sunshine, fire, wind, food, music, sacrements, swimming,
talking, music, loving, caring, cleaning up the earth and some great music
by a lot of wonderful DJs who are rarely heard.  Many,many thanks to
the Ameba crew, the Mother Earth Sound system crew, Galen and the Pacific Crew,
Bryce, Al and Tracy, The Bus, Jason, Garth and the Chief for making this all
happen so wonderfully.


DJs to look out for:
	There were some excellent DJs that I have rarely or never heard
	that were absolutely wonderful:

		ELF - didn't he spin at the first sfraves picnic three years
		      ago?

		SOLAR - Really neat new stuff/ and some old :)

		TRACY - Get it girl!
			Tracy is clearly my favorite DJ right now. In my opinion
			she has what it takes to become a world class DJ.
			It's not the quality of her technique (which is good
			and can only improve) but she knows what record to play
			next AND she has a sensitiveity to the music that only
			comes from having journeyed to those realms by way of 
			the dance floor. Plus she's a capricorn which is always
			a good sign :)

		GALEN - As long as there are beings like Galen on this planet
			and in the Scene, there is still hope for us all.
			Galen has put a lot of hard work and effort into what
			he does and it is paying off not only for himself but
			for the whold group, (just imagine what it would be like
			if just 10% of the world could do this).  He is a
			prime example of what new energy in the Scene can
			accomplish. And definitely has made it to the upper
			ranks of what it means to be a DJ.

> On Fri, 14 Oct 1994, Maui expounded:
> 
> > We don't care what people think raves are generally, but when you're 
> > trying to put on a good party *and* having to deal with drunk kids that 
> > have no sense (and are _very obviously_ looking for drugs) it tends to 
> > sour the mood a bit. Indiscretion on the part of minors at your party can 
> > get you *busted*.
> 
> 	Furthermore, if raves have an evil image, god-damn youngsters 
> going around and taking god knows what drugs, and having sex with god 
> knows how many people, to that awful noise that just does the same thing 
> over and over and over..., they are more likely to broken up on 
> compliants. The general public has this thing of not wanting 'evil' 
> things in their neighborhood. So the worse th image that the masses 
> associate with loud techno coming over the hills, the more likely the 
> cops will be called, and thus, the more likely the party will end. 
> Granted the attitudes and atmosphere at parties may be counter to many of 
> those accepted attitudes that dominate the minds of our neighbors in 
> grand old country, and maybe they have reason to want to put an end to 
> parties before their attitudes are called into question and -oh no- those 
> attitudes might change a bit.... But why should we help them shut our 
> gatherings down. Yet, I guess following my train of argument, one might 
> think I was for putting up a false image of what a 'rave' might be, which 
> I am not in favour of.... (hmmm, what is an image of a 'real' rave I 
> wonder?) 

> dave

Basically, if I may so state, people have been taught that they are right 
to fear what they don't know or understand. Therefore their first instinct 
when confronted with something that is unknowable without investigation, 
such as a rave, is to call the "law" in to have it terminated with 
extreme prejudice. <sp?>

As far as putting up an "image" of what "raves" are -- can't be done. 
There are too many people involved, for one thing, and for another, you'd 
have to be the worst kind of Nazi to attempt it. Take a lesson from the 
gay community -- here we are arguing fiercely whether or not the "Year of 
the Queer" is appropriate as a theme; meanwhile lesbians, gay men, and 
transgendered folks are getting murdered in cold blood. 

Ravers are not ever going to win acceptance from the world at large, 
because our M.O. is totally at sixes and sevens with it. However, we 
should not let this discourage us... we don't need social sanction to see 
each other for the loving beautiful people that we are, and we don't need 
it to spread that love to those around us. So I say, rave on, my 
lovelies, and I'll be there with you... anyone we can bring along for 
this best of rides is more than welcome.


Maui



From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 17 14:50:35 1994

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Tribal Phuture party at the Russian River
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

A report on Tribal Phuture party at the Russian River
=====================================================

   For those folks that missed a wonderful party,   all I can say,  is that you
missed a really wondeful time.     I got up there in the late afternoon,   
discovered that it was at the same campground as the Groove Kitchen a few
months back.    When I arrived,  they were just getting the sound system set
up,   and the first clean-up work party was just about to get started.    So
we grabbed our trash bags and started the Russian River clean up project.   This
earned me free addmission,  and food,  and we certainly made a "dent" in the
amount of trash and refuse around the river.

   When we finished,   the music had already started,   and after a big hearty
dinner,   I wasted no time in dancing to the funkey grooves.    The weather was
perfect for dancing,   and as usual,  Garth twisted my brain with his usually
high variaty of trance and funk.    Although we couldn't keep the music going
all night,    I made up for it by dancing almost all the time,  with little
or no breaks.    Eventually,   11 pm came around much too early,   so the 
dancing had to come to a stop.    

   Along the river bank,  they set up an Ambient system,   going all night long,
and people were sitting by the fire,  trying to keep warm in the cool crisp
evening.   I tried to crash,   but couldn't manage that,   so I just huddled
in my speeping bag,  watching the shooting stars all night long.

   The next day,  we were treated with a very efficient grill,   cranking out
pancakes for all who were hungry.    Eventually,  the music started again,  and
the dancing commenced.    It took me a while to warm my body up,  as I'm used to
dancing all night with no breaks,   but it didn't take long before I got into 
the groove as Tracey spun one of the best sets I've heard in a long time.   She
played some really old classics I haven't heard in a while,   and mixed them up
with some newer tracey stuff.    Jeno eventually came on,   but shortly after that,
someone complained about the noise,   but it was worked out that we could still
go,  but at a lower volume,  so people just migrated closer to the speakers,
and the grove picked up again.

   It was said that the music was to continue until 11 pm,  but that wasn't quite
so.    The music eventually stopped around 9 - 9:30 or so,   but everyone had a very
good time.     I would estimate about 80 - 100 people showed up.    I stayed there
overnight,  and helped with the clean up crew....   Had long talk with the owners,
who invited us to come back a a few months and have another rave.     But this time,
they will try and work it out with the neighbors and allow us to keep the music
on till much later....   We left with the campground all cleaned up,   and the last
crew tended to the canoes,  put them all away,   and we left and headed home.

   All in all,  these camp/rave events are so GREAT!!   No stuffy smoke filled
clubs,   no faschist security goons,   just a lot of happy smiling raver folks
having a good time,  out in the wilderness with nature.

   Hats off for Mark at Ameba for putting on this fine party,   as I'm sure going
to look forward for more in the future...

CC

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 17 15:20:43 1994

Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id PAA18981; Mon, 17 Oct 1994 15:20:43 -0700

Received: from DialupEudora by netcom18.netcom.com (8.6.9/Netcom)
	id PAA11543; Mon, 17 Oct 1994 15:11:33 -0700
Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 15:11:33 -0700
X-Sender: ambient@localhost
Message-Id: <aac8417c00015006b454@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ambient@netcom.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: Tribal Future
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Sort of recovered now from the Russian River party. (Discovered that 3
hours sleep on a picnic table just ain't enough =) )

This was the sort of party where you ended up meeting all kinds of people
because everyone seemed to know someone that you also knew. It was a
diverse yet connected group of about 200 or so enjoying the beauty of
nature, the music, and each other.

I got there at about 3:30 on Saturday when we set up the main system and
Whitsett (I think) started the music, which went until about 11pm in the
campground. I didn't get to hear many of the sets, but I liked what I heard
from Elf and much of what I heard from Garth.

There was ambient down on the beach all night, although many of the
attendees retreated to their tents. I thought Tobias in particular played a
good set and Bryce picked things up in the morning with some chunky tunes.

The main system got going in the afternoon again with a good deep set by
Jake. Solar played some great acid and Tracy rocked it, getting everybody
jumping. Galen closed out the night with a beautiful set and it was time to
clean up and go home.

Thanks much to the Amebas and Bryce and Galen and Alexander Valley
Campground for putting this all together. It was what all parties should
be. Hopefully there will be another next year, perhaps with a bluegrass
stage as well. =)

Joe


 (Joe Rice)---------------------------------------( welcome to the church)
(tic-tac@ultima.org)-----(ambient@netcom.com)-----(of what's happening now)

If I may be so bold, even a re-re-re-request for something is not such
a big bother.  If we're all here to help each other out, it seems like
a small price pay to read these kinds of requests occasionally.

*Especially* for something as historically notable as 'Jack's House',
which keeps showing up in samples on new tracks even now, because it
has something important and enduring to say about our scene, and because
the sound of that voice is so inextricably tied up with the entire 
history of house music.  

Just my opinion . . .

phred

I've always wondered about break-ins myself.  It's one thing to
be in a public space like a park after dark -- I mean really, what
does it mean to close off an open air area that is deadicated to
the public, you know?  But to me it's quite another to remove a
lock and sneak in . . . that really could count as breaking and
entering, which is even worse than the $270 and misdemeanor charge
Liquid participants got slapped with for violating the East Bay
Regional Park Service's 10:00 pm curfew for Oyster Bay.

Laura

This is something I can't pass up, though.  If you are responding to 
someone's post, or worse, an entire thread, must you quote the entire 
thread or post in your message simply to say "Yeah, me too" or something 
equally useless at the end?

Hyperreal is a lagged machine as it is, and there are around 350 people 
on sfraves, meaning any mail you send is sent out that many times (not to 
mention the million other things Hyperreal handles).

At any rate, please use some discetion when quoting in your posts.  
Besides, I hate reading yesterday's news :)

	Sami


From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 18 02:27:41 1994

Received: from gladstone.uoregon.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id CAA03319; Tue, 18 Oct 1994 02:27:38 -0700
Received: from [128.223.116.101] (lanrover1-5.uoregon.edu [128.223.116.101]) by gladstone.uoregon.edu (8.6.9/8.6.5.Beta7) with SMTP id CAA27989 for <sfraves@hyperreal.com>; Tue, 18 Oct 1994 02:27:36 -0700
Message-Id: <199410180927.CAA27989@gladstone.uoregon.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Mon, 17 Oct 1994 02:27:32 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: drenalin@gladstone.uoregon.edu (drenalin)
Subject: Re: space respect
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I just wanted to insert a comment that sometimes it is up to the organizers
of a renegade to provide the opportunity for everyone to help respect the
place you use.  I know that a lot of the renegade groups do things like
provide trash bags and such when the party is outdoors.  The Cloud Factory
provides trash bags, and then supervises the separation into recycling
bags, and tries its hardest to always leave a place cleaner tha nit was
before.  We've never done a breakin yet but we would try to follow the same
guidelines.  I always wonder about the ethics of breakins too but what if
the building is unused?  Isn't it a shame just to leave empty buildings all
over?  As an architecture major I think raves are a great example of urban
redevelopment :)

peace and love  Scott

>without some of the proper permits.  In the worst
>scenario everyone there totally violated someone else's
>property and space.
>
>For what reason?
>Because we really need to dance in different places?
>Because the party was free?
>
>I enjoyed dancing there.  It was fun.
>But I have mixed feelings about how I treated
>other people.  People I don't know.  Just to
>go to a fun party.
>
>I think that I like a party where all the shit
>is together.  Including a place in society and
>respecting it.  It does not add any thrill for me
>to be at a renegade as opposed to a club (or a park).
>Permits are not inherently bad.

people in London who are putting out these records, many of

increasing their access to this music.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 18 08:48:03 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id IAA10749; Tue, 18 Oct 1994 08:48:03 -0700
Received: from ns.PacBell.COM by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id IAA10740; Tue, 18 Oct 1994 08:47:58 -0700
Received: from srv.PacBell.COM (mother.srv.PacBell.COM) by ns.PacBell.COM (4.1/PacBell-10/04/94)
	id AA22973; Tue, 18 Oct 94 08:47:56 PDT
Received: from pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM by srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.0)
	id AA23151; Tue, 18 Oct 94 08:47:55 PDT
Received: from lizard.srv.PacBell.COM by pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM (4.1/SMI-4.1)
	id AA04602; Tue, 18 Oct 94 08:47:54 PDT
Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 08:47:54 PDT
From: lxfogel@srv.PacBell.COM (Lee Fogel)
Message-Id: <9410181547.AA04602@pbssi.srv.PacBell.COM>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: weekend with the tribe
Cc: jlf3@mofo.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Saturday nite, we went to the wedding ceremony of Jon Drukman and
Ann Francis, two original SFRavers, though I don't think they are on 
the list anymore.  This was or first rave wedding, and it was a rather
moving experience.  It took place in a loft space that was used
for a Richie Hawtin party a year ago.  I'm usually not a fan of formal
ceremonies or rituals that are handed down to the masses by cultural
authorities, but this wedding ritual was created by the folks it was 
intended for, making it relevant and meaningful.

Ambient music, psychedelic projections, friends reading poetry
or short statements about friendship & love, candle lighting, humor, 
audience involvement, symbolism... it was all very warm and heartfelt;
a wonderful way to initiate the union of two individuals.

After the ceremony, the party took over.  We danced to great sets by Laura 
and Tamara, and spend a lot of time chilling with other people that we
knew.  This was by far the most enjoyable wedding we had ever attended.

Sunday morning we made our way to the Russian River Tribal Phuture,
arriving around noon.  It was like a little raver village with lots
of tents spread around and a big bus; a relaxed laid back scene with 
people mostly chilling/spacing out with nature in perfect weather.
I'm guessing that most people had shot their wad the day/evening b4. 
We headed down to the water and joined a contingent of canoers with
garbage bags to help with the river cleanup.  Bryce provided a nice
energetic backdrop on the Liquid Air soundsystem for us.  There was quite
a bit of garbage and it was obvious that it would take a more than one
environmentally conscious rave to finish the job.  But an important
statement was made along with some good karma for our community.

Perhaps it's just the outdoor parties that I've been attending lately, 
but I've started to notice a marked increase in ravers who seem to care
about their surroundings. At Russion River, I saw people diving into huge 
thickets of poison oak to retrieve garbage.  There will always be slobs 
amongst us, but perhaps the sight of just a few cleaning up will be 
enough to make lazier partiers a little more self conscious.  Well, we 
can only hope.

The canoing was fun;  In the river, there were a bunch of other 
canoers and swimmers, and we somehow managed to avoid smashing into a 
few of them. =%-}

We wandered back to the main campgrounds where Stonie was spinning some
nice tunes.  There were only about 20 people dancing, but there was a good
vibe.  We ran into a variety of SFRavers and other friends.  M Normal 
showed up and we checked out her ambient set back down by the river for a 
while.  Then Tracy took over the main system and was typically wonderful as 
the rave gathered some  steam.  Galen followed around sunset, appropriately 
enough.  Unfortunately, at around 7ish, the owner of the campgrounds said 
that he was getting noise complaints from 3 nearby ranchers, so the volume 
had to be turned way down.  This kinda killed the energy for us, so we 
called it a day.  But all in all, we already had had a great time, so no
complaints.  Next time, we hope to be there from the beginning.  Thanks
to Mark, Tracy, the Pacific crew, Bryce and everyone else who helped :)

Lee
____________________________________________________________________________
lxfogel@pacbell.com   (    (   (  ( ((1)) )  )   )    )    lee@hyperreal.com
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

On Mon, 17 Oct 1994 23:57:18 -0700 (PDT), 
Sami Khoury  <sk1@uclink.berkeley.edu> wrote:

>This is something I can't pass up, though.  If you are responding to 
>someone's post, or worse, an entire thread, must you quote the entire 
>thread or post in your message simply to say "Yeah, me too" or something 
>equally useless at the end?
>
>Hyperreal is a lagged machine as it is, and there are around 350 people 
>on sfraves, meaning any mail you send is sent out that many times (not to 
>mention the million other things Hyperreal handles).
>
>At any rate, please use some discetion when quoting in your posts.  
>Besides, I hate reading yesterday's news :)

Hello,

While I really sympathize with this viewpoint, 
I find that I am more likely to receive messages that are just the 
reverse, ie the person has not quoted *any* of the original message.

With many different messages arriving, sometimes it is difficult or 
impossible to figure out what the reply means.

For example, a stellar personality sent me a reply recently saying just:
"Well, yes, of course".  I still did have my last message to that person, 
and so knew what it meant, but in other cases, I am not so sure, 
especially in "list" messages.

Maybe people can find a happy medium between including nothing and 
including all the previous messages on the subject! :-)

-

respect to all,

Ken            ken@snowcrest.net   (primary address)
               (if no answer, try ken.stuart@tigerteam.org )

Precedence: bulk


I found this on a newsgroup and thought it might be of interest...

----------------------

SOUND TRAFFIC CONTROL's "THRONE OF DRONES" and "RE-IMMERSION"
Thursday 10 November & Friday 11 November, 1994
Club Townsend, 174 Townsend Street, San Francisco
 
"THRONE OF DRONES" and "RE-IMMERSION" are two of the more unusual 
electronic/ambient music events you'll see/hear this year in San Francisco. 
The shows, presented by SOUND TRAFFIC CONTROL (a Bay Area-based media arts 
collective), feature a unique real-time spatial audio system through which 
musicians, engineers, conductors, vocalists and DJs form an interwoven, 
surround-sound orchestra. Anyone who heard the Mixmaster Morris/Spacetime 
Continuum presentation last spring will find these to be a great follow-up.
 
Sound Traffic Control's audio/visual system is a 3D sound reinforcement 
network that projects music and audio animation throughout the room, 
creating sonic environments that stretch the boundaries beyond the THX 
audio arrays used in many theaters. "Sound Traffic Control" is also a 
metaphor: the "air traffic controllers" in the 3D Surround Hub pilot 
airborne "musical cargo ships" from different parts of STC's "sound world" 
utilizing separate/simultaneous "taxis," "takeoffs," and "landings."  The 
audience members are "passengers" who roam runways intersecting the dynamic 
musical trajectories.
 
Thursday's "THRONE OF DRONES" features the ISO-AMBIENT ORCHESTRA, a group 
of instrumentalists from numerous local bands and international solo 
projects whose real-time virtual performance is akin to an Internet-style 
online experience. Iso-Ambient Orchestra members include: Joe Gore; Chris 
Muir; Michael Belfer (Torcher); Anton Newcombe (Brian Jonestown Massacre) 
and Larry LaLonde (Primus) and a host of others. Later on the same bill is 
David Darling, solo cellist, whose evocative music provides an atmospheric 
melancholy. Those familiar with his CD releases on the ECM and Hearts of 
Space labels should witness his inauguration into the 3D sound field. Along 
with this, arrives the Acid Karaoke of Carl Stone and oriental singer Mien 
Xiao-Fen. Stone is an internationally-known electronic music composer who 
has traveled extensively and released many wild and whimsical works for New 
Albion and other labels. His music, in combination with Mien Xiao Fen's 
exotic vocals, should transform the event into a department-store frenzy. 
DJs for the night are not your usual fare: ethnic/world specialist Cheb i 
Sabbah will create a multilayered tribal/space mix; Jonah Sharpe is back 
from England with a fresh new collection of tracks; and debuting on 
"digital transport" will be the creator, co-ordinator and curator of Sound 
Traffic Control, Naut Humon. The Drones begin at 9 p.m., tickets are $6.
 
Friday's RE-IMMERSION, presented in conjunction with Ambient Jungle, adds a 
festive element to the occasion. Appearing with STC will be Spacetime 
Continuum, a techno-ambient convergence from the Astralwerks label guided 
by Jonah Sharpe, whose aural exploits include collaborations with Bill 
Laswell, Peter Namlook and Deep Space Network. The evening's lift-off will 
be provided by Reflective Records' Single Cell Orchestra, who explore the 
mysterious underside of the ambient phenomenon through chromatic 
transpositions and narrative form. For those who continue to dance, DJs 
Mark Farina, Thomas and Felix will spin atypical house- and techno-beats in 
the Dubzone. Macross Vision by Hyperdelic will fill the Dubzone with 
synaesthetic color and light. Doors open at midnight, tickets are $10.
 
On both nights, the 3D sonic habitat will be punctuated by Perry Hoberman's 
"Symphonic Appliance System," which animates a garage-sale full of 
household gadgets including projectors, radios, records and electric tools 
in an audio/visual atomic-age setting.
 
The Audio Engineering Society (AES) convention for pro audio gearheads at 
San Francisco's Moscone Convention Center will run concurrently with the 
shows, so anyone looking for a futuristic sampling of audio technology 
outside the convention site need look no further. Sound Traffic Control 
uses a Level Control System from LCS, Inc. that sends multiple Macintosh 
digital audio workstation outputs live to discreet DSP mixer posts which 
are then forwarded to a 3D loudspeaker diffusion matrix.
 
For more information, contact Sound Traffic Control at (415) 522.7380

..

Hello everybody on sfraves!

 This is not a rave related issue but since I take it a lot of you are probably  
SF voters I'd like to pass this info along -- I am volunteering for the  
Campaign to elect Mabel Teng as San Francisco City Supervisor in November, and  
we have set up a www home page for the campaign to distribute position papers,  
endorsement lists, etc., on the net. The following information is distributed  
on the net to various political discussion groups to annouce the availability  
of these pages. If you have a www browser, please check out the candidate's  
platform, etc. And if you have any further questions, or want to get involved  
in the campaign, please send mail to bong@netcom.com (preferred) or  
bong@Next.com.

Thanks!
/bong

###
As part of our effort to reach out to the San Francisco voters on internet, The  
Mabel Teng for San Francisco City Supervisor campaign has made campaign  
literature available via anonymous ftp or World Wide Web. 


World Wide Web access:

	set URL to ftp://ftp.netcom.com/pub/bong/MabelTeng/www/index.html
	
Anonymous ftp access:

	% ftp ftp.netcom.com
	
	use "anonymous" as user name and your email address as password.
	
	Information are available in /pub/bong/MabelTeng/ftp. A README.txt
	file in that directory will point you to the campaign literature
	available. You can see by issueing the ftp command:
		
	get README.txt |more
	

For further information, please contact:

Mabel Teng For San Francisco City Supervisor
683 Commercial Street. SF, CA 94111
Voice: 415.788.2214  Fax: 415.788.8528
Email: MABELTENG@AOL.COM
###


PS -- FYI: Some other candidates  on the November ballot have also made their  
home pages available via www on the SF Examiner www server.  Set URL to 


	 http://sfgate.com/examiner/

On Tue, 18 Oct 1994, Cynthia Lopez wrote:
> for any dj on sfr who's interested...
> 
> For information about how to get new Jungle records by mail, 
> contact shaggy@panix.com. I am in contact with some of the 
> people in London who are putting out these records, many of 
> which won't be available in record shops outside of the U.K. I 
> am trying to set up a network of Jungle enthusiasts, interested 
> increasing their access to this music.

If you're realy interested in buying Jungle/breakbeat/uk hardcore/drum 
and bass stuff i'd recommend two dealers. If you're just a listener, 611 
REcords in Philadelphia. They are a fantastic record shop carrying pretty 
much everything and have a great bbeat section. If you're interested i 
have an email address but not on me now. Also, if you're trying to spin, 
and want the latest and greatest, i would most definitely recommend Lucky 
Spin Records in London. These guys are pretty much the ultimate jungle 
store, as everyting is happening in london now, and these guys have been 
there from the beginning. Again,for those interested i can get phone 
numbers, address, etc. 

mikebee

ps you also probably want to try the breaks mailing 
list....breaks@xmission.com. send a message to majordomo@xmission.com 
with subscribe breaks  in the body and they'll hook you up. 


From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 18 15:15:06 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id PAA21419; Tue, 18 Oct 1994 15:15:06 -0700
Received: from pilot.njin.net by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id PAA21414; Tue, 18 Oct 1994 15:15:01 -0700
Received: by pilot.njin.net (5.59/SMI4.0/RU1.5/3.08) 
	id AA06340; Tue, 18 Oct 94 18:14:18 EDT
Date: Tue, 18 Oct 94 18:14:18 EDT
From: csc@pilot.njin.net (Sean Casey)
Message-Id: <9410182214.AA06340@pilot.njin.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Re: space respect
In-Reply-To: <199410180927.CAA27989@gladstone.uoregon.edu>
References: <199410180927.CAA27989@gladstone.uoregon.edu>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I don't think there's anything "magic" about a renegade, except
perhaps that they tend to draw certain types of people that I like
associating with. They also tend to be spontaneous and have little
production... it makes for a different kind of interaction than other
parties. I've met most of my good friends in SF this way.

Variety is good. I mostly attend renegades and small parties, and go
occasionally for the big blowout, especially if it has a good laser
show. Helping with parties is the best, I think, because it brings you
close with other people and it lets you put more of your personal
energy into the party.

I respect Laura's concerns on break-ins. I draw the line on break-ins
for several reasons, mostly safety and respect. Safety is important to
me; one can't protect guests from everything, but I feel one has an
obligation to deal with obvious and risky safety issues i.e. no stupid
risks.  This isn't easy to do at a break-in, where there can be all
sorts of surprises: Things fall from the ceiling. The rottweiler wakes
up. The circuit breaker trips at 15 amps but the wiring melts and
burns at 8.  People accidentally break something. The owner shows up
with a shotgun.  Armed thugs with badges take the sound system,
handcuff everyone, force them into trucks, and imprison them. You find
out the hard way that you're in a local gang hideout. Etc... There's
just too many unknowns, and I don't want a tragedy at my party.

The other important issue to me is respect.  You just don't break into
someone's property and have a party there. You ask. Just like you'd
expect someone to ask you rather than cutting the lock on your house
and letting hundreds of people inside. I personally don't want my
party to start with the karma of breaking-in to someone's space.

Now public property is free game. The way I feel about it, I paid for
it, and as long as I don't disturb anyone (much...any possible action
will disturb some californian) and leave the place like I found it,
then I'm perfectly in the right for using it. Statutes may disagree,
but most of the statutes are bad laws, blanket protections that hurt
responsible users by not taking things case-by-case. Even enforcement
knows this; they're usually pretty chill after talking with us and
having a look.

Sean

Subject: Indian Summer Daze
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com

Just a quick review:

Indian Summer Daze on friday night was a lot of fun.  It was a very classic
house club.  It reminded me a lot of good house clubs in LA.  Everyone was
dressed real funky, and most people were really into dancing.  The location
was neat.  Above the street at 15th and Petrero, this fully legal club
had lots of UV, some strobes, plenty of sound.  The club was small, intimate,
and suprisingly cool.  But you could retreat to the rooftop chill area to 
(freeze!) also.  

The music was not particularly stellar, but the DJ (unknown to me), had
plenty of spirit+energy and kept the party going.  Unfortuantly, by about
4am there was plenty of open space on the dancefloor, but those of us who
were into it didn't seem to mind much.  I'll look forward to future Dazes.
We payed a 5 dollar cover to a friendly door person.  Age span was about
18-23, and the crowd was really diverse.  Enjoy!

-troy

hello folx,
thought u might be interested in couple of items next week:
on the 24th of october, dr. daniel matt of center for jewish studies at
grad. theol. union will talk about "god and the big bang" at temple
beth am, 26790 arastradero, los altos hills, 415.493.4661 at 7:30 pm.
then, on wed., october 26 i will be talking on physical and metaphysical
cosmologies at san jose state univ., in business bldg., rm 124 at 6:30 pm.
more immediately rave related, i really recommend "lacho drom", a beautiful
movie about rom people and their peregrinations from rajastan to spain.
most of the movie is music the rom people play, with few words spoken.
there is a small drawback in that few of the words of the songs are
translated. but we can see in wonderful detail how music is an integral
part of the rom peoples' lives. the music is great, as is the dancing
we see. i could barely contain myself in my  seat. oh, it is playing at
uc theater on university near shattuck in berzerkeley until the 20th.
take care/shalom
ovid

> For me the bottom line is
> it's alot more exciting to be someplace your not supposed to be 
> with a whole bunch of cool people  
>	Josh B

I guess what I figured out is that the "someplace your not supposed
to be" part doesn't excite me.  It struck me as silly.  I felt a
like a juvenile deliquent.  A hooligan.

The space used was ideal.  It was basically perfect.
I understand the cost/energy motivation for 'using' a space.

However, I definitely picked up on this sense of excitment *because* 
of the break-in aspect that I didn't share with others.  I was excited 
because it was an otherwise nice party.


**********************

More Cool Californians 

I went to What's Happening at the cocodrie on Tuesday.  It was
really empty and the music was odd/funky/clubby and uninspiring.
It had a nice sized dancefloor.

Counting on an extremely small cover charge and free water 
I went over to Butterfly @ Cassanova.  Comfortable bar. 
Nice people.  Freaky easy hiphop to bass solid house.
I haven't heard this kind of music anywhere lately.  
My cup of tea.  I thought Charlotte was amazing.  So precise.  
Almost made me want to check out Megatripolis this week ... $$$
Butterfly is very cool.  I am going back when I can afford a beer.

Dave

syrup-tish-ously monitoring your list is basicaly my interest in acid
breaks(trip hop, watteva); Im sure you locals have your own names, Ive
heard plenty... Basicaly Im hoping some SF'rs can hook me up w/ names, #s
of reputable shoppes in SF area having the meaty stock of current acid
breaks, also, of course, any new releases or labels I can/must check

originated; any SF'rs out there know UK sources,labels heavy on this tip?

Subject: last week's megatrip
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Wed, 19 Oct 94 19:02:40 PDT
From: Barry Alexander <peyote@ekstatic.com>
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


hi everybody, while most of you were probably at the russian river last
saturday, i checked out megatripolis.  i was actually helping out gramme
and reed (and david too) with setting up internet access at the troc.  boy
what a hassle that was!  its hard to maintain a connection when the sushi
bar picks up the line while you're wwwebbing.  i think frazier said they
will be getting more lines for dedicated computer access.  that will be cool.

there was only one "real" phone line, david set up this windows
machine and demoed "mosialla?" (mark p. help me with this if your out
there), which is a mosaic www browser that has more robust features than
the NCSA's version.  anyway it was fun playing with that and david's other
pc eye candy.  it will be nice to get more computer playthings there in
the furture.

i brought my portable too but with one phone line avaiable i checked out
the party.  i was pretty sparse compared to the only other time i was
there which was opening night.  i figure alot of people were doing the
russian river.  but things picked up after 2am.  i really didn't mind
there was more room to dance, it wasn't too hot and it seemed more than
half the people there were ON: lots of smiles and dancing among the people
there provided tangible positive energy.  i think megatripolis is one of
those parties where you dont have to trippin to have a good time. 
although one of these days i'll have to, the environment is ripe for that.

denis peron's talk was really moving.  the parallel universe series is
something that an adult like me appreciates.  it was really magic when
denis announced in the middle of his talk that he was tripping and carried
on without missing a beat.  seriously though medical marijuana is
something worth supporting.

Jacob wrote:  i really recommend "lacho drom", a beautiful
>movie about rom people and their peregrinations from rajastan to spain.
>most of the movie is music the rom people play, with few words spoken.
>there is a small drawback in that few of the words of the songs are
>translated. but we can see in wonderful detail how music is an integral
>part of the rom peoples' lives. the music is great, as is the dancing
>we see. i could barely contain myself in my  seat. oh, it is playing at
>uc theater on university near shattuck in berzerkeley until the 20th.
>take care/shalom
>ovid

I too have seen this, Mijos, and he is right! Don't miss this, especially
for the fig tree in the desert, covered with candles and a beautiful
dancing girl under it, spinning and releasing the stars. The percussion is
incredible, and the charm uncomparable. don't miss it, if you do, hey,
you're missing it!

Lotsa love
 Milton and the E-Bee....

Btw: cinema rec: easy rider still on haight? And don't miss the vibe-movie,
Priscilla, Queen of the Desert, this movie is about raving!

Subject: South Bay happenings
To: ". sfraves list" <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9410192128.A2131-0100000@quack.kfu.com>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; CHARSET=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Well for those keeping track, I'm at 367 pieces of mail and rising.  It's 
just like that scene in The Shining where all the blood is rushing out of 
the elevators - well for me it's e-mail spewing out my inbox.  

Okay there seems to be a lot of shtuff to attend in the south bay as far
as club-type events.  It's good music and only a small quantity of 
people... so I'm going to keep blurting these out if you don't mind:
(I know these are already in the calendar, but I just wanna comment..)

Monday:  Free Life at Greg's Bar in San Jose
	Cozy little bar with hardwood floors and unfortunately a large
	mirror.	9-2am but crowd doesn't come in til like 11pm.  From then on
	everyone gets into the housey tunes. Good mix of people gay/straight
	you name it.  There's an outside "backyard" where people gab and 
	hang out which is interesting.  Usually Harry Who, Rick Preston, 
	and lotsa others

Tuesday: Groove Room at Waves in Los Gatos
	I've only been once.  Another cozy dance area with a big screen
	TV with strange videos playing.  younger crowd, minimal light effects
	I get a basement feeling in this space.  The DJ is away from the 
	speakers so it's kinda disjoint.  Alonzo and others

Wednesdays: Buzz at the Oasis in San Jose
	lately it's been empty in the house room unti like 10:30 or 11pm 
	and then things start picking up.  Always cool slide visuals and 
	an occasional smoke machine misting.  Lots of room and good 
	ventilation.  Jacked up DJ booth like any other club but good 
	sound system. Lots of funky hi tech lights and almost always a bongo
	drummer in a corner for the tribal beat.  Seen all kinds of DJ's here.
	Rick Harry Spun Garth Markie Loren many more.

Thursdays: Velvet Shop in San Jose
	This reminds me of a big cabana or something.  It's a very 
	centralized feeling to be in the dance floor... you're surrounded 
	by people on just about every side and it's usually dark and very 
	friendly.  DJ is at  the corner of the dancefloor a-la rennegade
	style and even the speakers look portable.  The crowd here is 
	lively from the very beginning until the very end from what I've
	seen.  Even though the bar is right nect to the dance floor it's 
	possible to dance and not even notice the drag queens and gawkers.  
	This thursday it's Rick Preston, Markie Mark, and Ryan.

Sundays: The Blue in Santa Cruz
	Sorry no data on this yet.  but my flyer sez:
	Dj's Loren, Mei-Lwun, Rick Preston
	$1 21+
	923 Pacific 408/684.3434

Oh yeah, Motion Wednesday the 26th should be good.  Great slanted floor 
to dance on.  The south bay sure is keeping me busy.

Ok it's time for Buzz.

-willis
o.O
( ) walrus@quack.kfu.com

p.s. Highway 85 is open, yay!

Hello Ravers,

I thought I'd drop you a line to let you know a bit more about what 
this "cathedral Rave" thing is all about. I am a Shefffielder whose 
been to their event. Firstly, I wouldn't describe it as a rave, 
at least not in the traditional English sense (continuous fast techno, 
flashing lights, lots of amylen nitrate and E). It is more like 
ambient yoga type vibes going down. They use alot of high tech video 
technology to lead people into a 'spiritual' experience. Lots of 
cosmological  techno imagery sort of stuff of science programs, DNA 
loops, black holes and shit like that. The music goes from ambient 
to techno house. Its quite an experience, difficult to describe,  
see for your self. 
I dunno where this idea that Mattthew Fox is running it has come from 
I know he visited the church in England this year but I'm sure its 
the Sheffield lot running it in San Fran. 

See ya 
if you want any more info drop me a line.

Tom

------- Forwarded Message
To: WRPI Alumns <wrpi-alumns@peregrine.Eng.Sun.COM>
Subject: Throne of Drones

This was sent to me by a friend of a friend who will be part of the
Iso-Ambient Orchestra for this performance.

Aaron

P.S. Does anyone know what "Acid Karaoke" is?
- ---

   SOUND TRAFFIC CONTROL's "THRONE OF DRONES" and "RE-IMMERSION"
   Thursday 10 November & Friday 11 November, 1994
   Club Townsend, 174 Townsend Street, San Francisco

 "THRONE OF DRONES" and "RE-IMMERSION" are two of the more unusual
 electronic/ambient music events you'll see/hear this year in San
 Francisco.  The shows, presented by SOUND TRAFFIC CONTROL (a Bay
 Area-based media arts collective), feature a unique real-time spatial
 audio system through which musicians, engineers, conductors, vocalists
 and DJs form an interwoven, surround-sound orchestra. Anyone who heard
 the Mixmaster Morris/Spacetime Continuum presentation last spring will
 find these to be a great follow-up.

 Sound Traffic Control's audio/visual system is a 3D sound
 reinforcement network that projects music and audio animation
 throughout the room, creating sonic environments that stretch the
 boundaries beyond the THX audio arrays used in many theaters. "Sound
 Traffic Control" is also a metaphor: the "air traffic controllers" in
 the 3D Surround Hub pilot airborne "musical cargo ships" from
 different parts of STC's "sound world" utilizing separate/simultaneous
 "taxis," "takeoffs," and "landings."  The audience members are
 "passengers" who roam runways intersecting the dynamic musical
 trajectories.

 Thursday's "THRONE OF DRONES" features the ISO-AMBIENT ORCHESTRA, a
 group of instrumentalists from numerous local bands and international
 solo projects whose real-time virtual performance is akin to an
 Internet-style online experience.  Iso-Ambient Orchestra members
 include: Joe Gore; Chris Muir; Michael Belfer (Torcher); Anton
 Newcombe (Brian Jonestown Massacre) and Larry LaLonde (Primus) and a
 host of others. 
 
 Later on the same bill is David Darling, solo cellist, whose evocative
 music provides an atmospheric melancholy. Those familiar with his CD
 releases on the ECM and Hearts of Space labels should witness his
 inauguration into the 3D sound field.  Along with this, arrives the
 Acid Karaoke of Carl Stone and oriental singer Mien Xiao-Fen.  Stone is
 an internationally-known electronic music composer who has traveled
 extensively and released many wild and whimsical works for New Albion
 and other labels.  His music, in combination with Mien Xiao-Fen's
 exotic vocals, should transform the event into a department-store
 frenzy.

 DJs for the night are not your usual fare: ethnic/world specialist
 Cheb i Sabbah will create a multilayered tribal/space mix; Jonah
 Sharpe is back from England with a fresh new collection of tracks; and
 debuting on "digital transport" will be the creator, co-ordinator and
 curator of Sound Traffic Control, Naut Humon. The Drones begin at 9
 p.m., tickets are $6.

 Friday's RE-IMMERSION, presented in conjunction with Ambient Jungle,
 adds a festive element to the occasion. Appearing with STC will be
 Spacetime Continuum, a techno-ambient convergence from the Astralwerks
 label guided by Jonah Sharpe, whose aural exploits include
 collaborations with Bill Laswell, Peter Namlook and Deep Space
 Network. The evening's lift-off will be provided by Reflective
 Records' Single Cell Orchestra, who explore the mysterious underside
 of the ambient phenomenon through chromatic transpositions and
 narrative form. For those who continue to dance, DJs Mark Farina,
 Thomas and Felix will spin atypical house- and techno-beats in the
 Dubzone. Macross Vision by Hyperdelic will fill the Dubzone with
 synaesthetic color and light. Doors open at midnight, tickets are $10.

 On both nights, the 3D sonic habitat will be punctuated by Perry
 Hoberman's "Symphonic Appliance System," which animates a garage-sale
 full of household gadgets including projectors, radios, records and
 electric tools in an audio/visual atomic-age setting.

 The Audio Engineering Society (AES) convention for pro audio gearheads
 at San Francisco's Moscone Convention Center will run concurrently
 with the shows, so anyone looking for a futuristic sampling of audio
 technology outside the convention site need look no further. Sound
 Traffic Control uses a Level Control System from LCS, Inc. that sends
 multiple Macintosh digital audio workstation outputs live to discreet
 DSP mixer posts which are then forwarded to a 3D loudspeaker diffusion
 matrix.

 For more information, contact Sound Traffic Control at (415) 522.7380

 -30-

------- End of Forwarded Message

  i personally haven't readit, but you should check out the book by
    Mickey Hart, "Drumming at the Edge of Magic", in which he describes
      how indigenous cultures all over the world design, make, and play
        drums, both for ceremonial purposes and just jammin'.
   it even gets into how native americans selected and sacrificed animals
     when a drum with skins was required; very nasty stuff...

?Mijos, did anyone out there go to the full moon?

I couldn't get my motivation up, bumming rides and waking up at 1 am to
call, after being jerked off these last few months, so that's 3 in a row
that i've been denied (or, shall i say, I denied them?).

So, to back up Ken stuart's query, yeah, how have the last two been? It's a
small but significant sign that allen couldn't find "his own" party last
month! Has the lack of accessability made people less enthusiastic,  or has
it made people extremely happy to feel that they have accomplished a great
deed in finding it? How does that little cloud of love that hovers over
smiling, dancing people look? Is it a light fog, or that really funky,
thick thing that you remember  forever and go "oh yesssssssssssss" as you
roll your eyes?

With a party like sunset every weekend, tho, my vibe reservoir runneth
over. Galen, I wish I had a farm by the bay,to give you a permanent
space...

Lotsa love, and if any sfraver wins the lottery, BUY SOME PARTY LAND! 
 Milton and the E-Bee........ 



From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 20 16:09:00 1994

From: Mdma@eworld.com

	(1.38.193.5/16.2) id AA27982; Thu, 20 Oct 1994 16:08:25 -0700
X-Mailer: AOS Mailer
Message-Id: <9410201608.tn33261@eworld.com>

Date: Thu, 20 Oct 94 16:08:22 PDT
Subject: fmr
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

     Since no one has posted anything about the fmr, I thought I'd be the
first one to get it on =)  The site was beee-u-ti-full!  As we drove down the
cliff we could see the moon casting an silver reflection on the water, along
with the massive Goat Rock .  A few minutes after we got there, apparently
there were some sound problems and left stack of speakers were down.  To me,
it felt like that the party never really started  (did I just miss out, or am
I correct?).  Garth let some record spin for what seemed like an eternity
while the problems were being fixed.  Soon enough, the cops decided to shut
it down because of noise complaints.  
     Although, momentum never gathered, the vibe was definitely there!  That
was the first fmr, I had been to since one last year at Bonny Doon, and
everyone was so friendly--except one particular girl I introduced to a friend
of mine who was experiencing his first rave.  She held out her hand to shake
his, when I told her he was a newbie, she withdrew her hand and gave him a
dirty look!  Its that kind of shit that pisses me off.  Don't we want people
to see what raves are really about?  Its that kind of attitude that helps
perpetuates the negative stereotype.  
     Other than her, everyone else I introduced Matt to was very receptive
and glad he was there.  I really enjoyed meeting all the people and seeing
familiar faces again.  David (?)from Oakland, and many others whom I'm not
sure of their names but you helped make the three hour drive for us worth
while.
rave on,
Brian

Mijos, just needed to say that it was so refreshing to do some camping with
you! Tents were unnecessary, toatl tweakin population can sleep no more,
but what joy to be beached with all you love seals around that fire...was
that Einstein talkin' in that ambient set? I couldn't ground my mind too
well during that part, but "dis poem" made my night. 

Ah, a chance to do something healthy for myself! Got a tan, did the river,
watched my scrotum shrink to unbelievably small dimensions upon immersion,
and see the diference between a "raver" party (picking up trash) and a
pickup party (drive to the river, drink your budweiz, leave your trash). Me
an Dave spent four hours coming down by canoe, getting 5 bags and hiting 30
or so trees (damn hard to steer those things). As an entomologist, I was
dissapointed by the lack of mosquito, blackfly and tick bites, they are
great conversation starters ("you know, that female needs your blood to
make her babies. Here, let me show you how it pierces your skin"). But hey,
at least i didn't have to stink of DEET or Off!

Too bad the directions confusion made some people stay in sf, but I think
we were pretty close to max capacity,and wow, how do ravers keep those
bathrooms so clean? Could have something to do with respect? Consideration?
Hmmmmmyeah, could beee! 


Lotsa love, maintain yer tans,
 Milton and the E-Bee.........

Hello sfravers!
I'm a nw-raver and this is my very first post (i think :) ) to sf!
yaaaaay!

Anyway, let me say that I can feel the vibe you folks have down there
all the way up here!  I'm jealous and I wanna come down there!

HOWEVER, I am unfortunately posting because I feel motivated to respond
to the post about the rude girl at your fmr (sorry I forgot who posted).

I agree that this type of negative energy has NO PLACE in the 
underground universe.  Isn't the reason we escape to the underground
to avoid that type of shit and promote LOVE and ACCEPTANCE?!?!

True, there are some closed-minded people who should not be going
to raves, but if someone really wants to check it out, they should
be welcomed warmly.  AAAAAaaaaaa !!!!!  I HATE THAT SHIT!!!!!!
Jesus, doesn't that girl remember when she was new??? 
OH. . .maybe she was BORN on the dancefloor.

Seek and destroy this menace.

love, 
eric

sounds good, and so does the party in the park on Sunday, plus
Megatripolis combines with Your Sisters' House on Saturday, so all
that ought to keep you busy!  

New in the weeklies: the Eighth House and Move!

	Milton,

	  In rolling stone there was a real good article about nitrates and
	they're link to karposi's sarcoma in aid's patients.  Basically in
	the gay community nitrates are known as poppers.    There has
	been a strong link of people who use nitrates and the occurance
	of sarcoma.  The conclusion was that sarcoma are not a result
	of hiv/aids, but a result of the usage of nitrates.  Sarcoma normally
	occur in men over the age of 50 and are benign, but something
	about the nitrates not only makes them occur at a much earlier
	age, but they are malignant and will ultimately cause death.

	  Basically not great stuff for the long term.  But the effect of
	poppers is that you get a relaxation in your muscles.  Supposedly
	this increases the sensation and intensity of orgasm.  Also
	gay men into the fisting scene use it to relax, well their
	muscle.

	  So from what I understand, do not, and I stress NOT use them
	unless you want to encounter the long term affects.

	Ron.

On Thu, 20 Oct 1994 medeiros@nature.Berkeley.EDU wrote:

> What is amylen nitrate? what is it made of, where does it come from, what
> does it do, does it trash you out like speed?

	Amylen nitrate are 'poppers'. It is a little tube you shove in 
your nose and it makes you high. If I am not mistaken, hey are supposed 
to be used for people we feel like they are fainting. I have inhaled 
through the nice little off-white tube once, but I was waiting for my 
real drug to kick in, so I cannot tell you about it trashing your system 
(Although I would guess it does not, but then it does not keep you up 
like speed, at least the way I had done it)

> Also, someone told me nexus was an herbal snort, i've never come across it,
> so what can anyone tell me about that? hat's the experience like, as well
> as the crash?

	Nexus is not an herbal snort. It is not herbal (at least the 
nexus that was going around last fall. I had talked to someone on here 
about it. It is 2-CB which is a psychoactive synethic. I have not tried 
so I cannot tell you from experience what it is like, but it is well 
documented in PIHKAL (alongwith 180 other of your favorite substances, 
many of which are not scheduled - yet.) Furthermore, 2-CB had been legal 
up until mid-Ocotober if I remember correctly. Then it went in your 
favorite category, Schedule 1.....

dave

>>
>> 	they're link to karposi's sarcoma in aid's patients.  Basically in
>> 	the gay community nitrates are known as poppers.    There has

>
>Hmmmm.... Kinda reminds me of the 'good Dr.' up in Boikley who sez that
>AIDS and ARC's are not the result of HIV but the weakening of the human
>body when 'stressed' with a combination of anal sex and drugs. In short,
>he is an extreme homophobe who has let his views distort his studies. Fuck
>him. This is the first I've heard of a link between poppers and Sarcoma.
>So I guess I should go read the article when I get some time....

	The short answer to the statement is that the study was not
	homophobe biased.  What the study brought out was that sarcoma
	was found to not occur in anyone except men who used
	'poppers' and there are documented cases of men with
	sarcoma, but not hiv or aids.  Of course this research is
	completely ignored by the centers for disease control which
	infuriates me and in addition the FDA refuses to ban nitrites
	even though this has been uncovered as a problem, and
	in addition nitrites are becoming the rage again but under
	a new guise.  In the early stages of the epedemic warnings
	about this drug was circulated in the gay community and
	incidents of sarcoma declined markedly.  Now that time
	has passed people of forgotten the danger and nitrate
	manufacturers are peddling this drug again in a new guise.

	So I once again would stress, please do not do this drug.

	Ron.
