> 	  In rolling stone there was a real good article about nitrates and
> 	they're link to karposi's sarcoma in aid's patients.  Basically in
> 	the gay community nitrates are known as poppers.    There has
> 	been a strong link of people who use nitrates and the occurance
> 	of sarcoma.  The conclusion was that sarcoma are not a result
> 	of hiv/aids, but a result of the usage of nitrates.  Sarcoma normally
> 	occur in men over the age of 50 and are benign, but something
> 	about the nitrates not only makes them occur at a much earlier
> 	age, but they are malignant and will ultimately cause death.

Not to be too picky, but I would like to add to this...
Kaposi's Sarcoma was predominantly a disease of Eastern 
European/Mediterranean men in their later years.

I would like to know who has "proof" that poppers, in and of themselves, 
cause KS. As far as I know, poppers are believed to be a correlated risk 
factor, not a direct cause. (feel free to correct me if there is some *new* 
study out that says differently.

Plus, if poppers were _the sole cause_ of KS, you'd see a lot more folks 
walking around with KS lesions. They do tend to pop up on one's face.

> 	  Basically not great stuff for the long term.  But the effect of
> 	poppers is that you get a relaxation in your muscles.  Supposedly
> 	this increases the sensation and intensity of orgasm.  Also
> 	gay men into the fisting scene use it to relax, well their
> 	muscle.

Amyl and butyl nitrate are also vasodilators -- they expand blood vessels.
That would account for the rush. And a heavy rush will do a lot to relax 
the muscles in the rectum.

> 	  So from what I understand, do not, and I stress NOT use them
> 	unless you want to encounter the long term affects.

Same goes for the quasi-legal inhalants, which are just about as bad.

I'd also like to point out that anal sex is the riskiest sexual practice, 
but one that is performed by hets as well. So where are all the women 
with KS?

> 	Ron.

This is not a flame, BTW. I just want to know what's being said out there 
in the "real world". Especially if it's new stuff that I should know. 
(like if someone manages to *prove* that HIV causes AIDS)

Maui

From: geoffw@nexsys.net (Geoff White)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: The Full Moon
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


	60 miles above the Golden Gate bridge?!  I exclaimed.
	It's no further from the City than Bonnie Doon, Markie replied.

	(I live in Mountain View and Bonnie Doon is only about 50
	miles away from me.)  The plan was to have the sound system crew
	at the site by 11 pm and set up so that when people started to
	arrive by 2 everything would be set (yeah right).

	I got to the River road exit on 101 at about 0200 thinking I was
	terribly late, only to discover that I had another 13 miles to go to
	Gurnerville, when I got to Gurnerville the coast weas another 23 miles
	away!! and the roads were twisty! Shit.  Still you gotta have devotion.

	When I did arrive at the site, it was indeed absolutely beautiful.
	Definitely one of, if not the most beautiful FMR sites ever. I drive
	the last mile with the windows open, listening for the thump, thump,
	thump of bass bins, but all I hear is the crashing waves and the
	most beautiful moonlight reflecting on the surf.  There are several
	MASSIVE rocks off shore and one extremely huge rock (The Goat Rock?)
	at the beach itself, but still no sign of the party, was I too late?
	Had it been busted already? I round the last bend and right before me 
	is a yellow rental truck with huge generator in tow.  It's about
	0245 and they are just getting here as well!  We park everything
	and begin to set up. It is _very_ cold (by california standards) i 
	would guess in the mid to high fourties with about a 10 - 15 knot wind 
	out of the southwest that will be a problem for the DJ. Still we get
	the system hooked up and Garth drops the first beat at around 0330.

	The Purple People Pusher excells in outdoor situatuions like this,
	the sheer amount of clean sonic energy it can deliver in outdoor 
	settings can only be described as _otherworldly_.  It's as if you
	asked the folks from Zeta Reticuli to build a system for Homo Sapien
	Reprogramming (like a PROMM burner for Humans). I was parked about 75
	meters away in my car (a CRX) and the BASS was actually causing the
	body to vibrate and sway a little, (shit, talk about PHAT!)

	Dancing under the stars and moon and surf, is a perfect way to recharge
	ones batteries. And Garth took us out of the space dock with expert
	precision,  he built momentum as we did our pre-flight check, all 
	systems were go, this was gonna be a killer trip, and then...
	a ranger shows up.  She says that she got a complaint from some
	houses several miles down the coast she points in the general southern
	direction that the speakers were pointed in.  She was actually
	quite mellow about the whole thing, she says that we need to turn it 
	down.  And that she's gonna go up to the top of the hill and if the 
	sound level is low then we can proceed, else we gotta turn it off,
	OK fair enough, Garth plays some quieter grooves, we cruise along on
	impulse power, and wait.  The sound guys reconfigure the system
	to deliver lower power and to a smaller dispersion pattern.  I notice
	that she swings by about 20 minutes or so later but doesn't stop.
	(I guess we passed the test!) So the party criuses along until Markie
	takes the decks, I guess he decides to not wait for dawn and make
	the jump to light speed now. I was in my car getting warm with a friend
	and we hear/feel the thump, Thump,THUMP. I think OH shit, It's Markie,
	he's goin for it. Sure enough about 15 minutes later there is silence,
	She says "What happened?" I say "I think the party's over :)"
	Sure enough, the ranger is back and tells us that we have to stop the
	amplified music. We are welcome to stay on the beach but we can't play 
	the sound system.  Mark Ameba says he knows of a place near by in a 
	redwood grove where we can go, they pack the stuff up and begin a 
	caravan to the site, I have a meeting to attend to at work, I split
	and head for SF.

	The site was indeed absolutely beautiful and most likely with the
	old style sound systems that the FMR used to use there wouldn't be 
	a problem.  It will be hard to find a place around where it can
	really be cranked, I'm sure Burning Man next year will be one such 
	place but memorial day is a long way away and the nights are getting 
	colder, still the search for the perfect, remote, deserted coastal
	beach with access from the road, and parking continues.

From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>

My mailer says that Maui-Your Sister's House said:
> 
> I'd also like to point out that anal sex is the riskiest sexual practice, 
> but one that is performed by hets as well. So where are all the women 
> with KS?
> 
a friendly interjection from your safer sex advocate: "unprotected" anal
sex (without some sort of barrier) is a ~high~ risk sexual practice, not
necessarily the riskiest.  The nature of the risk, and to whom the risk
is present varies on the exact nature of the anal sex involved.  it has
been demonstrated that fisting (vaginal or anal) without a barrier presents 
a high risk to the insertive partner (somewhat counterintuitive), while 
penis/anus sex presents a higher risk to the recipient.  Note that this 
"risk assessment" is largely in the context of HIV.  Various other kinds 
of STDs can be contracted, on an equal basis, by either partner.  The 
highest risk sexual practice I can imagine is sharing blood or blood products 
in some way, shape, or form (hence the general concern for folks who share 
needles used for injecting IV drugs of whatever kind).

Barriers (condoms, dental dams, vinyl gloves, saran wrap, finger cots,
stubbies) dramatically reduce the probability of transmission of STDs,
including HIV, regardless of the sexual activity one engages in.  

Learn to love latex!  Don't share works (or at least clean them properly)!
Know your partner (get that phone number for later reference)! Know your
own body! Be informed, and make informed, conscious choices about the
risks you choose to take. 
-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

Nexus isn't guaranteed to be anything. People selling it have claimed
several things. Some say it's a derivitave of the khat plant. One says
it's "brominated cathinone". All the samples Shulgin looked at turned
out to be 2CB.

Chances are, if it's being sold openly, it's probably some junk mix of
ephedra and other legals. You'll probably have a lot more fun buying a
bottle of "Brain Wash" soda :).

If it's being sold discreetly as a white powder in gel-caps, then it's
probably 2CB. Beware: 2CB can be powefully disassociative at highter
doses. Use with the usual care.

Amyl Nitrate linked with sarcoma in AIDS patients? Are there any other
studies on this or any technical critiques of the study? Basing such
an important conclusion on one study seems awfully premature.  What
other work is being done on this possible link.

Sean

	Basically to wrap it all up, the study while not being exhaustive found
	that men who used poppers ended up with KS while men who did not
	use poppers did not.  In addition there was no correlation of the
	occurance of KS with AIDS.  In other words men with KS did not have
	AIDS or test positive for HIV.  The whole write-up was in SPIN (I had
	previously stated rolling stone).  The study results was being made
	public by a gay group to bring up the awareness of the public
	to the danger.  While I don't think that they study guaranteed that
	KS would be brought on by the use of poppers,  I do beleive it
	pointed out that it could in fact be a factor in wether or not you
	could contract it.  The interesting thing about the results also was
	that anywere the nitrate was used on the body KS was more likely
	to appear (i.e. the face).  As you pointed out KS may be a male
	related disease only and that may be why we don't really see any
	women with this disease.

	What I was mostly trying to point out was there has been information
	for some time that nitrates could lead to health problems that lead
	to death.  Whenever I consider a substance for consumption I like
	to know as much info about it as possible before consuming it.

	Ron.

From sfraves-owner  Fri Oct 21 10:48:03 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id KAA28619; Fri, 21 Oct 1994 10:48:03 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id KAA28608; Fri, 21 Oct 1994 10:47:55 -0700
Message-Id: <199410211747.KAA28608@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Re: amylen nitrate
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 21 Oct 1994 10:46:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
In-Reply-To: <9410211656.AA16784@pilot.njin.net> from "Sean Casey" at Oct 21, 94 12:56:12 pm
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3970
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

My mailer says that Sean Casey said:
> 
> Amyl Nitrate linked with sarcoma in AIDS patients? Are there any other
> studies on this or any technical critiques of the study? Basing such
> an important conclusion on one study seems awfully premature.  What
> other work is being done on this possible link.
> 
actually, there have been ongoing studies about AIDS co-factors...the
use of inhalants is one of them.  

There is a bit of discussion in the medical community concerning the meaning
of the relationship of inhalant use and contraction of AIDS, or at least
sero-conversion to HIV antibody presence.  The use of amyl and related
inhalants was much more prevalent in the '70s and early '80s in the USA
(at least) because 1) they were legal (most nitrates are no longer legal,
and haven't been for years) 2) they were readily available (over the counter
in bookstores) 3) there had been no prior study suggesting they were a cofactor
in AIDS or sero-conversion.  When they were criminalized, driven onto the
black market, and the initial study released, use of nitrates dropped
dramatically in the USA.

In the context of the initial study, at that time, LOTS of things were
suggested as cofactors for AIDS or sero-conversion...including being Haitian
(hence a button i wore for years claimed i was a "Bisexual Haitian Junkie"...
these were all considered, at the time, indicators of one's risk of infection).
the point is that the available study group at the time was largely European
and US gay males, who had a "somewhat" homegenous culture and practice at
the time.  As we know now, this is no longer (and really, NEVER was) the
case.  The sample size these days, is, regrettably, huge, and very diverse.

There was a very lively discussion of the study in mention at the time. It
was not conclusively shown to be bogus, but is regarded with some reservations.

It is also important to remember, vis a vis Kaposi's Sarcoma, that the 
incidence/morbidity rate for KS has dropped dramatically since the early
'80s, in most of the developed world (though not in AFrica and significant
portions of Asia).  This is largely because the medical community has done
its research on effective treatments, and now properly treats KS.  It still
occurs (too often, sadly), but is not as life-threatening (by itself) as it
used to be.

There has been little new news released on AIDS cofactors in the past few
years.  Most research money has been dedicated to treatment, the search
for an inoculation, and for understanding the molecular biochemistry of
HIV.  Studies are ongoing, however.  

For more information, an introductory text on the early history of the
disease in the US and Europe is Randy Shilts' _The Band Played On_ (the
book, please), though his history is somewhat flawed.  Current news can
be obtained in the periodicals _The Body Positive_ and _BETA_, which
are available in many larger cities.  There are frequent articles in the
_New England Journal of Medicine_ and _Lancet_.  It is also very likely
that most libraries have materials available, at various reading levels.
Consult your librarian or bookseller.  There is also likely to be an AIDS
hotline in your area...the folks on the line should be able to point you
toward a local source of information.

ObRave: Informed choices in use of substances and one's sexual activities
is very important.  Reasonable guidelines suggest that one should be
possessed of normal consciousness when engaging in sexual activity, or
at least to be aware of risks.  One should also choose the level and kind
of risks one is comfortable with, and have appropriate knowledge of how to
play safely, and to have the necessary implements (latex in all its forms,
bleach, etc.) at hand.   PLUR is wonderful, and we can all have a safe and fun
time with our rave friends.  I'd like you all to be around for a long time.
Play and travel safe!
-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

>There is a bit of discussion in the medical community concerning the meaning
>of the relationship of inhalant use and contraction of AIDS, or at least
>sero-conversion to HIV antibody presence.  The use of amyl and related
>inhalants was much more prevalent in the '70s and early '80s in the USA
>(at least) because 1) they were legal (most nitrates are no longer legal,
>and haven't been for years) 2) they were readily available (over the counter
>in bookstores) 3) there had been no prior study suggesting they were a
cofactor
>in AIDS or sero-conversion.  When they were criminalized, driven onto the
>black market, and the initial study released, use of nitrates dropped
>dramatically in the USA.

	Bryce,

	  Nitrates in certain formulations are illegal, but nitrate companies
	have reformulated nitrates so that they pass the FDA regulations,
	and are now marketing them again under a new guise.  You can
	pick them up from you local leather store as "leather cleaner" and
	they are being heavily advertised in different leather magazines.
	So the general outrage is that their is some info, whether it is
	conclusive or not that nitrates are a problem, but yet they are
	remerging and a new generation of consumers are buying them
	without the knowledge.

	  I totally agree with you about informed consumption, and I really
	want all of you to be around for a long time.  I want to have everyone
	around when I am old and grey to rave with :-)

	Ron.

Well, since I was mentioned in two different posts this week, I thought 
I'd say hi.  I had fun demoing my computer at Megatripolis last week, and 
I hope to bring it back Saturday.  The WWW browser mention below was 
"Mosilla", actually Netscape Mosaic, so named because their mascot is a 
dinosaur (I don't know the story behind that).  Its free by ftp, I 
highly recommend it. I also demonstrated  
a 3D virtual reality interface to the Web. It's brand new, and should be 
publicly available in a couple of weeks. Software was 
contributed by Mark Pesce of Interspace (I think).  A thank you to them. 

As for the nitrite/nexxus controversy, check the hyperreal.com archives, 
you should find all the information you need there.  Don't trust anyone's 
net.opinion.

As for the Rave mass, one need look no further than African-American 
churches for inspiration.  From what I hear from people I know, they have 
quite elaborate productions as well as music.  House music is very close 
to gospel, and there is a lot of house music with spiritual lyrics.  The 
Sheffield paradigm is also intriguing, but a mixture of trance and house 
would be fantastic.  A good rave will contain elements of both cultures.
On Wed, 19 Oct 1994, Barry Alexander wrote:

> there), which is a mosaic www browser that has more robust features than
> the NCSA's version.  anyway it was fun playing with that and david's other
> pc eye candy.  it will be nice to get more computer playthings there in
> the furtu

Making the record store rounds last weekend, I heard not one but TWO
new songs with "Get down to the funky beat!" ARRRGH! And this other
despicable piece of vinyl had (I kid you not) the guitar lick sampled
from Dire Straits "Money for Nothing". After that, I felt kind of
unclean :).

Well, at least I can understand get down to the funky beat. I never
understood "Come on!" Am I being chided to dance, or dance harder? Or
is he speaking to "the band", telling them to pick it up a bit? "Come
on" and mix this song out? :)

Is it ironic if there's no melody playing when the man is singing
"Music music music music music..."?

Is there any "Hi-NRG" out there with a harder edge and no goofy
choruses?

Any cure for DJ disease?

Sean

> > 
> > I'd also like to point out that anal sex is the riskiest sexual practice, 
> > but one that is performed by hets as well. So where are all the women 
> > with KS?
> > 
> a friendly interjection from your safer sex advocate: "unprotected" anal
> sex (without some sort of barrier) is a ~high~ risk sexual practice, not
> necessarily the riskiest.  The nature of the risk, and to whom the risk
> is present varies on the exact nature of the anal sex involved.  it has
> been demonstrated that fisting (vaginal or anal) without a barrier presents 
> a high risk to the insertive partner (somewhat counterintuitive), while 
> penis/anus sex presents a higher risk to the recipient.  Note that this 
> "risk assessment" is largely in the context of HIV.  Various other kinds 
> of STDs can be contracted, on an equal basis, by either partner.  The 
> highest risk sexual practice I can imagine is sharing blood or blood products 
> in some way, shape, or form (hence the general concern for folks who share 
> needles used for injecting IV drugs of whatever kind).
> 
> Barriers (condoms, dental dams, vinyl gloves, saran wrap, finger cots,
> stubbies) dramatically reduce the probability of transmission of STDs,
> including HIV, regardless of the sexual activity one engages in.  
> 
> Learn to love latex!  Don't share works (or at least clean them properly)!
> Know your partner (get that phone number for later reference)! Know your
> own body! Be informed, and make informed, conscious choices about the
> risks you choose to take. 
> -- 
> ====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========
> 
What you just said, Bryce, is what I would have (and partly did) say. 
Thanx for your post.

The reason I said that anal sex was "the riskiest" is because it is the 
easiest method of HIV transmission. The tissues of the rectum are 
delicate and can become torn easily.

I had no idea, however, that the fister was more at risk than the fistee!
Learn something new every day...

I believe in safer sex; I used to give away condoms at the clubs I went to.
Unfortunately, I can't learn to love latex; I'm *very* allergic to it. I 
can't even have it on my *hands* for long, let alone put my mouth on it. 

That is one of the reasons I had to stop working at Mr.S Leathers... to 
dye leather, latex gloves are essential.

Forgive me for not going into the detail that you did -- I was extremely 
tired. I was also expecting to be flamed by folks yelling "OFF TOPIC!", 
and I wasn't sure if I would be stepping on someone's toes by the whole 
subject -- as I'm pretty new to the list, I don't know how much safer sex 
has been discussed herein.

But anyway, thank you for your concise posting. It is very much 
appreciated. I think I'll file it for later use :)


Maui

on the nod than someone freaking on psychoactives for the next 8 hours...

> "Ooooh, stick em(?), ah ah, stick em" what is that?
"Listen to the Drummer" by Nation 12.  It's on an old Rhythm King compilation
called "Beat This" (not to be confused with a different Rhythm King compilation
called "Beat Dis").  I found a CD of "Beat This" in Rasputin's used CD section 
a while back.  Both "Beat Dis" and "Beat This" feature old house classics from
the likes of Bomb the Bass and S-Express.

> Remember "bass line kickin' yes I'm groovin'............bass line 
> kickin'    bass line kickin'"  
That's "Londres Strut" by Smells Like Heaven (and it's on the Cowboy Records 
double-CD compilation).

"Maui-Your Sister's House" writes:
 > That "brrrrr - stick 'em -ha ha ha - stick 'em" sample is from the Nation 
 > 12. 
 > 
 > Sean, what is the complete name of that? Susan gave her copy to you, so I 
 > have imperfect recall of the exact title/artist.

Nation 12, "Remember".

The good track is the B-side, "Listen to the Drummer". Susan must have
sold hers, because I bought mine at Primal. Funny thing is, I never
would have associated the sample with any sort of violence had Susan
not explained what it's sampled from. I wonder how many partygoers are
the same? (Out of context, that sample could be about football or
someone with lots of post-it notes...)

If a sample--even from a nasty source--is sufficiently vague or out of
context, then it won't disturb my sensibilities.  I'm not into hate
and violence, and my records reflect that. I like songs that are fun
and that make my butt move :).

There is room, however, once in a while, for anger and a
non-destructive channeling of that dark energy and frustration that
builds inside us.  Sometimes what I want to evoke is an overwhelming
insane sick dark energy primal scream mindfuck dance into oblivion.

Who said purification couldn't be fun? :)

Sean

> *I would really like to see this good drug/bad drug thang go away!* I for 


Hey, i could care less what drugs you do, until it affects *me*...now, 
i'm coming from a strictly east coast point of view...but i've been to 
enough parties where only half the people are dancing and the other half 
are on the floor drooling because they've fallen into a K hole. I *kills* 
the vibe, obliterates it, and really has no place, as far as i'm 
concerned, in this scene. the good drug/bad drug thing, for me, is based 
on the risk taken when taking these drugs. you can be safe with E or 
acid, when you know the dealer and have seen people on the same 
stuff..but with smack, who knows? it's too risky. (as an aside, a very 
good friend who just did not get the fucking picture recently od'd after 
repeated wake-up calls. )
the bottom line is, i like to go to raves/parties where there are alot of 
smiling happy friendly people there having a good time, not numbed-up 
zombies.
mikebee

Subject: Re: amylen nitrate DO NOT USE!

> What is amylen nitrate? what is it made of, where does it come from, what
> does it do, does it trash you out like speed?

> Amylen nitrate are 'poppers'. 

Please take my advice and DO NOT USE THIS SHIT!  When I was a kid I became
very addicted to the crap and ended up trashing my immune system (as it
breaks it down) suffered extreme physical and mental breakdowns from it and
was pretty much bed ridden for over 6 months.  I though it was really kewl at
the time but of all the stuff I've put in my body, I can truly say I wish I'd
never have touched the shit.  Years later now, with a reasonably clean mind,
I have gone back to school and have noticed the effects of its use and think
I really suffered from it.  I know it is legal in many states, but if you
really think about it, and what is happening when you do the stuff I think
you'll understand.  I feel very, very strongly against these and very rarely
makes posts, but I couldn't help making one on this subject.  Thanks for your
time!
Quinton

[re: Geoff White talks about Full Moon and the shut down by Ms. Ranger]

I was wondering where the system was set up in relation to the parking
lot up at Goat Rock.  From what I recall of the New Moon so long ago was
that it was over a mile down along the beach.  I remember Ms. Ranger
discovering the party way into the morning and being totally cool about
it.  One thing about the beach a mile down is there is a huge cliff face
that has got to do something about keeping the sound down at sea level.
I don't know why there hasn't been another new moon at that site again,
but I sure wish there was.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

Coke.  (I regret I can make that reference.  Talk about a vibe-less drug...)

as well.  Save your money...

Another wooley argement about legalization.  Heroin is a fucked-up drug, 
make no mistake about that.  I know people who have got addicted after 
one hit in just te same way that I have known poeple to get addicted to 
ciggerettes after just one pack.
By saying what you are saying you ared oing what our opponants do which 
is to lump all drugs into one catogory where it is either all illegal or 
all legal.  Crack, heroin and cocaine mess you up and are to dangerious 
to be taken by the general poulance on a regular basis.  Pot, LSD and E 
on the other hand are very safe drugs which have a positive effect on 
large groups of people and they should be the ones who are legalized.
It is very easy to make sweeping statements but it only really has the 
effect of causing ignorance which are opponants feed off and use as an 
excuse to justify there arguments.
In short, subtlety and depth of perception is what you really need.
Mr. Trippy October 1994.
Keiper@itsa.ucsf.edu


On Fri, 16 Sep 1994, JUMP IN THE FIRE wrote:

> 
> > You know, heroin isn't especially dangerous in itself. It takes a long
> > time to get addicted, and most people who use it don't get addicted at
> > all. Compare to tobacco, where 9 out of 10 people who ever smoked a
> > cigarette are still smoking.
> 
> Heroin and tobacco both must be taken daily (pack-a-day or more for cigs)
> for 1-2 months before physical addiction sets in.  However, once this
> happens, even if you quit, _one dose_ will jump-start your addiction
> right back up.
> 
> The figure for crack is 5 in 10.  All are addictive -- I think the
> difference can be explained by relative availability.  I support
> legalization, but don't fool myself into thinking _less_ people
> would shoot up if it were legal; less people would die, though, which
> is the important thing.
> 
> > The only thing really dangerous about it is that there's no quality
> > control.  Are you getting a dose, or 200 doses, or 2000 doses? Care to
> > bet your life on it?
> 
> More importantly, what is it cut with?  Quinine is common and also
> very nasty.
> 
> You can't have a war on drugs; you can only have a war on people.
> 
> // g
>

Here are the directions for the free party tonight:

Get to the 580 West towards Richmond (so cross the Bay Bridge if you're
coming from SF) Exit Castro St., which is the last exit before the Richmond
bridge. Turn right on Castro and follow it for awhile. It will curve to the
right and turn into Richmond Pkwy after awhile. Stay on this and turn right
on Parr. (I think you have to turn ithr right or left there) Turn left on
Goodrick (it's fairly soon) and left again on Freethy. It's at the end of
Freethy on the left side. Park inside the gate.

We'll get going around 10.

On Sat, 22 Oct 1994, Maui-Your Sister's House wrote:

> Yeah, I hear ya on the zombie thang -- but that seems to me to be *(once 
> again)* to be a problem with the idiot who came to that party in the 
> 
> As for smack, well, once again, that is a people problem. 

 People problem indeed !  We need to educate ourselves and simply 
 drawing arbitrary lines like:

  These are the GOOD drugs ....

  But these are the BAD drugs just won't work.

 Human biological variation just will NOT allow it..

 For example: I personally am VERY allergic to alcohol. If I have even
 a very small quantity I get an incredible headache within a very short
 period of time. So much for alcohol being an acceptable drug FOR ME. I
 always let others check their own responses and make their OWN rules
 about it for THEMSELVES - they aren't me. Also, for years ( even tho'
 I'm a chemist ) I didn't know what "crack" really was - I figured it
 must have been something I had NEVER done because I heard all this 
 stuff about "INSTANT ADDITION". Then I learned it was free based coke.
 Oh is that all!!! was my thought since I've done free base several
 times and found it "BORING AS SHIT for the price". Luckily, I never paid
 for it since I was getting it uncut from a dealer when he was turning
 a group of us friends on from his private stash. So for my body the
 quick addiction theory of coke doesn't apply - for others it might.

 And on it goes.

 As far as addictions go:

 How about "addictions" to foods? I know these are not TRUE addictions 
 but I know more people killing themselves with foods that are "heart
 attack on a plate" than are killing themselves with drugs. Of the 7
 chemistry professors at my school 3 have had bypass surgery. Yeah!
 Let's outlaw fats in the diet above 30%. ;-) 


 Bottom line IMHO is: It really should NOT be the providence of ANY
 government to legislate how and why someone treats their body a 
 certain way - especially when they are doing so in private. Laws that
 affect the common good like - not driving while intoxicated I can
 accept since that has a direct impact on others. But I am very tired
 of laws preventing suicides for terminally ill, "un-natural sex acts"
 between conscenting adults, explorations of consciousness altering 
 through drugs etc. These are things that governments in past centuries
 did not worry about ( in general ). 

 So my vote is : Let's have MUCH more of the FREEDOM our country is
 famous for ( at least in the "myths" that our culture expounds ) and
 far, far LESS of the tyranny of a small group of people deciding which
 things are GOOD and which are BAD for everybody else around them.

 'Nuf said!


 Mike Clay

 PS Kill Your TV was KIILER.  TV's smashed with various destructive tools,
  bowling balls, dropped from roofs, driven through by a car. Then the
  SRL finale - one of the BIGGEST, BADDEST, SHIT-KICKING flame throwers
  I've ever seen. Two fires later - they were isolated from ANY other
  structures and ground debris BTW - 3 fires trucks from SF arrived with
  various police and support vehicles. Hundreds of people, firemen
  squirting flames, wrecked TV debris - dead TV body parts scattered 
  everywhere. When the Cacophony Society throws a party - they go all out.
  See the video - F&F IV Sat Oct 29.....



 meclay@netcom.com          |  Alone & estatic 
 Mike Clay   (415)572-8971  |  A young rainbow learns  to levitate.

I just wanted to thank everyone who came to Megatripolis last night... 
saw lots of sfravers, met some *new* sfravers for the first time :)

And the DJ's -- Jen, Laura, Tracey, and Charlotte --- we were so glad to 
have you all spinning in front of the YSH banner :)

It *was* rather odd to have the security people doing their trip in the 
midst of the party; but then, considering what the City gov. is doing to 
the SoMa clubs, it didn't surprise me. They weren't particularly enjoying 
what they were doing, or at least it didn't seem so to me.

It's so ironic -- my last job (and Susan's) was working for a nightclub, 
but it took about 3 weeks for us to make us feel kinda alien if we went 
to them :p ...

Thank all of you who came and participated -- Bryce, Mark Ameba, 
ravnbird, mike (thanx for showing me Netscape), michael clay, cindy and 
greg, shana, Aaron & Jen, Lee Fogel, and all the others that I am leaving 
out 'cause I'm rather tired  |-]

Kaht, and supposedly it makes people impotent and really polite after a 
long time-at least that was what the brochure said( I swear I'm not 
making this up). I tried it and it's really this lizard like high that 
makes you feel kinda hollow-pretty kool but scary-One thing:
IT BURNS LIKE FUKKING HELL-AAAHHHHHHHHH....-DEADLY BUDA

Maui posted recently - 
> 
> And the DJ's -- Jen, Laura, Tracey, and Charlotte --- we were so glad to 
> have you all spinning in front of the YSH banner :)
 - I want to thank THEM for mixing so well. !
> 
> It *was* rather odd to have the security people doing their trip in the 
> midst of the party; but then, considering what the City gov. is doing to 
> the SoMa clubs, it didn't surprise me.
 I don't know what particular events Maui was refering to , but I did see one 
of the security guys buttonhole some guy in the restroom for exchanging money
for something from a little leather bag. Sorta stealth security , as they 
didn't seem to be wearing any staff id badges last night. On the other
hand , the "plainclothes" look is less visually intrusive.

-------------------------------

 I got there fairly early , so I got to hear Jen do her atmospheric thing
to start the evening. She eventually stirred in chunks of dance-rythm 
stuff , gradually moving into total dance music. Interesting.

 The guy DJing upstairs ( anybody know his name? ) started with a mix of
socio-political-philosophical monologues blended with spacy ambient/industrial
music. Kinda LOUD too , which was unfortuate , since some of the only couches 
upstairs were located right in from of one of the speaker stacks.

 A little after Laura took over the turntables downstairs , I crossed the 
street to the "lounge" to listen to a lecture called "Better Sex Through
Chemistry" from a fellow named Dan Joy , the coauthor of a soon-to-be published
book of the same title as the lecture. With the aid of two asisstants named
Cathia and Riana , and the simulataneous projection of a masturbation video
starring his research assistant Leslis Wiston , Mr. Joy presented us with
a very informal lecture. 

 The topic of his lecture was not aphrodisiacs , which act to increase or
initiate libido - his book was devoted to chemicals which enhance the 
body's sexual ability. Some that were mentioned were GHB , bromocryptine ,
dopamine , and yohimbe.

 I got back to the dance floor at the end of Laura's set. I stayed to dance
for about an hour of Tracey's set , then I had to head home. 

 I HAD A GREAT TIME! I don't know if it was a combination of Wizard Smoke (tm)
( more about that smokable in a future post ), some catnaps I was able to get
at a friend's house , or the great music , or the great crowd , or what , but
last night was just RIGHT. Nice trance dancing .

	THANK YOU to Your Sister's House , Megatripolis/Frazier Clark ,
		and even the Trocadero !

	Larry Ching / larryc@netcom.com
s

X-Mailer: UGate [Ver. 1.94]

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


> Crack, heroin and cocaine mess you up and are to dangerious 
> to be taken by the general poulance on a regular basis.  Pot, LSD and E 
> on the other hand are very safe drugs which have a positive effect on 
> large groups of people and they should be the ones who are legalized.

How can you possibly say that LSD should be legalized on the basis of 
it being more dangerous than LSD?! There IS such a thing as a lethal 
dose of LSD. I imagine that the same can be said of E as well. 
Granted, these substances have the POTENTIAL to instigate positive 
mental states, much more so than H or C tho' it is NOT entirely 
impossible to experience positive mental change with the use of 
Heroin, Cocaine, or Crack. I think it probably has a lot to do with 
the reason behind your explorations in the first place...are you 
doing to HIDE from something, or are you doing it to DISCOVER 
something? Are you doing it as an excuse to hurt someone else, or to 
experience a wider spectrum of what "life" means,  being cautious not 
to harm anyone else during your explorations?

I can't believe that you could support the legalization of substances 
that impair judgement so incredibly, yet substances that only impair 
judgement minorly you think should be outlawed entirely. What logic 
allows you to think this way?

From sfraves-owner  Sun Oct 23 23:25:49 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves

	id XAA02008; Sun, 23 Oct 1994 23:22:51 -0700
Date: Sun, 23 Oct 1994 23:22:50 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Maui-Your Sister's House" <ysh@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Heroin & tobacco...
To: Kevin Keiper <keiper@itsa.ucsf.EDU>
cc: JUMP IN THE FIRE <grigsby@agames.com>, sfraves@hyperreal.com
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9410220932.A17676-0100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9410232203.A20507-0100000@netcom9>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I know people who have got addicted after 
> one hit in just te same way that I have known poeple to get addicted to 
> ciggerettes after just one pack.

"Addiction" is is not a medically justifiable term for this phenomenon.

Where are these folks now? I've never met anyone who has actually said 
that about themselves...

> By saying what you are saying you ared oing what our opponants do which 
> is to lump all drugs into one catogory where it is either all illegal or 
> all legal.  Crack, heroin and cocaine mess you up and are to dangerious 
> to be taken by the general poulance on a regular basis. 

I agree with that to some extent, but that is a *personal* belief. 

I find the mere concept of laws that are supposed to *protect you from 
yourself* utterly appalling. How can anyone tell me what I can and cannot do, 
when it doesn't affect the person or property of another?

 Pot, LSD and E 
> on the other hand are very safe drugs which have a positive effect on 
> large groups of people and they should be the ones who are legalized.

I'll try to remember that, but my short-term memory doesn't seem to work 
anymore ;)   (cough, cough)

Drugs ARE NOT "negative" or "positive". I find that certain people should 
stay away from certain drugs, yes. But I have had good, even rapturous 
experiences with everything I've ever done, (except an accidental PCP dose 
in a joint) and I wouldn't trade those experiences for anything.

I am curious why certain substances are pc or not pc in the "scene" -- 
everyone is like "Ooohh... don't go near meth, oooohh... it's so 
*baaaaad*....

Well, hell, anything is, if you overdo it! That includes E and herb. MDMA 
*is* somewhat neurotoxic, for example. 
And herb, though I think it's a blessing, helps alot of people to never 
get off their butt and *do* something with their life. Herb, like *all* 
drugs, can be used as a place to hide.

And as far as the meth/E/acid thing -- all three of these build up 
tolerance very rapidly. You can keep doing them, but they will cease to 
get you high. 

My personal belief is:  I am an adult. I am responsible for all of my 
decisions. I do not need and do not want Big Brother or any other 
patriarchal construct telling me what I am allowed to do with my mind 
or my body.

<rant mode off>

Thanks for your time |-]

Maui






> Mr. Trippy October 1994.
> Keiper@itsa.ucsf.edu
> 
> 
> On Fri, 16 Sep 1994, JUMP IN THE FIRE wrote:
> 
> > 
> > > You know, heroin isn't especially dangerous in itself. It takes a long
> > > time to get addicted, and most people who use it don't get addicted at
> > > all. Compare to tobacco, where 9 out of 10 people who ever smoked a
> > > cigarette are still smoking.
> > 
> > Heroin and tobacco both must be taken daily (pack-a-day or more for cigs)
> > for 1-2 months before physical addiction sets in.  However, once this
> > happens, even if you quit, _one dose_ will jump-start your addiction
> > right back up.
> > 
> > The figure for crack is 5 in 10.  All are addictive -- I think the
> > difference can be explained by relative availability.  I support
> > legalization, but don't fool myself into thinking _less_ people
> > would shoot up if it were legal; less people would die, though, which
> > is the important thing.
> > 
> > > The only thing really dangerous about it is that there's no quality
> > > control.  Are you getting a dose, or 200 doses, or 2000 doses? Care to
> > > bet your life on it?
> > 
> > More importantly, what is it cut with?  Quinine is common and also
> > very nasty.
> > 
> > You can't have a war on drugs; you can only have a war on people.
> > 
> > // g
> >

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 24 01:19:54 1994

From: "'Dave Bayer'" <dlb@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
Subject: Re: Heroin & tobacco...
To: SFRaves! <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
In-Reply-To: <Pine.3.89.9410220932.A17676-0100000@itsa.ucsf.edu>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9410240137.A8095-0100000@fallingrocks.berkeley.edu>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



On Sat, 22 Oct 1994, Kevin Keiper wrote:

> Another wooley argement about legalization.  Heroin is a fucked-up drug, 
> make no mistake about that.  I know people who have got addicted after 
> one hit in just te same way that I have known poeple to get addicted to 
> ciggerettes after just one pack.

	This is a problem with the people, why they are doing the drug, 
and/or the information upon which they are making the decision to take 
the drug. Addiction to e and pot and happen as fast as addiction to 
herion or coke in the psychological sense which is what I assume you are 
speaking of since one hit (this is a vague term) cannot elevate levels in 
your body for a long enough time for a physical dependence to set in. And 
in my opinion, the psychological dependcies/additicions/cravings are much 
harder to initially recongize, and then overcome. 

> By saying what you are saying you ared oing what our opponants do which 
> is to lump all drugs into one catogory where it is either all illegal or 
> all legal.  Crack, heroin and cocaine mess you up and are to dangerious 
> to be taken by the general poulance on a regular basis.  Pot, LSD and E 
> on the other hand are very safe drugs which have a positive effect on 
> large groups of people and they should be the ones who are legalized.

	Making a distinction between safe and unsafe things to put in 
ones body is not a binary distinction (ie, it is not either safe or 
unsafe). Nor are any drugs safe or unsafe. Pot, LSD, and e have nearly as 
many potential negative side effects as coke or herion (nearly and 
especially if one includes e as it has an methamphetamine hanging off the 
benzene ring). Granted the drugs can faciliate attaining different 
states, but who is to judge which are good and which are bad and place 
that over decision on the liberities of other people). The argument that 
cigs and alocohol are legal so pot and e should be too falls away if you 
do not include coke and smack in those to be legalized. 
	In general, it is not the drug itself which needs to be outlawed, 
but instead, it us who need to look at why their is a feeling that the 
drug NEEDS to be outlawed. If it is a question about the potential for 
abuse, then it is not the drug which needs help but the people who 
might/do abuse it. 
	Drugs are a question of personal responsibility, and people need 
a source of information that is reliable. A long time ago, when Leary was 
still in Harvard doing some really good research and had some other 
really good ideas, he spoke of an alternate type of drug education in 
which people were told of the clinical studies, what they seemed to mean, 
how to identify the drugs and the such. He discussed changing the FDA to 
the Food and Drug Advisory, which left the ultimate choice up to the 
individual, where it belongs.

dave

On Sun, 23 Oct 1994, Alissa Feinberg wrote:

> I can't believe that you could support the legalization of substances 
> that impair judgement so incredibly, yet substances that only impair 
> judgement minorly you think should be outlawed entirely. 

	Drugs impair judgement. This I am not sure I agree with. Maybe 
they impair judgement in reference to the decisions you might come to 
when sober, but does this mean they impair judgement? And what if they 
open your eyes to something you were forgetting when you making decisions 
before. Were previous decisions impaired? Granted some drugs impair your 
ability to make a quick decision, but I do not think that any drug will 
make you decide something that was in you before you were on that drug. 
Whether you allow yourself the excuse of 'I am high/drunk/amped so I need 
not take this and this and this into consideration' or 'I am high/etc so 
I will just do things and not think about what I am doing' is the 
over-riding concern.

dave

Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Alissa Feinberg writes:

>This stuff you're calling "Kaht": is it at all related to Ketamine,
>a.k.a. KrazyKat, Kitty, VitaminK? Ketamine is a veterinary medicine,
>usually used to sedate (supposedly an anaesthetic) cats during
>surgery.

Ketamine is a completely different thing than "kaht".  The chemical
components found in Kaht are of the phenylethylamine family (same chemical
family as in ecstasy), which are amphetamine-related mild stimulants.
Ketamine is a powerful anaesthetic which, upon their ingestion, deadens the
entire body but leaves your mind conscious (it has been described as an
out-of-body experience).  Basically you lie immobile (on the ground, bed,
whatever) while your mind is completely somewhere else.

Don't take ketamine under the assumption that you're taking a "kaht" based
drug.  The difference between the two will be rather dramatic.

I have been informed that ketamine mixed with a speedball (heroin & coke
injection) is rather popular in certain drug circles.  Ketamine itself was
(or maybe still is?) popular in England, I have heard.

For me, my days of drug excesses are over.  If I could make a suggestion, I
would like to see some threads pointing away from drug-use and perhaps
continuing discussion about some other non-chemical interests of the scene?
Music?  Friendships?  Politics?


jack

From: crunch@netcom.com (John Draper)

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: Full Moon Madness in Northern Calif
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Full Moon Madness in Northern Calif
-----------------------------------

  Well,  I'm a little late in reporting on the Full Moon rave,  but as usual,
our faschist authorities have gone above and beyond the call of duty to spoil
our fun.    After getting set up shortly after 3 am,   I finally got to hear
that new WICKED sound system (Probably not at full volume).    It only took
about an hour before the ranger told us to turn it down.    So,  after
adjusting the speaker system to minimize sound in the direction of the
complainer,   the music started to get turned up again.

  Shortly after that,  in less than an hour,  we were told to leave.   Mark,
from Ameba suggested a vacent campground not far away,   so we all wait in our
cars for the sound truck to get loaded,  with the intent of following it to
the new site.    On the way,   we notice that the truck failed to notice the
turnoff,  and was heading out in the wrong direction.    I would estimate about
75 cars in the caravan.     Certainly very noticable.    By this time,  it was
getting daylight (About 6:30 - 7:00 am).    Eventually,  the truck stopped by
the side of the road,   everyone else pulling over,  or just stopping in the
middle of the road.    The early commuters,  heading east were probably very
pissed off,  as  the road was blocked off for about a half hour.

  Eventually,  someday,  the authorities might soon recognize the fact that
by busting a peaceful rave is going to cause MORE safety problems,  then to
let it continue.

  Everyone made a U turn,  and headed back to the turnoff.   The sound truck
continued on to get gas,  then eventually made it to the campground.   The
grounds were an absolutly perfect site.    By about 7:30 or 8am,  the music
continued for about an hour,  until eventually a ranger showed up.    They
were met by the WICKED crew,   but this ranger didn't know how to deal with
our group of people,  so radioed for instructions.    There was a dispute 
about having to pay $2 for parking,  so the WICKED people took up the
collection and continued negotiating with the ranger.

   Eventually,  the head ranger showed up and explained that the music coundn't 
continue for insurance purposes,  and explained the permit process.   So we
decided to stay there all day long (At least until 4 pm.    I got to spend 
a lot of time with Tracy (I met her at the Russian River rave last weekend),
and a few times before that.   We had a great time,  enjoying a perfect
day in this wonderful campground,  hanging out in the woods,   hiking and
schmoozing around.

  Saturday afternoon I spent ALL DAY doing Yoga Thai chi,  and other exercises
to remove a weeks worth of energy blockages after sitting at the computer all
week.    I can't have these blockages running around my body,   sapping my
energy,    especially at a rave.    After all,   I get my energy this way.

   You see,  I just discovered the really neat place not far from where I live,
thats out in this grove of huge redwood trees.  Largely unoccupied,  and
a great place to do yoga and be with nature.   Getting large doses of nature,
yoga,  and thai chi goes a long ways in helping me deal with the city,  raving,
and dancing long hours without getting tired.

  This weekend,  was SCHWA (An underground party),   Megatripolus,  and 
some other unnamed party,  was sheduled.   I volunteered to manage the Internet
room at Mega again.   Hey!!   Whatever happened to that dude who was supposed
to set up the WWW station?    Thanx David,  for saving the day!!   Yay!!  we
had our WWW station.... Later on,  I learned that SCHWA got busted.   BUMMER!!

    This week at Mega,  featured "Your Sisters House" DJ's,   and
it was like OLD TIMES last year.   Yay!...      Laura layed down
the most insane hard acid trance I've heard in a long time.   Having an
over abundance of energy that evening,  I pulled out all the stops,  and
went totally insane,  digging the music to the max,  stopping ONLY to cool
down.    All the "Sisters" did great behind the turntables,  as the music
was pumpin big time.    My only regrets were that 6 am finally came all
to quickly (sigh!).   So after a big breakfast,   I eventually head home
to meet some friends before making it out to Sunset.    I yearn for a rave
that goes well into the next day.  For me,   24 hours of raving is just
about right.   This 8 hour stuff is for the weenies,  and I'm sick of
spending my after rave hours at the EndUp.   You see,   when I'm out
there raving,  I'm a man with a mission.    My mission is to have a big
smile,   have eye contact with people,   get them to smile back,  and
I give them my energy and love.   At the EndUp,  thats  lot harder to do...

   Again,  this weekend,   I stayed awake from Friday morning until Sunday
evening,  and am now so used to it,   that I no longer feel sorta sluggish
on Mondays anymore.    I just get up at the normal time (about 8:30AM)
and I find that I feel really loose,  and have lots of energy in the
morning.    The last time I slept on a weekend,   sometime in early
September,   I find that I don't feel as well when I wake up.   So,
to rid yourself of the Monday blues,   get out there and rave ALL WEEKEND!!!

   Sunset,  this time was at the Berkeley Aquatic park.    By the time
I arrived (4 pm),  the music was going,  and about 150 fine folks were
out there,  having a great time.     Just after sunset,  a cop showed up,
and was met by one of the Sunset folks,   then eventually went away.  WOW!
It DIDN'T get busted?   I learned that we had a whole half hour left to
go.    Solar was behind the tuntables,  and layed down some great housey
trancey tunes.    The music eventually stopped,   but started up again
with one last song.   By that time,  it was totally dark,  so I headed
back to SF to check out that Ambience party at 1190 Folsom.   Learned
that it was starting at 10 pm,   but with it being 8 pm,    I thought
about hanging out at the Endup,   but decided to head back home.

  Next week....  Friends and Family!!    Yay!!  Also Funkey Techno Tribe!!
Holloween special..... Oh goodie!!   I can hardly wait... It will be the 
first time I'll hear Sean spin....

-- CC --


From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 24 12:09:03 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id MAA17040; Mon, 24 Oct 1994 12:09:03 -0700
Received: from mercury.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id MAA17030; Mon, 24 Oct 1994 12:08:56 -0700

	id AA05322; Mon, 24 Oct 1994 12:08:56 -0700
Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 12:08:55 -0700 (PDT)
From: Sun Kim <sunkim@mercury.sfsu.edu>
Subject: Ambient Jungle in GG Park
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9410241117.A1208-0100000@mercury>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
content-length: 2321
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

I got there as they were setting up the Ambient Jungle sign on a tree.  
Quite a feat to try to hang that thing on a tree.  I must have gotten 
there a little after the first DJ started.  Great sound system and what I 
thought was good weather.  Not too bright, but occassional spots of 
clouds and wind to cool me down.  

I don't know who the DJs were but I enjoyed them.  The first DJ, played 
some really wonderful music.  Lots of happy sounds.  Even played the 
Moodswings song with the MLK Jr. Speech, but it unfortunately got 
scratched up and didn't get to hear it finished.  I had a giant smile on 
my face as the song played... but dropped to a giant disappointment as 
the song unexpectedly stopped.  

When the second DJ came on, the record that was put on was a fast
breakbeat track.. kinda spacey.  I thought was this the Jungle part of
Ambient Jungle?  But the DJ (completely shaved head, with English (?)
accent, kinda reminded me of Frankie Bones).  As he was playing his 
ambient tracks, he inserted sound bites from the first landing on the 
moon.  He kept the theme going until his set was over.  I had never heard 
this done before and thought it was interesting. 

The third DJ came on and put on a reggae track.  His set (which I didn't 
all of) seemed a bit more dark.  I left around 4 so I don't know what the 
rest of his set sounded like. 

I thought the reason why the DJs played non-ambient tracks in between 
sets was so that people knew it was a diff. DJ.  I honestly wouldn't have 
known it was a different DJ.  I've never hard these DJs before and I'm 
not very trained with ambient to know "styles."

People showed up with wine, cheese, strawberries, bread.. a picnic.  Some
girls were passing out little flowers to everyone, Don & Noah were
drumming to the music.  All sorts of people: cyclers, in-line skaters,
ravers, asian family barbecuing, parents playing ball with their
daughter... a very good mix of people I thought.  Got to meet a new
friends and talk with some old ones.  I had a good time.  Never thought
I'd go to an exclusively 'ambient' event.. but it was free and fun.  No
one played volleyball or frisbee.. but I thank the promoters for having
thought of water and things to do. 

(Didn't make it out to Sunset.. I'm sure it was good.)

Sun			sunkim@mercury.sfsu.edu

i must say, this weekend was one of the most fun i've had since moving 
out here...

first, doug mike and i went to joe rice's party...the location was quite 
neat-o...i'm not sure how to describe it...we got there around 
12:30...met troy...made some nice new friends there, but around 1:30 it 
was busted by the police...there were 5 or 6 patrol cars there...a little 
bit much considering how many people were there...maybe 40 or so...
so after that, we were told to head out to the schwa party which i think 
was their unofficial back up site...the vibe there was pretty 
incredible...everyone was very friendly...i very much liked it...
around 5:30 schwa was busted...

so we headed back home, hung out, boogie woogied, went to sleep...woke
up and went to ambient jungle...aj was very nice and mellow, i just love 
this whole sunset/aj/outdoor action :)

see you soon


-John

Geoff waxed:
>The ranger WAS very nice with us and no one gave her any attitude, even
>when she came back, no one was rude.  (she must have felt safe, she was
>alone on both trips and didn't feel the need for police assistance or
>anything, even though there were over 150 people there.
 
"Right on, excellent, thank you all who came down and didn't trash the
guard" love to hear that on the wicked line...

Why shouldn't she feel safe? A bunch of people in overalls and smiling and
dancing is not a threat to a sound, peaceful mind. Especially when no glass
objects are to be seen. But yeah, I love it when no-one boos or sez "fok u,
pigz". I'm shure 50% of the time they feel like you did when you were a kid
and had to follow mom's arbitrary orders ("tell your friends to leave!")
and dissapoint your buddies. It must not be fun to bust a party, unless
it's a personal dick  thang/power trip (refer to  oakland/sf cops).

Anyone at antioch's moon can remember how much stronger the party got when
we talked the cops into letting us stay. They loved our getups and I gues
watching girls in skirts at 2 am wasn't so bad for them, either. It shure
wasn't at July's infinity (carlos, garth, dutch..), where the cops actually
got a date (takes all kinds, some people just have a badge fettish). I get
a kick giving stickers to real PEACE officers. 

Lotsa love, 
 Milton and the E-Bee...

ps. Maybe next time, we should have a small snack stand, with cold-cut
sandies and donuts and coffee, and invite them to join us?

subjects, or so I have been told.  Someone please correct me if I am
sadly mistaken!)

net.  The wires do have ears occasionally.  Now, I *do* have a Friend
Of A Friend who tried _____ and HE says........ :-)

Date: Mon, 24 Oct 1994 13:59:08 -0700
Message-Id: <199410242059.NAA18535@nature.Berkeley.EDU>
To: <ken@snowcrest.net>
Subject: pistachio addiction
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Mijos, I received this from a lurker in Petaluma, and thought I should
forward it due to the recent"good drug/bad drug" debate:

Recently, US news and World report ran a series on addictive beer
synergists. It was found that casual and habitual brew chortlers regularly
employed chips, stale popcorn (styrofoam was often sold in pocorn's place
by dubious dealers), pretzels, peanuts, and of course, pistachios, in their
rituals and social gatherings.

Barry Q., a truck driver from Minnesota, destroyed his marriage and
waistline, as well as his fecal texture, due to the "GREEN NUT". The dye
used to redden the shells, when sold at popular outlets such as Sears, has
been implicated in finger staining and may be absorbed directly thru cotton
gloves, latex being the only effective barrier. 

Many claim that peanuts are a softer high, due to the traditional  removal
of the shell. The EPA has also reported that several rivers in NY state are
clogged with the Pist-shells.

Syrian and Turkish contraband of pistachios has fueled a multi-million
dollar war on nuts, which has only resulted in higher street prices,
leading afficionados and addicts alike to lives of petty crimes,
prostitution and pope-abuse.

Although many, such as SF resident Ken R.(all names in the article were
changed), used the nut recreationally at first, at parties, dates or
reunions, the nut has made its way into the backpacks of many attendees of
the so called "rave", where people hide behind the protective shell of the
pistachio, refusing to face their real alimentary and dietary problems.

While many say pistachios contribute to expanding their pallate, and some
claim that the experience helped them appreciate all foods more, it is very
clear that beer drinking is but the first step leading to munchie
addiction. A move to regulate pistachio use, with a 21 and up  chewing age,
may not be the solution. Alternatives such as pocorn and fritos are still
legal, even purchaseable at quicky marts in bags.

Taxing of these products and use of that money to set up weight-loss and
dental clinics, the Clinton administration proposes, would not only
eliminate the street sale of inferior-even dangerous- products, but would
also generate millions in sale taxes.

Already in California, ever at the forefront of American tolerance, an
Amsterdam clause allows the liscensed selling (only) of peanuts and popcorn
at popular, massive gatherings, such as sporting events. The liscensing
eliminated 100% of munchie associated gang activities in Northern
california stadiums.

Just thought I should share this with everyone.....

Joe Turner writes:
 > Please, check and quote your source.  According to all the books I've
 > read, there is NO LD-50 for acid.  (A drug's "LD-50" refers to the
 > dosage that consistently causes death in at least 50% of the test
 > subjects, or so I have been told.  Someone please correct me if I am
 > sadly mistaken!)

That's true. There aren't enough people who have died of an LSD
overdose to create any sort of statistic. The current wisdom estimates
between 40,000 and 100,000 doses.

Medically, LSD is an extraordinarily safe drug, far safer than most
over the counter medicines. Even people who have overdosed so badly as
to depress their vital signs (by thinking a bag of pure LSD was
cocaine) recovered completely both mentally and physically within 48
hours. It's almost impossible to overdose on LSD in blotter form;
you'd have to eat several hundred sheets of blotter paper, and you'd
fill your stomach or visit God before that happened.

LSD can be a very wild ride, though, and the potential user is
cautioned to be fully informed about when it's advisable, what to
expect, and to have someone trustworthy around to guide them.

Sean

PS - Cannabis has a similar safety factor. LD-50 is estimated at
around 40,000 doses. That level of THC is virtually impossible to
attain via the usual methods. To date, there are no documented cases
of death due to overdose.

Continuation of this thread...

        I normally am not the sort who gets on a soapbox and make speeches,
but I definitely am the sort who stays up late watching the news until I
fall asleep. (ABC World News Now... the news show for insomniacs)

        Lately, I have been particularly disturbed by a proposition that is
on the California election ballot, Proposition 187.  This is the
proposition, if passed, that would deny public education and health
services to illegal immigrants.  Governor Pete Wilson has come out strongly
supporting this proposition, making it the cornerstone of his campaign.  If
passed, this proposition may be taken to Supreme Court, as it is currently
unconstitutional to deny illegal aliens schooling and social services.

        This proposition has caused many heated and passionate debates up &
down the state.  Personally, I believe Prop 187 is the start of a trend
that I find very disturbing, and if it is allowed to continue, it will
affect the very core of American society.

        This proposition could be an incredible disaster for law
enforcement, education, and health services for the state, and it will most
likely cost the state untold millions (instead of the "savings" to
taxpayers).  Law enforcement agencies, educators, and state health
officials have come out against the proposition, even well-known
conservative politicians such as Jack Kemp and William Bennet have
described this proposition as a misguided attempt.

        However, the proposition has been enjoying solid support in this
state, as it is backed by powerful conservative elements such as the
Christian right (Pat Buchanan's shock troops), as well as Pete Wilson.  I
believe the reason why the proposition does well in this state is that the
people it hurts the most (Latinos, Asians, children & young people, and
women) vote the least and/or can't vote.  This proposition also indicates a
trend towards growing xenophobic attitudes among our society.

        Can you imagine a schoolteacher having to kick out little
schoolchildren (using skin color as an indicator) and calling the INS on
their parents?  Frightening.

        On some level, it even affects our scene, as a number of our top SF
DJs are of English citizenship... :)  Markie... are you reading?  Sorry if
I got all preachy...

        Please give this Proposition a lot of thought.  I know that sfraves
is a diverse collective of young people who are part of a scene they
passionately care about.  I also hope that we should passionately care
about the diversity of our society as well, and I implore you to take those
passions with you to the ballot box this November.

        jack

        YOUTH + VOTE = POWER

Katharine Mary Nester writes:
 > On Mon, 24 Oct 1994, Sean Casey wrote:
 > first line accidentally deleted said something to the effect that LSD
 > was a very safe drug safer than
 > > over the counter medicines. Even people who have overdosed so badly as
 > > to depress their vital signs (by thinking a bag of pure LSD was
 > > cocaine) recovered completely both mentally and physically within 48
 > > hours. It's almost impossible to overdose on LSD in blotter form;
 > > you'd have to eat several hundred sheets of blotter paper, and you'd
 > > fill your stomach or visit God before that happened.

"Safer than most over the counter medicines."

 > I may be ignorant but i don't think that you can catagorize any drug as
 > "safe" if it doesn't kill most people. I think turning into a vegitable 
 > becuase you fried your brain is a fate worse than death. I know of at least
 > for of my firneds who ar decidely less intelligent because of their drug
 > use , and the drug they used was LSD. Any drug with the effect of making
 > you dumber, i don't think is safe.

LSD does not turn people into vegetables. It temporarily affects your
seratonergic reuptake, but it does not "fry your brain" (though it may
feel that way). It does not cause chromosome damage. It does not
contain strichnine.

There is no medical evidence that LSD causes any long term effects
whatsoever. No long term effects on cognition or recall. It is gone,
and I mean completely gone, within 4 days. If new evidence corrects
this, I'll be the first to post it.

LSD is medically contraindicated only in people who have latent
psychosis. This is not because LSD has any tendency to make people
psychotic; it does not. It is because LSD is usually a very intense
experience, and intense experiences are what tend to bring out a
psychosis.

People like to blame things on LSD but on closer look that the drug
may have been a factor, but not the cause. I see people throwing their
life away all the time, and they often use drugs, alcohol, or
obsessive activities to escape from the pain. They spiral down and
abuse themselves all sorts of ways. Blame it on drugs? What for? If
it's not one escape, it's another. Some people even (gasp) use
computers to escape, and even though using computers (presumably)
makes one smarter, no doubt someone feels it ruined a friend's life.
It's not even escape that's the problem (what is a vacation?), it's
_excess_ escape.

If LSD does have any long term effect, it is purely psychological. You
had an intense experience. Maybe for the first time you though about
things with your ego turned off. Maybe you saw things from a different
perspective. Maybe everything seemed new. Experiences like this make
one think, and most people report positive results with it. Some hate
it and never do it again.

LSD has been around for 50 years, and has been heavily used since the
60s. If there are any long term kinks, they must take more than 30
years to show up, because so far there is just no evidence of damage.

Sean

I realize that this "addiction" stuff is really getting old -- but if 
anyone out there wants some insight from a guy who has *really* "been 
there-done that", just start reading William S. Burroughs. Only a stone 
junkie can really tell ya what is going on there, and his insight into 
addiction and the whole phenomenon of drug use is quite valuable.

Maui

plus, he is just such a sick puppy -- the cool thing is, he *knows it*, 
and works with it.

> Maui spews:
> >My personal belief is:  I am an adult. I am responsible for all of my 
> >decisions. I do not need and do not want Big Brother or any other 
> >patriarchal construct telling me what I am allowed to do with my mind 
> >or my body.
> 
> As someone said in "Forbidden Love" (the canadian documenatry on the
> lesbian underground during the fifties and early sixties), "the world
> should be run by post-menopause women."

Now that I've got my hilarity under (hee hee) some control, I would like 
to elaborate, because I thought that this might come up.

The concept of a "patriarchal construct" really has nothing to do with 
either lesbians or lesbianism.

The term has been used, and quite widely I might add, to denote a social 
strucure in which the average person is placed in thrall to a figure of 
"worship" or whatever (this never did make much sense to me) that is 
outside of yourself, but supposedly contains *you*, nonetheless. It knows 
better than you do what you need, what you want, what is good, what is bad.
All terms are absolute. It is the Ultimate Because I Said So.

Female and Male have *nothing whatsoever* to do with this.


> and I'd say to myself, what a wonderful world........

(snicker snicker)

> 
> Buzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz from the E-Bee............
> 

(Okay, get me outta here -- I was about to make all kinda inappropriate   )
(remarks, but then I remembered I don't work at Mr. S Leathers anymore....)

Maui

i think the Greens have it right when they suggest an additional
  little checkbox on each issue/candidate to be voted for:
   
   NONE OF THE ABOVE [   ]

if this choice beats the candidates (har har) then that means that the
  election (for that post) must be re-cast, with NEW candidates; this
    gets rid of the 'lesser of two lizards' syndrome that politics is
      heading for, by GETTING THEM OUTTA THERE!!!
if yer active in yer respective party, push for the 'none of the above' 
  option on the ballot.  if you don't like who's running, you should
    have the option of venting your opinion, and IMHO, this is the best
      idea around...


seeya!

Dave SCruton

Greetings Friends!

Given that the discussion seems to be already well underway I thought I
might as well add my voice to the fray :)

Make no mistake... 

Friends & Family is going *off* this Saturday night!

Here are the details:

_____________________________________________________________________
DJs:
Lee, Susan, Sean Casey, Ethan, HDW, Graeme (LaPaix)
Jeff Taylor, Laura, Joe Rice, Deaks

Viusals:
Micheal Clay, Sean Casey & more...

Audio:
soundvision & liquid

$3 benefits Komotion 
415.985.5244 for more info
_____________________________________________________________________

I'm actually really glad that we're on the same night as FTT. Besides being
an established tradition :) it once again emphasizes exactly what we aim to
be: a *minimal* cost, intimate, all ages, techno-trancy *alternative* to
the larger and more expensive traditional sf parties. How nice that we have
so many wonderful choices :)

In other news: some small architectural changes at komotion have also
opened up the space in some nice ways and, while not yet perfect, we expect
ventilation to be greatly improved, though for those of you who like to
sweat (like me :) you should have no difficulty! As always, the sparsest of
attire (boxers and bras:) is recommended!

We stil need help in a variety of areas...if you can bring bean bags, art
supplies, butcher paper, stuffed animals, food, positive energy, or naked
guys or gals please do so. (I've actually got all the graffitti from the
last one! I'll transcribe and post it someday). As always we can use help
setting up, cleaning up etc. So if you'd like to be involved in any of
these or the above contexts, plese let us know.

look forward to seeing you all soon!
lots of love
ethan

::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::CHECK THE *NEW* ADDRESS:
::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::::  nrg@ultima.org

[Shameless plug]

The last F&F was a _rave_... totally insane! It was packed all night,
and yet that tremendous energy felt friendly. I never heard so much
hollering at one event :). This one has an outstanding (and
enthusiastic) DJ lineup, lots of great visuals planned, good attitudes
all around, free water, ins & outs, etc etc.

Go to both if you want...each will be a good party, and each has great
things to offer. I'd say go to F&F first as it usually starts up and
gets vibed in very early. And it's so cheap you can afford both. :)

Sean

More likely $25, which is what they charged for Futur.  

At Megatripolis, one of the guys handing out those hideous poster-sized
flyers for FTT told me that it'll be in the city at a warehouse near
Army & 3rd where a Cool World was once held.  The space doesn't sound
too familiar to me, and it doesn't sound like the Galleria, but my info
my be totally unreliable.  If you decide to go, be prepared for long lines
and the absolute zoo that big Halloween Sat. nite city parties tend to be.

But who knows, FTT could end up being a lot of fun.  But at the very least,
you will want to consider the F&F and Megatripolis parties as less 
chaotic, and perhaps vibier alternatives to where the masses are heading.

Lee

bass (the shame!) and narcs up the wazoo! The whole organic/ftt crowd was
there in the crowd, and carlos and jeno on the tables, great visuals, lousy
vibe. 

 But i am rambling. The warehouse had 2 anterooms, a mini-trampoline in one
of them, and a chill room in the back, must have been an office before.
Along one wall, a long row of portapotties, and the other, a loading dock
type thing for people to hide on/under. A very big warehouse, tho, everyone
will fit. Maybe it was my trip, or maybe the rafters did shake with the
music? 

I'll go the smaller way, methinks.

From sfraves-owner  Tue Oct 25 16:46:31 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA04723; Tue, 25 Oct 1994 16:46:31 -0700
Received: from ultima.org by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA04716; Tue, 25 Oct 1994 16:46:25 -0700
Message-Id: <199410252346.QAA04716@taz.hyperreal.com>
Subject: Oyster Bay Finale
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Tue, 25 Oct 1994 16:39:03 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Bryce Ryan" <brycer@ultima.org>
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
Content-Type: text
Content-Length: 3532
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

Greetings!

For those of you interested in the saga of the Oyster Bay 21:

The attorney, Bob Selvidge, has finally concluded his negotiations with
the courts at Alameda County.  The charge was reduced to an infraction
(down from a misdemeanor), and the fine reduced to $50 total.  Each of
the people the attorney represented (we managed to get in touch with 20
of the 21 people cited--not perfect, but very good, considering that the
last person was not on the net and had no forwarding address or phone
number) will be receiving some mail from Bob in the next few days with
the various court papers and instructions on where and when to send the
money.  We have until December 30th, 1994 to pay the fines.

I'd just like to say a few things, now this matter is finally resolved
to the satisfaction (sort of) of those involved:  I want to apologize to
everyone for inviting them into a situation that resulted in such a financial
and time drain to everyone.  It was a very expensive party.  Your patience
and good humor in the face of these obstacles is much appreciated by me.

I would also like to point out to the rave community at large that people
DO get busted, and DO have to pay real money to defend themselves and even
so may still have to pay fines.  Our crime (and it is considered a real
crime, not some civil offense) was in being present on publicly owned
land between the hours of 10PM and 5AM, even though this was neither
posted nor advertised.  We were not warned, nor asked to move on prior
to being cited.  We were very fortunate in not being cited for additonal
violations of the law.

What i'd like you all to think about is:  Why is it illegal, even criminal,
to do what we did?  What can you do, what can we as a group do, to change
these laws in the broadest possible cases?  Are you aware that many 
communities in the Bay Area, and really, throughout the nation, regard
people under the age of 18 out after midnight to be criminals? Are you
aware that it is a criminal offense to be present on East Bay Regional
Park land between 10PM and 5AM, regardless of your age?  That we were
prosecuted despite the fact we were disturbing no one (the police were
NOT responding to any complaint)?

This may sound high-falutin and hackneyed, but i believe this to be true:
My civil liberties were infringed along with everyone else's, and our
freedom to assemble was denied.  This is a serious threat to our
constitutional rights, and our human rights to freely associate in the
place and manner of our choosing.  Frankly, and baldly, I think it's
wrong.  It was very much a matter of financial analysis and time, however,
that affected our decision to plead no contest; to fight and win the case
would have been prohibitively expensive.  I, for one, got yet another
personal taste of the justice system in this country, and got yet more
exposure to the use of "community standards" and behind-closed-door
dealings of the legal system.  I'm very sorry we couldn't do more to
fight and win this case; I tried to do the best I could with the
resources available.  It's my hope that someday, someone with legal and
financial backing will challenge these laws which, though well meaning,
infringe our personal freedoms.  I hope you will join any such challenge,
should it arise.

Thanks to all of you for your financial and moral support during this
difficult time.  I hope it was a "learning" experience for you, as much
as it was for me.
-- 
====== Bryce Ryan ========== AMBIANCE ========= brycer@ultima.org =========

>either lesbians or lesbianism.
