>better than you do what you need, what you want, what is good, what is bad.
>All terms are absolute. It is the Ultimate Because I Said So.
>
>Female and Male have *nothing whatsoever* to do with this.

Patriarchy = male

Subject: we need a bigger pumpkin
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


Sunset was near the train tracks

I was chatting with a nice fellow who I had 
noticed blowing bubbles.  His name was Dave.
I was dancing a bit and thinking about the world
of people on the train and the world of people
dancing in the park. 

Then I meet John Draper (Mr Crunch). 
Dave, John, and I are dancing.

Dave is explaining the energy-refocusing techniques
and excercise regimen that allows John to stay up 4 days.
He doesn't eat much.
He dances.

Occasionally, John interjects an enthusiastic
comment while flailing about in front of us wild eyed
('Damn, you gonna Freak' - Big Bad Hank).  The music 
(respect) (in the most respectful manner) was clearly
affecting John in a positive way.

I'm thinking "what did he say?"
I try and explain how I had Thai food for lunch
and it was really good. I also like naps. In fact,
I sleep alot.

The music is good.  Very good.  We are dancing.
Another train comes by.  It moves the bushes.  The
wind increases.  The music is increasing.  It is stronger.

"... and so there are these energy points - John can find 
the weak ones ..."

The music is peaking.  I like the train.  Watching it.
Everyone is completely Going Off.  

and then
John 
Lunges Toward Me
Across the Grass
Buggy
Frantic
He SCREAMS - "I'm Evolving Into A Monster Who Doesn't Sleep!"

eeek
take it easy, girl

Everybody was down
Perfection
Another very nice Sunset


Dave

Sometimes I get just so fed up with this country and all of its fucking 
stupid laws that I want to live somewhere else.  Bryce's report made me 
sick to my stomach.  Groups of people used to be able to assemble without 
any problems once upon a time.  Now all these idiotic laws practically 
keep people prisoners in their own homes - then the politicians who make 
these laws complain about the lack of COMMUNITY!!! how hypicritical!!
Bryce, if there is anything I can do to help your/our cause, count me in!!

Amy

 On Wed, 26 Oct 1994, David Alves wrote:

> 
> Sunset was near the train tracks
> 
> I was chatting with a nice fellow who I had 
> noticed blowing bubbles.  His name was Dave.
> I was dancing a bit and thinking about the world
> of people on the train and the world of people
> dancing in the park. 
> 
> Then I meet John Draper (Mr Crunch). 
> Dave, John, and I are dancing.
> 
> Dave is explaining the energy-refocusing techniques
> and excercise regimen that allows John to stay up 4 days.
> He doesn't eat much.
> He dances.
> 
> Occasionally, John interjects an enthusiastic
> comment while flailing about in front of us wild eyed
> ('Damn, you gonna Freak' - Big Bad Hank).  The music 
> (respect) (in the most respectful manner) was clearly
> affecting John in a positive way.
> 
> I'm thinking "what did he say?"
> I try and explain how I had Thai food for lunch
> and it was really good. I also like naps. In fact,
> I sleep alot.
> 
> The music is good.  Very good.  We are dancing.
> Another train comes by.  It moves the bushes.  The
> wind increases.  The music is increasing.  It is stronger.
> 
> "... and so there are these energy points - John can find 
> the weak ones ..."
> 
> The music is peaking.  I like the train.  Watching it.
> Everyone is completely Going Off.  
> 
> and then
> John 
> Lunges Toward Me
> Across the Grass
> Buggy
> Frantic
> He SCREAMS - "I'm Evolving Into A Monster Who Doesn't Sleep!"
> 
> eeek
> take it easy, girl
> 
> Everybody was down
> Perfection
> Another very nice Sunset
> 
> 
> Dave
>

I just read my own post and decided it was kind of pointlessly drug oriented
so....here's some kind of point :-)

Everyone should try going out to a party sober as a right-wing religious
fanatic :-)  If you haven't tried this yet (no drugs? How do you do that?)
you owe it to yourself to try it once.  You will be amazed at how high you
get with no chemical assistance, though having had such assistance in the
past seems to help you "get there."    One good thing you will discover is
what your body really needs across the course of a night in terms of water,
food, etc.  Though some chemicals increase dehydration and some can make you
hungrier than normal, at least you'll know what's norma.  Ok, a double
expresso, guarana, or some power drink stuff will help you dance all night. 
Note that caffeine is addictive, dehydating and an appetite supressant not to
mention it comes from a plant grown in Columbia and is then refined and
processed, imported into the US and consumed with special paraphenalia to
concentrate the active ingredient in a viscous liquid(expresso!)  The street
price is quite high too, compared to homebrew ;-)

j..i.tt..tter..rrr.... .er er (jitterbuggers -great name - they had lots of
real original CocaCola you know - danced all night!)
phuture

Hello from Pacific!

Thanks to all who showed up at the Berkeley Aquatic park last Sunday, it 
was beautiful out there, and the police were once again chillin'.  
However, some people who came were spotted by locals doing such things as 
tagging buildings, urinating on buildings, and walking on the rail road 
tracks (probably not such a good idea given the locomotive factor).  In 
addition, two cars were broken into at the park.  All of these events 
were reported to the Berkeley police, and were connected to our party.  
As a result of these events and others events in the past at the Berkeley 
Marina, we will not be granted permits in Berkeley for a long while.  I 
do not resent the Berkeley police for their opposition to our party given 
the disrespect which some people have shown to this community.  I am, in 
fact, ashamed that people who attend our parties would enact such stupid 
maneuvers.  I urge anyone reading this to look out for foolish behavior 
around you in our scene and to point out this foolishness.  Perhaps we 
can collectively raise the standards of our celebrations so that we will 
be able to have them more easily in the future.

Anyway, on to the future: we have been organizing our side room at Funky 
Tekno Tribe, and it looks like we are going to be able to really do it up 
nicely.  The DJs for our room are going to be Dano, Binnie, Solar, Galen, 
Cyril, and Kenneth (hope I got the spellings right).  We have some cool 
art and trippy visual stuff planned for everyone to stare at!  This party 
is not free, but remember that some of the money taken at the door will 
benefit Pacific and allow us to bring you more dancing fun in the 
future!  Call: (415)266-8215 or (415)985-5264 for info.

After FTT is over, we are going to take our stuff out to a killer 
location in the city near the water for the Sunset Finale!  We're gonna 
start early, and continue through the day into the night!  This is the 
last one we're doing, so I hope to see everyone out there.  Let's end 
this party with the right vibe so we can all remember Sunset properly!  
Please, bring your love, respect, and smiles!  Tel: (415)985-5264

After this weekend we are going to chill a bit, and pay some more 
attention to the rest of life.  We will be throwing parties in the 
future, but less often and different from Sunset.  We hope that all of 
you will keep an eye our for our events, and come to them.  If you want 
to be sure of not missing any, you can send your mailing address (snail 
mail) to me <helagon@well.sf.ca.us> to get onto the Pacific mailing list.

I hope to see you all this weekend!  It's going to be PFHATT!!!
-Lorien

sorry about the non-topicality of this, but since many of you
also use netscape/WWW, I thought I'd mention a problem with
that browser -- it violates your internet privacy. fortunately
you can override the main privacy violation.

Yours in spreading fear uncetainty and doubt,
		Niels.

------- Forwarded Message
Xref: netcom.com comp.windows.x:80832 comp.infosystems.www:24529
Newsgroups: comp.windows.x,comp.infosystems.www
Path: netcom.com!mayer
From: mayer@netcom.com (Niels P. Mayer)
Subject: Re: Problem in X-Netscape
Message-ID: <mayerCyCE3s.G8G@netcom.com>
Summary: another problem with netscape
Organization: NETCOM On-line Communication Services (408 261-4700 guest)
References: <38k299$jel@eis.calstate.edu> <38mlgr$hld@newsbf01.news.aol.com>
Date: Thu, 27 Oct 1994 17:33:27 GMT
Lines: 64

Here's another even worse problem with netscape -- it sends your e-mail
and/or account name back to the HTTP server at the WWW site you are
browsing.  This is great for WWW sites interested in creating
interest-based mailing lists for future internet junk-mail and
direct-marketing. Of course this feature can be used for "good" as well as
"evil" -- but it is quite annoying and sneaky that the user is not warned
about this breach in privacy and security prior to using netscape.

Also, netscape sends HTTP servers information on the URL which referred you
to the current HTTP server. This will allow advertisers to collect
information on outside sites that they might want to influence with
advertising dollars.

By default most HTTP servers don't collect this information, but it is
trivial to set up an HTTP server that logs the account name, host,
and referring page for each access to the server.

Also note that I'm not against commerce on the internet, but I do believe
that people should know what they're getting themselves into by using
netscape's default settings. (Just like most people know that giving their
name/number/usps-address during a retail credit card purchase will put them
on a wide variety of mailing lists). But maybe you all *like* the idea of
the internet equivalent of MCI/Sprint/ATT calling you up and interrupting
your dinner....

Finally, I have nothing against MCOM or netscape -- I much appreciate
"mosaic done right", and in particular the effects of proper useage of
XtAppAddInput() in doing network reads...

| To: www-talk
| Subject: netscape sends your e-mail address??
| --------
| 
| We ran netscape into 'socket' and noticed that it was sending back
| one's e-mail address to the server. This seems kind of anti-social,
| somewhat sneaky, and a real privacy leak:
| 
| | >> socket -sl 8000 
| | GET / HTTP/1.0
| | Referer: http://home.mcom.com/home/welcome.html
| | User-Agent: Mozilla/0.9 beta (X11; IRIX 5.2 IP22)
| | From: frop
| | Accept: *
| | Accept: image/gif
| | Accept: image/x-xbitmap
| | Accept: image/jpeg
| 
| Fortunately, if you go to Options->Preferences->Mail And Proxies you can
| change the "your email" field to something else, and the "From" field
| above will change accordingly. 
| 
| For example, I was able to change the from line to
| 
| | From: marca@mcom.com
| 
| So now I guess I can read
| 	http://www.i.love.sheep.com/bondage-and-bleating.html
| in complete privacy. :-) Unfortunately, all the e-mail I send from mozilla
| will look like it came from marca... bummer.
| 
| -- Niels.
| 
| PS: what is the "referer" line for?


------- End of Forwarded Message

From sfraves-owner  Thu Oct 27 20:45:42 1994

	for sfraves@hyperreal.com id AA07247; Thu, 27 Oct 94 20:49:21 -0700
Date: Thu, 27 Oct 94 20:49:21 -0700

To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: holiday toy drive!
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk



		club townsend holiday toy drive for
		     pediatric aids patients

	the holiday season is quickly approaching!  each
	december club townsend sponsors a toy drive to benefit
	the in-patients of the ucsf pediatric aids unit.
	with a donation of a new, unwrapped toy, patrons
	will receive a discount on the admission price to 
	the club.

	this year club townsend will begin the toy drive on
	saturday november 12th.  the holiday party for the
	ambulatory and out-patients will take place on 
	december 4th.

	ucsf is a designated california childrens services
	hiv program centre, providing a clinic for screening
	and treatment.  the clinic offers testing, counseling,
	hiv treatment, and access to hiv preliminary testing
	treatments for pediatric patients from all over
	northern california.

	due to the increase in the infection rate of hiv and
	the occurrence of aids in children, the staff of club
	townsend is putting out a call to this community. 
	please assist us in providing joy to children during 
	the holiday season and throughout the year.

	gifts are needed for boys and girls from infancy to
	pre-teen.  besides coming to club townsend with a 
	toy donation, you can also contact us regarding placing 
	a donations barrel at your place of business.  donations
	of wrapping paper, ribbons and other gift wrapping
	decorations will also be greatly appreciated.

	for further information, please contact phil smith
	or audrey joseph at 974-1156.  please mention that
	you saw this posting here.

	thank you for your support!!

This weekend's choice is a no-brainer - Ethan and Bryce bring back
Friends & Family to Komotion.  Go early - it should get going
quickly...  Party hoppers might want to stop by Funky Tekno Tribe (may
be expensive) or the Halloween Megatripolis, which has a lot going on
too.  Afterward, find the final Sunset of the season - call for
location.

Thanks to everyone who's been sending info (especially Sun Kim the last
couple of weeks).  Please remember to send it to dhchung@us.oracle.com,
not dchung@us.oracle.com - someone else here's been getting a lot of
strange mail! :)

---------------------------- Radio/TV Shows ---------------------------------
Sunday evening 9-11pm - Universal radio at 89.1 FM.  Trance dance
        and power house.  Guest DJs weekly (SF & East Bay)
Sunday night 10pm-2am - Ambience w/Michael Hayes & David X  KWOD 106.5 (Sac)
Sunday night 10pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 47 - Progressive house, 
        acid jazz and "alternative" music views. (415) 281-3377.
Sunday night mid-3am - "88 Acid" w/Unknown KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
Mondays midnight-2am - "The Mix Show" KWOD 106.5(Sac) - lineup 916.551.0494
Wednesdays 10pm-2am - Belladonna, KFJC 89.7 (Los Altos) - last two hours
        are usually techno-tribal-trance and ambient
Thursday evening 9:30pm-12mid - Minor Minor KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF 90.3 (SF)
weeknights ~9pm - the Modern Mix w/Steve Masters KITS 105.3 (SF)

Found this in my mailbox. Thought maybe some of you might be able to help.
Seems like a nice guy.

Send responses to: FAAX@MUSICB.MCGILL.CA

Begin forwarded message:

Subj:  Raving!
Date:  Wed, Oct 26, 1994 11:24 AM PDT
From:  FAAX@MUSICB.MCGILL.CA
X-From: FAAX@MUSICB.MCGILL.CA (SARGENT,RYAN JAMES,MR)
To: yookeroo@aol.com

Hi there!!
My mane ie Ryan, and I am at McGill university.  I got your e-mail
number off of the Alt.Rave news group and was hoping that you may be
able to help me out with something...  I'm compiling a number of
articles for a small zine which I want to produce about Rave-Culture
as a class project...That's where I need your help, if possible.
Since you were on the internet, I guess I assume that you know more
about Raving than I do!! I was hoping that you wouldn't mind writing
a brief article or opinion piece which I would include in my project.

  Some of the things I had in mind were:
is there a philosophy to rave culture (why did it come about?)
Are drugs (extacy) or smart-drinks important, and why?
Do sexual/racial/social boundaries break down in environments
      like a rave?? (I think that they DO!!)
-----or any other topic which you may just want to write a quick
page about so as to help me out.
   I'm trying really hard to get in touch with people around the
world (I've got some answers from the states, canada, and australia!!)
I'd really like to have your input, too, though.

If you cant help me out, I understand but hope that you will write to
say that you got my messasge (I'm new on email and want to make sure
that I'm sending okay).  If you've got any questions I would be
thrilled (!!!!!!) to hear from you, and I hope that you can help
me out......

            'Till later!!  Ryan  FAAX@MUSICB.MCGILL.CA

Well, I knew my statement about the relationship between house and 
gospel/spiritual music 
was rather categorical.  I am talking about the more soulful styles of 
house music, i.e. with a lot of vocals, organ licks, etc. I try to keep
persective about music.  Check out the book The Gospel 
Sound for more info on gospel's influence on popular music (interesting 
stuff such as that
gospel is the only form of music organized matriarchally, except I would 
also include Womyn's music of course).  

My point was that since religious institutions are some of the most 
segregated in American society, and African-American religious music has 
so much to offer, the 9 O'clock rave mass people could use these elements 
to bring different people together, and that we would all be the richer 
for it.

David

On Fri, 21 Oct 1994, Sean Casey wrote:

>

> Detroit house, progressive house, Hi-NRG house, or... :)
> 
> Sean

Greeting all fellow ravers and Happy Halloween weekend! >:-}
I stopped by Grace Cathedral yesterday ( Thurs.) to check out the Rave 
Mass set up and thought I'd share what I know.. 
Grace Cathedral is located on Nob Hill, on California at about Taylor - 
near the Fairmont Hotel. It is accessible by Cable Car ( Calif. line) or 
via car. There is *very* little on street parking, so I recommend drivers 
park in the Masonic Hall garage. It cost $2.00 per half hour and is open 
24 hours. As tickets are free, this shouldn't set us too far back in the $$$
land :)
The Mass goes off AT 9:00 PM - from 9:00 until 10:30Pm - and that is 
it!!!!!!! So no showing up at 12 mid - we'll all be at F&F or FTT :):):)
I repeat 9:00 pm - 10:30 PM
The set up looks *very* *very* cool. We will be *surrounded* by visuals
on monitors and projection screens. There is a cool alter, intellabeams, 
and the 35 Sheffield people are really into it. I talked a while with 
Tom (T.C.) Hill, the lighting director, and some of the women, Ann and 
another lady whose name I missed - *really* nice people. I will be 
limping in on Saturday night, and look forward to seeing ya'll there!!
Peace and happy horrors! Lady Trash

From: ameba@netcom.com (allen jebian)
Message-Id: <199410282330.QAA21908@netcom11.netcom.com>
Subject: tribal future
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Date: Fri, 28 Oct 1994 16:30:53 -0700 (PDT)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4 PL23]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Length: 4915      
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

                                               WHY   TRIBAL  FUTURE  ?

     "The only thing constant is change"  Since humanity started keeping 
track of history, this maxim  
has been presumed correct. Many of the changes, if extrapolated 
indefinitely, unfortunately lead to the demise of the planet. Why is it 
that tribal societies, where there is no concept of fashion , maintain 
harmonious cultures for many thousands of years ?  A deeper look into the 
psyche of pre-literate peoples might illustrate to us all that indeed, if 
we are to survive, a peaceful future will have to resemble our ancient 
tribal past . 
    Before there were alphabets , people didn't read about the past  , 
they talked about it.  Prophesies and legends were told and retold from 
generation to generation , sung , chanted , or spoken from grandparent to 
grandchild in an unbroken verbal chain . Changes in the tribes tradition 
were unthinkable, very often taboo . The design of a clans clothing or 
the lyrics of a chanted legend would remain the same for hundreds of 
generations. In tribal societies there is truly no such thing as fashion 
because the very fabric of life is dependent on keeping the oral 
tradition unchanged .    
    History begins when people start keeping track of events by writing 
things down. Cultures without written alphabets are generally considered 
prehistoric . A written record fragments time into the past and the 
future with little emphasis on the now. The procession of fashion 
parallels the progress of history.   As we turn the pages of history we 
become accustomed to a seemingly endless cycle of newness ,we want new 
clothes every season , a new car every year, soon we will need a new rain 
forest, but can technology provide us with one? 
    In non-materialistic tribal societies, a person was judged not by 
their accumulation of wealth but by their generosity and number of 
friends. Great chiefs had few possessions at all, witness the potlatch 
ceremony where valuable gifts were exchanged only to be burned in a great 
communal bonfire. Perhaps there are valuable lessons to be learned from 
our ancestors who had a direct connection with the spiritual essence of 
nature and felt no need to interfere with the natural flow of things .  
Primitive cultures all have in common some form of ecstatic boundary 
dissolving ritual or ceremony that bonds people to the greater spirit of 
nature. People who have  dissolved the boundaries between themselves and 
the spirit of Mother Earth might feel less need to amass wealth or to 
dominate other people or species. 
    The thrust of technology throughout history has largely been to 
separate people from nature, at the expense of many less fortunate 
species. We have unwittingly become specists , letting the mediated 
experience of  entertainment and religion replace the direct knowledge of 
the planetary soul with the false concept that  western man is somehow 
above, or separate from, or superior to this wonderful world of peoples, 
plant, and animals that we call home . 
     Blaming technology itself is too simple an answer, but many 
destructive practices , if continued, signal the death of the planet.  
There are developments in technology however, that have the potential to 
create an electronic re-tribalization of society and help humanity 
remember our place on this sacred sphere . 
Virtual communities on-line are changing the way we perceive each other 
and share ideas, there is no pre-judgment of concepts based on sex or 
color, a new form of universal language has emerged. Another universal 
language is rapidly transforming the way people interact. House music, 
tribal dance music with a continuous beat is the soundtrack to an 
enormous youth movement worldwide. House parties are basically an updated 
version of an Indian Pow-Wow where certain members of the tribe provide 
the beat ( D.J.'s or drummers ) and the other members of the various 
tribes come together in peace to share the blessings of being alive, 
dress wild, act crazy and dance themselves into oblivion. Out of this 
oblivion is where one gains knowledge , direct experience of  the 
equality of all people and creatures of the universe.  The insight gained 
by abandoned tribal dancing changes a person , spiritual awareness is no 
longer a mediated experience but an irrefutable feeling.
     As more and more people have boundary dissolving insights into 
nature and more and more of these people link minds with each other via 
technology we can hope for a future where an awareness of  the spiritual 
value of nature is factored into decisions regarding the fate of the 
planet . By loving each other , dancing with each other , and 
communicating with each other we have our best hope for a future where 
all people, plants , and creatures co-exist in peace and harmony 
.                             

mark ameba

>01:00    Alex               Ethan
>02:30    Susan              Graeme
>04:00    Sean Casey         Jeff Taylor
>05:30    Deaks              Joe Rice
        ^^^^^^^^^^          ^^^^^^^^^^^^
>Is this main floor and this ambient room??????????

Better than that, Denis -- F&F will be running "anything goes" in
both rooms.  The people in the first column are in the front room,
the people in the second column are in the back.  

I don't know about anyone else, but expect something quite different
from me.  I'm pulling out a lot of silly collectables I've got,
including the famed KLF track "The Queen and I," which was banned
because it sampled (errr, stole) just about the entirety of Abba's
"Dancing Queen."  I'm thinking of my set as being a sort of "Mystery
Science Theater 3000" of music, including no-beat, spoken word, trance,
acid, industrial-dance, and disco.  I figured since I'll be in the front 
room I can just go insane.

To me, different spaces and environments bring out different moods
and types of music.  The reason my set at Megatripolis was so driving
was because I got really caught up in the environment -- the big
space, the intellabeams, the huge sound -- it was the right place to
showcase the driving acid trance I love.  But I couldn't get away with
playing certain tracks there, because a big room has a certain vibe.
Likewise, there are certain tracks I'd never play during a sunrise set,
they just aren't fitting.  So what I'm babbling about is that the front
room could be quite interesting because of the conditions it gives the
DJ to work with.  Ok, I'm going to shut up and go pick my records for
later.  See you all, and make sure you say HI when you come in!

Laura

Only one of us got ticketed. He was chosen to get the ticket because he had
the sound van in the park. The district attorny contacted him and wanted to
ask
a few questions (to see if it was worth proscuting, I guess). We all went to
the
interview and after explaining that it was a alcohol-free party. He decided
to
drop the charges and told us to get a permit next time.

Speaking of rabbits, I'm reminded of a very profound event that happened to me
not too long ago.  It was on Memorial Day in the middle of the Black Rock
desert at an event called Burning Man.

Not to far from our encampment, someone had corded off an area and placed a
replica of the ten commandments in it.  Later they added a cross and then
they erected three foot high white neon letters that spelled "GOD".  Some sort
of statement i'm sure.

My profound moment happened on Sunday night, a church night.  It was after
they had raised the man, and then razed the man, and then danced in the man's
ashes.  We had built a warm, welcome fire at our camp and many people had
joined us around the fire.  There wasn't much talking around the fire, mostly
just quite whispers and staring into the fire.  Occasionaly, even the
whispering would stop and all you could hear was the crackling of the fire.
It was during one of the really quite moments that a woman yelled out:

   "THERE ARE RABBITS ON THE OTHER SIDE OF GOD!!!"

Everyone looked at her kinda funny and then she stood up and pointed, "No,
look, rabbits" and she pointed over at the "GOD" sign.  And there, on the
other side of the God sign, there were man sized rabbits with pink bunny ears
hopping around on and looking quite cute.

And somehow, at that moment, a complete sense of "rightness" came upon me.  It
so strong that I knew that it couldn't be any other way.  The universe would
cease to be a fun and magical place without rabbits on the other side of God.

Ciao,

Purple Tiger

access.

get people movin.  was that single cell upstairs? or space time c?
it hardly matters, i didnt hear enough of them, workin a club is hard
when you feel like having fun.  damn.

get some?"  i felt like an e fiend bonding with other e fiends.  or
a support group exchanging first experiences.  man, i really regret not
be able to FF4.  

blathering off.

Oh shit!

Reminds me of my first rave, when I walked in and was assaulted by a
wall of sound, projections on all the walls, and a crazy insane vibe.
It's even more incredible to think I helped make it happen. Geeez...

At 10 till 10, the party was going and there were already 51 people
there dancing like fiends. I've been to an awful lot of parties and I
am totally impressed at people showing up early ready to party.
Tamotsu opened the "big room" and just tore it up from minute one. And
that pretty much describes the night. A totally insane vibe but VERY
friendly and a massive smile factor.

$3 bought you one hell of a party. Thanks to everyone for showing up
and spreading your good vibes around. You were just wonderful.

Sean

Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII

Precedence: bulk


I'm still trying to sort out and make some sense of what happened 
yesterday at Sunset.  The party finally went off at around 3:30 at the 
3rd & Cargo location after the first site was busted. Galen, Jason and 
the rest of the Pacific crew deserve lots of credit for persevering with 
this party despite no sleep and having to haul their equipment all over 
the City.  Those of you who were there know it was an incredible 
party--great energy, vibe, music, etc. But unfortunately, the world of 
violence invaded our world of love.

For those of you who don't know this location, the 
party was held out on a spit of land surrounded by water on three sides. 
To get from the parking lot to the site, you have to walk quite a ways 
along a winding path that has grasses and shrubs alongside it. At 
around 7:30-7:45, the music stopped, and someone asked whether 
anyone in the crowd had a cellular phone.  Apparently there had 
been a mugging in the parking lot. Someone was hit over the head 
(with a bottle? a gun?) and there was gunfire.  Luckily, someone 
did have a phone, and the police were called. Because of 
the distance between where we were and the parking lot, it was impossible 
for us to know what was going on. Rumor flew of course; there 
was a whole gang out there, they were coming down the path, they were 
hiding in the bushes along the path waiting for people to leave.  People 
took responsibility for sharing what information there was and for making 
sure no one left the site. We were stuck out there for about an hour 
until we got the word that the police were in the parking lot and it was 
ok to leave. There was more or less and exodus at that point; safety in 
numubers I guess. Walking back to the parking lot was eerie--in my group, we 
were all 
hyperalert, scanning the darkness for who knows what. I'm still shaken by 
this experience; I can't quite find the words to express how I feel. I do 
want to thank our community for pulling together in the face of this 
violence; we took care of each other as best we could. And I want to 
thank the man who had the cellular phone--I can't remember your name, but 
I appreciate your letting me borrow it. If the people who were attacked 
are reading this, my heart goes out to you.

Some lingering questions:
Does anyone know more about who was hurt and how serious it was?
Does anyone know why it took the police what seemed like forever to 
respond? (I heard they were called 2 or 3 times before they sent a car.)
Does anyone have better/more complete information? 
What is going on in this world when a group of peaceful, loving ravers 
is in effect held hostage by the threat of people with guns? I do my best 
to understand and accept through the prism of love, but I don't really know 
how to understand and or accept this. 

Kathryn  


From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 31 10:22:04 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id KAA01934; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 10:22:04 -0800

Received: from DECNET-MAIL (SCRUTON@JOYCE) by eden.HAC.COM (PMDF #2669 ) id
 <01HIX8059AQ88WZEI6@eden.HAC.COM>; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 10:20:18 PST
Date: 31 Oct 1994 10:20:17 -0800 (PST)
Subject: tribalality
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Message-Id: <01HIX8059AQA8WZEI6@eden.HAC.COM>
X-Vms-To: EDEN::IN%"sfraves@hyperreal.com"
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7BIT
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

i'm not sure condemning fashion/trendiness/change per se is a
  not towards or an embracing of tribality.
some anthropologists have found quite a lot of trendiness and fashion
  evident in rather untouched tribes, and archeologists have DEFININITELY
    ININIETLY (luv my spelling) found a great amount of exchange of ideas
     (read: ancient trends) between, say, a mountain tribe and a
      shoreline tribe (the adoption of shells as scapers, for example,
        or the exchange of medicinal herbs)
this was especially evident in the Pacific Northwest, where fishhooks,
  calabashes, masks, etc. were copied and exchanged all over the place.
    True, each region had it's own 'flavor', but that's still evident
     today everywhere you go in the world, beneath the Sonys and the
       Coca Colas....
IMHO, tribalism isn't about technology, trendiness, pop culture 
  OR THE LACK OF IT.  It's about your local area.  It's about the
    common kinds of things people in your locale see, think, and do.
      even a country club is a tribe of sorts, albeit a very close-minded
        one, yesno?

don't cast off those trendy shackles, 'cause an archeologist ten thousand
  years from now will be identifying yer "tribe" based on your type
    of car, musical preferences, or favorite type of soda pop.....
      that may sound cynical and hollow, but in a way, the style
        of totem poles you saw around north america 1000 years ago
          was basically a trendy way of showing off the family tree...

ok, you can castigate me now

Dave Scruton

started with "Because..."--absolutely BRILLIANT.

couldn't" and many more that I can't remember, but ~do~ remember cheering

series some time.

Subject: sunset thugs
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

I was leaving when people came running toward the party.  A couple
of young women were obviously upset.  They said they were beat up
by 4 guys with a shotgun.  This seemed serious to me.  I spoke
to others running back to the party.  I got the same story.

I immediately went over to the cab of the truck and saw one
of the Pacific guys (Jason?).  Anyway, I explained what was
happening and asked if he had a cell phone.  I said that we
needed to call the cops immediately.  He went and saw the
crying assaulted girl.  Solaar and Jason decided not to call
the cops yet.  I told a few people not to leave since it might be
dangerous.  I didn't want to cause rumors but it didn't seem
right to let groups of 2 or 3 innocent raver girls walk into an 
armed robbery situation.

Anyway, a few minutes later I started walking out (I was trying to
leave in the first place) with a small group of Pacific folks.
It was wierd how the story unfolded as we spoke to people still
arriving.  Some saw a commotion.  Some saw the gun.  Later people
saw 4 men running down street.  The last people I saw arriving
at the party knew nothing.  I left without any problem.


Dave

Subject: Planetary Mass
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com

Hi, everyone! This is my first post. :) I am pretty new to the Bay Area,
and it is great to be here after being in Rhode Island for the past six
years.

Anyway, I just wanted to tell everyone what an incredible time I had at the
Planetary Mass Sunday night. My friend Don and I had planned to arrive well
before the beginning of the service at 9pm. Unfortunately, we didn't allow
quite enough time for the bus and ended running up one of the steepest
hills I have seen in SF. We arrived, wheezing, at around 9:20. Luckily, the
event hadn't begun quite yet. We were pleased.

The mass was held in the basement gymnasium of the Grace Cathedral. The
space was rather plain, but the people putting on the mass had done it up
with several projection screens, some regular TVs, a pretty large stereo,
and an altar in the center of the room with a spherical projection ball
suspended above it. It was an impressive instalation.

What was most impressive was the feeling I got attending the mass. I am not
a religious person, or rather, I was not brought up within any organized
religion, but this Mass really affected me. I don't want this message to go
on too long, so let me conclude that these people from England really have
the right idea. I am glad that I was able to attend their service.

If you have any questions about what went on at the service, email me directly.

noahpb

I regret not making it to F&F, cause it does sound wonderful.
But my previous pleasure with Futur inspired me to ravage
Funky Tekno Tribe... and I wasn't dissapointed.
Big beautiful lights and lots of happy people,
and booming sound, and that, from time to time
is just a heck-of-a-lotta fun.  Although I am looking
forward to pursuing a whole slew of intimate personal
parties for a while now.. hopefully the next F&F will
be soon for me.
Pacific's ambient village wasn't really so ambient,
but it was real nice too.  A small room with clean funky
toons and more good dancing.
One particular pleasure fore me this weekend was getting my
housemate of three years to finally attend his first rave.
He's never danced in his life and never really cared for
all that "repetitive noise" I always play, but after
some slight mood alteration and submersion into the world
of the groove he was dancing and loving it.
When he left he said that he got in his car and turned on his
stereo with his tape of the pixies and said, "that beat sucks."
*grin*
Then I had a great time at Sunset... good people, good
vibe, good music... These parties were indeed the highlights
of my summer.  I hope next summer brings something so wonderful too.
As I was leaving I heard the music stop.  I made it to my
car safe and sound and didn't notice anything.
I'm shocked and horrified to hear about what happened.
My heart goes out to you who was hurt.
It's amazing how  much goodness there can be right alongside
the evils of the world.
Like getting my car stereo stolen while a few weeks ago while in
love with Wicked.
But, onward we go, with Salutes to the Pacific crew,
and all that I am with my heart and praise to the glory of
friends and house music.
It was good seeing you again, Cathy, and Andrew and Katheryn and Tom
and Jeff and Milton and everyone else and the pixie nymph girl who
was the definition of grace and beauty dancing outside to the
sunrise
Looking forward to Basics.
-john.

Unfortunately, I was unable 2 make it 2 the last sunset.  But after 
reading what U wrote about it, I'm kinda glad I didn't go!!  Here's my 
question, What in hell is up with that location!!!!  Since I've only been 
on sfraves for a short time, I'm not sure if this was already covered but 
if it hasn't, here is what happened about 3 weeks ago at that same place.

The event was called "bonding of the spirits" and was meant 2 be a 
wedding ceremony for Charles (Chaz?) and his fiancee.  Things started off 
on a bad foot from the beginning.  Our friend Trent went 2 park his car 
and we started walkin' up the path 2 where the rave wuz.  Soon we saw 
that someone was tryin' to start a fight with some other guy but luckily 
this got stopped by several other ravers.  Wondering where Trent was, we 
started heading back to the parking lot when we met up with a large-ish 
group of people.  They said that it "cost $2 to leave the party" and 
literally physically pushed us back and prevented us from leaving. 
Several other remarks such as "it costs $2 if U got blond hair" and "it 
costs $2 if U R a girl" were also said by them but eventually we were 
able to squeeze through them.  After finding Trent, we walked back along 
2 the rave.  Now, that same bunch of dicks had pushed a huge object (I'm 
not sure exactly what it was) across the path and were tellin' people 
that it cost $2 to get in.  We told them that it was Charle's wedding 
ceremony and that he had said it was a FREE event. They responded with 
"Charles?  we don't know any charles.  Give us $2!" and again literally 
pushed us around.  After 5 minutes of this bullshit we finally got past them.
	Now we kinda started dancin' but could tell that the vibe at this 
party was shit.  A little later I heard all these popping sounds and a 
huge group of peeple started walking *quickly* out towards the rocks and 
water.  I wondered why this was and assumed that maybe bottle rockets 
were being set off and people were afraid of gettin hurt.  Then I saw the 
dj take off his headphones and start takin' off in a direction.  WHAT?? 
That's when I noticed some guy by the water with a gun firing shots (lots 
and lots of shots). I could see the blaze of his gun.  At this point I 
turned and ran with everyone else as far away as possible. Soon it 
stopped, and about a half hour later the police showed up.  Apparently 
someone had gotten shot and was being operated on at the hospital.  The 
next day I heard that this person was paralyzed but that part might not B 
tru.
	So, what is up with all this??  How come the once peaceful rave 
scene is now erupting with violence??  More importantly how can we 
prevent it?? (having security 2 search people @ free outdoor parties 
would B difficult).  After the event that I just described, a week later 
someone pulled a gun @ some party at 24th and illinois, and now sunset.
What is our scene turning in2????
HELP!

HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

-sly                          
vekatz@ucdavis.edu

At 9:53 10/31/94, Kathryn Ankrum wrote:

>Does anyone know more about who was hurt and how serious it was?

Yes - my roommate and some other friends. They were walking up the path
when they saw some people arguing. One of them had a shotgun so they
dropped to the ground and hid, but were spotted when some other people came
up the path and confronted the armed man. My roommate had a guy with a
pistol point it at her haead and had another man put a knife to her throat
and they wnt through her pockets and took everything. One of her friends
was hit in the back of the had with the shotgun. After the robbers left
they went back to call the police - an action that one or more of the
Sunset organizers didn't want to take. (Possibly to avoid bust?) Anyway,
the police were called, but after they didn't show up within a half hour or
so they left, figuring they weren't going to respond.

The whole situation is really sad and disgusting. With the shooting at 24th
and Illinois a couple weks ago this leaves a bad taste for anything in the
city that dosn't have some sort of security.

hi, all!

glad to hear the good tidings of FFIV! and sorry to hear
the sad tidings of Sunset :<( 

Perhaps we should all become peace officers. Seems to me that 
would solve many problems. policing our own parties; free 
access to radio communication equipment; nifty visuals a la
cop car; a lot of badge flashing to discourage any hostile 
elements; 21-gun salutes for a REALLY KILLER SET a la oldtime 
ranchero/a fiesta! maybe a helicopter ride or two; insider 
info on spotting plainclothes; and best of all: peacekeeping!

and speaking of peacekeeping-

In other news, there was a Merc article about the 
Pentagon saying that they had officially replaced the 
word "peace" with "pre-hostility." so those of you 
who thought you might be in a peaceful state of mind 
should be aware that, segun los federales, you are actually 
in a pre-hostile state of mind.

and we wonder where it comes from.....

I wish some raver techno-heads over thirty-five would 
form a political menagerie- promising to give everyone 
an authentication key for a new direct democracy.
PAP- the People's Public Accountability Party.... 

Wistfully yours (sigh)-

jocelyn

I'm very sorry to hear about the violence at Sunset. However you must 
realize that the location was very risky. That part of town is very 
dangerous. It is easy to get upset and mad at the perpetrators,I 
certainly abhor violence but we must realize that these are societal 
problems and they have roots in very complex systemic problems. I'm 
not trying to make excuses for the muggers       but we must starty to 
realize that we are all interconnected and until our society really 
starts to address its systemic problems we will continue to be threatened 
with violence from many arenas.

I hope that the injured persons are okay and that we continue to spread 
positive energy as well as engaging in critical reflection and action to 
help transform our violent dominator society and world into something 
ecological and festive.

Ronan



From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 31 14:04:08 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id OAA11087; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 14:04:08 -0800
Received: from netcom20.netcom.com by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with ESMTP id OAA11081; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 14:04:03 -0800
Received: from DialupEudora by netcom20.netcom.com (8.6.9/Netcom)
	id OAA23521; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 14:00:41 -0800
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 14:00:41 -0800
X-Sender: ambient@localhost
Message-Id: <aadaa187020150068387@DialupEudora>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
From: ambient@netcom.com (Joe Rice)
Subject: All those F parties
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

>From what I saw both F&F and FTT went off in a big way on Sat. night. I
started out at F&F, where people started showing up _early_ and were
dancing by 10pm, the official start time. Definately a rare occurance in my
book. I liked what I heard in both rooms.

I decided to check out FTT since I was able to get on the guest list via
some timely luck. $25 is way too much for a party - especially a warehouse
party. I'd already heard some bad things about it - namely that they had
refused to honor the $15 before 9pm pledge and the wait in line was over an
hour. When we arrived at around 1am there was a huge queue outside. They
didn't handle getting people into the party very well. There was only one
point of entry and the searches were fairly severe, although it was obvious
they were just looking for weapons and bottles.

Once inside I remembered what a RAVE was like. This was it. At least 3500
people in a huge warehouse with a dozen varilites and intellabeams,
projections all over the back wall, two huge walls of speakers and having
to search to find your friends (whom I tried to convince in vain to check
out F&F) in the sea of dancers. The music when I came in was solid acid.
Garth came on shortly thereafter and played some slightly funky hard house.
I was surprised at how high the vibe was considering the number of people
there. I certainly never expected to see something like that in 1994. 1991
in LA maybe.

Big problem - $25. Pure greed. Sure, they spent some cash on the show - the
lighting alone was probably $10k estimated a friend of mine who works for
Impact - but $25?!? Even more ludicrous when I found out Kevin Saunderson
wasn't there.

I headed back to F&F shortly after 3, where the energy and heat had grown
exponentially since I had left. The walls were damp with condensation and
the floor wet with sweat. Despite the difference in numbers, the vibe and
energy were about equal with FTT, with people whooping at every acid
buildup. One thing I noticed was that the crowd at F&F was quite a bit more
heterogenous than you usual club or even rave crowd. There was a welcome
diversity in dress, age, race, and gender (preference, too). Another plus
were the freebies being handed out at F&F.

The music got progressively harder and faster in the big room, which wasn't
really my cuppa but people were going off to it, and that's what counts. It
was especially cool because it's rare to hear harder stuff spun anywhere.

The crowd thinned out quite a bit from 4-6, but quite a few stayed to the
end dancing and cheering.

Major props to Ethan & Bryce for organizing, promoting, setting up, and
seeding the vibe. It's the F&F's that are the foundation of the scene.

Joe

(Joe Rice:_______________________________)        ( welcome to the church )
(tic-tac@ultima.org <> ambient@netcom.com)        (of what's happening now)

someone stopped the music and asked for a phone very soon after we
started to walk out to the parking lot.

Subject: non-violent reviews
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


a review:

I went to Zendada on Friday night.  It was starting on the
early side (12) which worked for me.  It was also only $5.
Jon Howard and Taj were excellent.  

favorite House sounds (House people)
powerful Bass Abstractions 

Folks are cool but friendly toward each other.
This goes with the large club territory.
It warms up when the last tourists are gone. 
Well, it warms up a little.  No one is interested
in much besides dancing - just Do Not Stop.
This party peaked after 4.  
The allnight crowd settled in and went off.
Everyone had a few hours of 'warm up' dancing (lucky us!) 
and I was a super-loose.  Every move was *such* a pleasure ...
BTW, I discovered strange new ways to move my ankles.  My ankles
really appreciated this, of course.



pre-mugging Sunset review:

I missed the most recent city party (Presidio) but heard from
from friends that it pulled a different crowd than the Berkeley 
parties.  I have to agree.  A bit monochromatic.  Unfortunate 
lack of dancing grandmas and little children.  Otherwise nice.

Dave




From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 31 15:28:10 1994

	id PAA13227; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 15:28:06 -0800
Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 15:28:01 -0800 (PST)
From: Vladimir Katz <vekatz@ucdavis.edu>
X-Sender: ez053410@bullwinkle
To: sfraves@hyperreal.com
Subject: FF4
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.90.941031141654.5915A-100000@bullwinkle>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk

FRIENDS AND FAMILY FOUR WAS ONE OF THE BEST RAVES I HAVE *EVER* BEEN TO!!!!!!

The night of Oct 29 was probly one of the highlights of my life.  I just 
had the absolute fuckin best time.For anyone who wants 2 hear about it, 
here it goes:

	My friends & I arrived @ komotion at about 7:30.  Bryce, 
Sean(sp?), and a few others were still settin' up and we helped carry a 
few items in from the car.  This wuz the first time I had ever been to 
komotion and to be honest was quite shocked as 2 how small it wuz. "Oh 
well!" I decide, it will probly still B good.  I tend 2 prefer smaller 
vibier parties 2 huge events anyway. Unfortunately, my friends didn't 
share my opinion and convinced me to try out FTT.  We got to FTT at 
around 8 and stayed till about 9:20.  During that time the line didn't 
move AT ALL! BTW, off the subject, what is up with chargin' $25 for a 
rave?? Yeah, part of it was $15 but for that U had to arrive b4 nine 
oclock! Isn't that a bit early?  Isn't a 10 dollar jump in price abit 
much?? Especially since no one was let in b4 nine anyway??? We had 
encountered the same crap @ futur ($25 after 12).  I mean sure they spend 
a lot of cash, but from the amount of people there they make way more 
money!  Anyways, we had decided b4 not to pay $25, so when we found out 
that we couldn't get in for 15 we left and went back to FF4. We got back 
a little b4 10 oclock and the muzik was already on.No need 2 wait, we 
started dancin' right off. I cut open one of my glow sticks, and me and 
some girl put glo stuff in each others hair, but this didn't work very 
well at all(p.s. If U R readin this, what was your name? I completely 
forgot to ask U what it was!) Someone (it might've been sean, I don't 
quite remember) was passing around a whole box of blo pops.  This was 
*much* appreciated and from then on I just new the vibe here would B 
spectacular! The muzik also was hella good from the very start with 
Tamotsu(sp?) playin' a really cool set.  As more and more peeple arrived, 
the event just got better and better. Soon I popped a FAT hit of E that 
fuckin just rocked my world. The vibe here was the best I have seen in at 
least 2 years.  It reminded me of back when I had just started ravin.  
Everyone was all smiles and sooooooo friendly.  I met an incredible # of 
people at this rave and talked soooo much. Plenty of people had dressed 
up for Halloween (someone had even dressed up as a cop which scared me at 
first!).  Scores of people were handin out candy!  I go more candy there 
than I've ever gotten at a rave b4.  Everyone was just so unbelievably 
positive! Instead of many raves where I feel like I'm ravin' *around* 
others, here I felt that I was ravin *with* others.  Peeple were handin' 
out stickers and lots of peeple shared their toys with me.  The visuals 
were cool and I wondered what the videocamera was for.  If it was all 
videotaped I have got to have a copy.  I talked to Captin Crunch who I've 
seen at practicaly every single rave but have never spoken to till then. 
(If you R readin' this, U asked me to e-mail U but what was your address??)
Soon Bryce took over the turntables and played a hella cool set.  I think 
it was him who played master and servant.  Me and my best friend just 
went completely nuts (we *love* Depeche mode). What was that one song he 
played withe the sample "put it in"??  The dancefloor started getting 
*really* packed and *hot*. the fans helped some but not enough.  Not that 
the heat stopped me or anyone else.  Everyone continued jumpin around and 
dancin. Everyone was havin' such a good time I couldn't believe it! They 
were giving out free water and also chips and salsa (U guys filled my 
water bottle with *cold* water. THANK U!!!! I needed it bad!) Someone let 
me borrow their spray bottle and I danced around for a while sprayin 
everyone around me. They loved it being hot as they were altho I think I 
accidentally squirted the camera man. sorry! When Ethan came on he just 
TORE SHIT UP!!! He just played the most INSANE set! I went absolutely 
mental dancin to those hard poundin beats.  I just had to get my friends 
who were coolin' off outside, and dragged them back in to witness just 
how good the muzik was! They danced their asses off too.  I continued 
dancing for what seemed like an eternity. After a while tho my faces 
acshully started 2 hurt I was soo hot.(my friend said that my eyes were 
bulging outta my head and that I was acshully steamin'!!).  I took arest 
then started dancin again.  Even tho I was starting 2 get tired the muzik 
was just too good to resist!  I spotted Brian in his X-ing shirt and 
finally got 2 meet him after all that stuff I've read of his on the net.
The vibe was still hella up and even tho it was around 4 the place was 
still packed and people were still havin a wonderful time. I took a break 
outside around 4:30 but whe I came back in the heat was just too much to 
bear.  Also the muzik was a bit fast for that early in the mornin and I 
was kinda feelin nausious(sp?) from my E. So I left what had to have been 
the greatest experience.
	This is the first rave I've been to thrown by sfraves and I was 
just wonderin', was this night just an amazing exception or are all of 
your raves that good! I don't remember havin' that good a time in 
forever!  And all for only $3! Thanx guys soooo much for throwin such a 
good party.  No words can describe how good it was!  I think this might B 
my first post to sfraves(I've only been on for alittle over a week) so 
I'd love 2 hear from all of you that went (especially all the people I 
talked 2 at the rave). pleeze e-mail me.  I live in Davis THE most boring 
place in the world, and mail iz my only source of happiness here. Hope 2 
here from ya-  

HAPPINESS IS BEING AMONG FRIENDS

-sly   (VLAD)         
                 
vekatz@ucdavis.edu

     SFRave crew,
     
     WOW! Its really sad to hear that Sunset ( and the last one, no less ) 
     ended on such a sour note. I hope that the people attacked are o.k. at 
     least.
     
     I agree with many people that $25 is waaay too much money for a rave. 
     I went to FTT about 8:30 ish. At first they didnt let us in for about 
     an hour, which sucked. However, they surprisingly *did* try to keep 
     people from cutting in line.. which appears to be a big problem these 
     days. Also, when they let us in ( about 9:45ish the line started 
     moving ), they charged us only $15! So it was great to see them keep 
     their end of the bargain up. Does anyone have any idea when they 
     started charging $25?
     
     As far as the rave goes, it was just spectacular. FTT really knows how 
     to throw a great *big* rave. It's everything Cool World -should- be! 
     3/4 of the whole warehouse was just throbbing with people getting off 
     to a great vibe! Wow! So many people! Lots of smiles and hugs. 
     Actually, for the record, I think Milton hugged half the crowd! :) I 
     really enjoyed Simon and Graeme's sets. Just intense!
     
     The best thing was at 8:30am, when the sun was up, lights were on, and 
     yet still about 300+ people still dancing their heads off! What a 
     great vibe! That made me get into it even more. Boy, with choices such 
     as F&FIV and FTT, its becoming hard to choose :) . Boy, am I glad I 
     live here, and not in Duluth or sm'thing! :)
     
     Well, rave on folks!
     
     Si Choudhury
     
     PS. Anyone know any cool people who are looking for a roomate from 
         December on, in Noe Valley...?  I figure it cant hurt to ask
         fellow SFRavers....

From sfraves-owner  Mon Oct 31 16:53:15 1994
Return-Path: owner-sfraves
Received: by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) id QAA15541; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 16:53:15 -0800
Received: from mercury.sfsu.edu by taz.hyperreal.com (8.6.9/8.6.5) with SMTP id QAA15534; Mon, 31 Oct 1994 16:53:08 -0800

Date: Mon, 31 Oct 1994 16:53:08 -0800 (PST)
From: Sun Kim <sunkim@mercury.sfsu.edu>
Subject: FF4
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.com>
Message-Id: <Pine.3.89.9410311611.A22724-0100000@mercury>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
content-length: 2079
Sender: owner-sfraves@hyperreal.com
Precedence: bulk


I also have to admit that I had the best time there.  Mike, Ryan, and I 
arrived at the rave around 11pm to hear Bryce finishing his set.  I got 
to hear a little bit of Laura spin "A-Dull-Vise".. but didn't hear much 
else.  The three of us were stuck in the main room just groovin' to the 
music.  Sean gave us some popsicles and other people gave us some candy.  
I saw Ethan in his pink with green polka dot boxers.  (What a easy way to 
stay cool.)  He spun a great set and it continued on after that.  You 
know the music's great when you have to close your eyes because the sweat 
is getting in your eyes!  Even Ryan, who never danced at a rave, danced.  
He said "Now I understand why you dance at raves!"  It made me feel 
good to hear that from him.  

After taking a little breather outside and talking with my friend Ryan, I 
got back in to hear the ending of one DJ and the start of Sean's.  Great 
music!  It seemed like almost a contest of who could dance the longest in 
front of the DJ.  The five or six people in front of the DJ's just kept 
on dancing and dancing.  I loved every second that Sean spun.  

After I just couldn't dance anymore, I made my way into the main room
again.  As I was watching the time lapse video of people shopping in a
grocery store, at a bank, industry... all the inventions of industry and
human endeavor I began to see how people were so machine like in this
video.  It made me think to see that raves were against being
machine-like.  I can't explain how I felt but the whole video got to me. I
saw how people related with each other, and with the earth.  It seemed
wrong to see industry.. For some reason, I felt the pain of what seemed
wrong and I began to cry.  I just cried and cried.  The world seemed so
wrong.  I kept on thinking, "It shouldn't be like this."

Aside from this serious moment, Friends & Family was a blast!  Everything 
I wanted at a rave: great people, caring promoters, free water & fruit, 
in-and-outs, huge fans, visuals, and great music... all made it a 
wonderful evening.


Sun			sunkim@sfsu.edu

Mijo, this summer Carlos et al. did a good party series outdoors (equinox
and infinity) one with a map point and school bus, the other with a car
search. Neither was free (5-10$) but they were unbusted and there was no
violence, let alone tension. And they were blissful-smiley-happy-hoppy!

Security is not the only answer, and is not my favorite presence at a
party. Altho Falcon security (martin/FTT) has some pretty lenient, low
profile guys, and so does 1015 Folsom. Collar your dogs!

Vladimir Katz writes:
 > FRIENDS AND FAMILY FOUR WAS ONE OF THE BEST RAVES I HAVE *EVER*
 > BEEN TO!!!!!!

 > ...Someone (it might've been sean, I don't quite remember) was
 > passing around a whole box of blo pops.  This was *much*
 > appreciated and from then on I just new the vibe here would B
 > spectacular!

That was me :) and if you remember what I look like, introduce
yourself sometime! The blo-pops were provided by Maui
(ysh@netcom.com), who really *really* wanted to be there, give them
out, and send her love around, but she was so sick she had to stay
home :(.  Send her some hugs...

When I gave those out, about 10 till 10, I was on a contact high
already. From the smiles and the energy in the air, you could tell
people just *knew* something great was going to happen.

 > ...This is the first rave I've been to thrown by sfraves and I was
 > just wonderin', was this night just an amazing exception or are all
 > of your raves that good! I don't remember havin' that good a time
 > in forever!

They've all been really good--the best parties I've been to.  And the
different parties have very delightfully different characters. The F&F
parties have all been like F&F4: insane yet friendly parties that take
off from minute one and kick ass all night :). And massive positive
energy at all of them, they make me smile so much my face hurts :).
Liquid parties have a more renegade feel, but are also really
friendly. I usually come away from these with about 10 new friends.
And of course at Liquid Drano, techno can happen :).  The SFR park
parties are just awesome, and have the feel of the better GG park
bandshell parties. And I don't know how much the New Moon crew wants
to be associated with SFR, but they're definitely part of the family,
and their ambient/dance renegades are nothing short of inspiring.

We've got a bunch of really fine people throwing these parties just
for the love of it, and I think that's why these parties turn out so
good. We want to make something beautiful happen, and it often does.
When you come in the door, you're not $20 to us, you're family.

I consider it a privilege to be associated with the people who work on
these parties and especially the people who attend them and give out
their good vibes.

Once again, it's _very_ rewarding to put your own personal energy into
a party and see it flourish. If you want to get more involved, ask to
help out! If nothing else, you'll meet some pretty insane people :).

 > I live in Davis THE most boring place in the world, and mail iz my
 > only source of happiness here. Hope 2 here from ya-

Mosheh and Matt and I often have "micro-parties" in Davis; we have
some friends over and I play records and we watch Ren & Stimpy and
Beavis & Butthead tapes :). Send me some mail if you want us to let
you know next time we have one. If you spin, bring records! (Did I
mention black lights, strobes, a laser, and toys? We usually have
those, too :))

Sean

I'm so glad to hear theat F&F IV was a hit.  I unfortunately have been
working 1 and a half jobs lately, and Brian has been working the
equivalent of three jobs, so both of us were very tired and left soon
after I finished my set.

I must admit that I had *fun* being completely unapologetically cheezy
in the front room.  I wanted to do something different, and so I did :-)
I feel like a whole new world has opeened up to me in a way . . . I realized
I can spin hardcore, I can spin acid, I can spin trance, I can 
spin bizzare funny cheezoid stuff, and now I'd like to try ambient
some time.  It's very freeing to break the pigeon holes we put ourselves
in, no?


So anyway, THANKS everyone who came, especially to those who stuck with me
on my trip through some of the more obnoxious dance tracks of the late 80's.

Hugs,

Laura
